“I’m just happy to tag along,” Soos offered. “Speaking of tagging, I’ve never really known a minizora before. What’s it like being so small?”

“Terrible. No matter what I do, I can always look up people’s noses and see the horrors that lie within.” That got everyone chuckling. “But seriously, it’s not too bad. It doesn’t hurt that I’ve got a nice steed to take me places.”

“See. He admits I’m a steed.”

“It’s just easier than saying rented mule-ow!” Dipper groaned as his head was pinched. “Somebody help! A pair of sausage fingers are crushing my head!”

“You sure that’s safe, dude?” Soos asked.

“Oh he’s fine,” assured Mabel. “First day here that lumberjack guy stepped on him and he just walked it off. This,” she tightened her pinch, “is nothing.”

Dipper finally stopped yelling, showing that he was just putting on a show. “Yeah, she’s right. There’s a reason so many stunt men are minizora, you know. We can handle just about anything.”

“Anything?”

“Anything,” Dipper affirmed.

“How much can you bench-press?”

“I once saw him lift up a whole pizza crust.”

“Wow, dude. You’re like a super hero. Got the proportionate strength of an ant, only you’re already pretty small, so it’s not that impressive, but it’s still pretty cool.”

“Wow. Thanks a lot, Soos,” Dipper said, feeling genuinely moved. Part of why he was the bookish type was because most kids his own age just made fun of him for being small. It was a refreshing change of pace to actually hear praise.

Mabel grinned from ear-to-ear. She’d already liked Soos. They got each other’s humor. But in seeing how nice he was to Dipper, Mabel knew she’d made a new friend for life.

That’s when a roar echoed through the woods. Birds were sent cawing in terror as the team finally had a direction.

“This is it. This is it!” Dipper said in whispered excitement. Still sitting on his sister’s shoulder, he kicked at her through her sweater and urged her onward. “Ya, mule! Ya-ya, mule!”

“Dude. That’d be so offensive… if it weren’t so hilariously accurate,” commented Soos as he grabbed a long and sharp stick. Perfect for stabbing.
12131211.title: Fishing Trip

121312111.content:
Unfortunately, it all turned out to be a false alarm. What looked like the gobblewonker through the fog was really just a derelict rotted out boat covered in cute beavers. And what sounded like the gobblewonker was actually an old chainsaw engine being messed with by a beaver.

“But… I was so sure.”

“There, there, little bro,” consoled Mabel, petting his head.

“Hey. At least we got to see a beaver with a chainsaw. That’s pretty sweet.”

“Maybe that old guy was crazy after all.” Dipper slumped on his slumping seat.

“He did use the word ‘scrap-doodle’,” Mabel agreed, just as despondent. While Soos was preoccupied with the beaver, the preteen girl decided to make some distance to give her brother some ‘alone’ time; which of course meant that she stuck nearby at all times.

“This sucks. We didn’t find the gobblewonker, and what are we gonna say to Grunkle Stan? We ditched him over nothing.”

“It’s not so bad. I mean, yeah, it’s pretty bad,” agreed Mabel. “He seemed really excited just to hang out with us and we left him high and dry… in that dinky little boat.”

Then there came a rumble.

“Mabel. Did you feel-whoa!” Dipper slipped, but thankfully caught himself on Mabel’s lifejacket.

“Ahh!” Mabel screamed, pointing out into the water where something big was swimming around.

“This is it!” cheered Dipper, pulling out one of their last few cameras. “I just have to-agh. Mabel, hold still. I can’t get a good shot with you moving.”

“Uh, dude,” intoned Soos worriedly.

In the few seconds since Dipper had taken his eyes off the lake, the gobblewonker had come up to the shore, rose it’s long neck out of the water, and loomed menacingly over the trio. And then, just as Dipper turned back around, it roared.

“Ruuun!”

In complete disregard to logic, the aquatic gobblewonker flopped its mighty frame onto land and used its flippers to give chase after the trio. Dipper couldn’t run on his own, but he could stare into the jaws of death and warn the others where and when trees were falling on them. And while Soos was able to get them to the boat, the gobblewonker just hopped back in the water, where it was significantly faster. What followed was an exciting chase across the lake, overturning many boats and causing general mayhem. Grunkle Stan would have found it hilarious, were he not on the business end of it.

“Ahh! Beavers!” cried Mabel as beavers began raining down on the boat. With their home just destroyed, the little fuzz balls were understandably agitated and were biting at anything they could reach. “Ahh! My brother!” Before one of the overgrown rats could chomp the little guy, Mabel beat him to it and stuffed Dipper in her mouth for safe keeping.

This was hardly a new experience for Dipper. He’d been eaten by his sister more times than he could count, though usually it was under less life threatening circumstances. The air was humid, Mabel had apparently forgotten to brush this morning, and saliva was creeping into his clothes. Keeping her lips shut, Mabel was still screaming as Dipper bounced around on the soft tongue. In a brief respite, he caught himself thinking that this wouldn’t be so bad if only he weren’t wearing sticky clingy clothes, but that was neither here nor there.

Pulling out a flashlight, Dipper opened the journal and quickly searched for anything related to the gobblewonker, but instead found a very interesting map of the lake. He tapped at Mabel’s teeth and signaled her to open her mouth. She did, screaming as she’d taken over the steering after Soos had been incapacitated by a beaver. “Head for the waterfall!” Dipper instructed as he clung to the tongue for dear life.

Mabel did, and everyone braced themselves for the worst. Fortunately, the journal proved true. There was a cave on the other side. Even better, it was too small for the gobblewonker, rendering it stuck.

“It’s stuck!” Dipper cheered, patting himself down within his sister’s maw. “Wait, I don’t have any more cameras!” he exclaimed in a sudden panic.

“Blah.” Mabel extended her tongue with her brother upon it and removed his hat, where he still had one tiny camera left. How lucky were they to find a place that sold tiny cameras? “Zare,” she said helpfully with her tongue still occupied.

Overwhelmed with elation, Dipper danced around on the tongue as he ran through the entire roll of film. “This is it! We finally got the picture.”

“Yay!” Mabel also cheered, ignoring the taste of fabric. It was more fun to play with a naked brother in her mouth than a clothed one. This would be important information to consider for later.

However, while everyone was cheering, the gobblewonker’s flailing caused a light cave in, leading to a large rock crushing its head and making some odd metallic sounds.

“What the?” Mabel started to ask. “Ahh, Dipper!” She reached out, but the little guy was already hopping down the cliff with the speed of a goat.

“Wow. Quick little dude, ain’t he,” observed Soos.

“You have no idea,” Mabel grumbled irritably. She hated when Dipper ran away from her, especially towards something so obviously dangerous. Her own efforts to follow were slower and more careful. Oh, Dipper was going to pay for making her worry like this.

“Hey guys, come check this out,” Dipper called from atop the creatures back.

Once they’d arrived, they found one of those spinning door cranks. It was on Mabel and Soos to open it up, revealing…

“Old man McGucket!”

The town kook was at some kind of control panel. It was defunct now, but clearly he’d been piloting the gobblewonker. As it turned out, he’d built this behemoth killing machine because he felt neglected and wanted some attention, especially from his family. While even he admitted that it was pretty contrived, his story did move the kids to sympathy for their own old person.

In the end, they all decided to make up with and spend the rest of the day with their favorite Grunkle. Fishing turned out to be a lot of fun. Even fleeing the lake police was enjoyable. All was well, except that there was an old man in a cave with a history of building death machines and the stated intent of making a death ray. Not to mention that Dipper never finished reading the lake segment of the journal, which had a good many pages devoted to the real life gobblewonker.

With the sun set and the day concluded, the Pines family and Soos departed the lake for their respective homes. Mabel held Dipper in her lap all the while, wondering how she was going to deal with her brother’s reckless behavior.
121312111.title: Gobblewonker

1213121111.content:
Following dinner at the Mystery Shack, Dipper and Mabel decided to wash up before heading to bed; especially Dipper who was all too eager to discard his saliva drenched clothes.

“Hey Mabel, could you get a cup of water or something?” asked the naked twelve year old of his undressing twin sister.

“Huh?” Standing in the bathroom, Mabel was down to just a pair of blue panties. She stared at her tiny naked brother, free of any sense of shame. They’d been bathing together since they were born, so the sight of the other’s naked body was nothing new to either of them.

“It’s just I don’t want these,” Dipper gestured to the clothes in his arms, “to dry and get all crusty before they can get washed. You know what crusty clothes are like.”

“Ugh! Only cuz you won’t shut up about it,” grumbled Mabel as she picked up the pile of garments and reached over the sink to ready a glass of water. This brought her bare and underdeveloped chest awfully close to her brother, but Dipper’s eyes were on something more important than her little nubs.

“Is something wrong, Mabel?”

“What? No. Of course not!” She kicked at the carpet. “Why would you think something’s wrong?”

Dipper cringed. “Oh, you know, no reason. Just being a concerned brother is all.”

“Concerned brother, huh? Is that what you call it when you leave me behind and run straight towards a giant monster?”

“Hey, give me a break. I was curious.”

“Curious, huh? Curiosity killed the cat, Dipper!” she said like it was some scathing accusation.

“In my defense, a giant rock just fell on the thing’s head. It was either dead or concussed. Either way, I’m too small to be looked at as prey. I was perfectly safe.”

“There’s nothing safe about giant sea monsters, little Dipper. You could have been hurt. Do you have any idea how worried I was?”

Dipper was taken aback when he caught his sister sniffling. Her eyes glistened before she turned her back on him. He reached out for her. “Mabel…”

“I’m taking a shower,” she huffed, slipping off her panties and discarding them to the side. Her immense hair shielded the back of her body as she marched off to the tub.

With a defeated sigh, Dipper turned back to the sink. He’d have preferred to shower with his sister like usual, but there were accommodations in the nozzles for a minizora to handle, so at least he could pour himself a steamy bath. The little boy dove in like it was a pool and swam around idly. Every now and then he’d turn to the silhouette of his sister in the shower, but she said nothing. She wasn’t even singing the latest awful boyband hit, but the only thing more awful than that was the ongoing silence.

“Um, Mabel,” Dipper called, but got no answer. He heaved a sigh. “Look Mabel, I’m sorry I made you worry, but I don’t think you’re being very fair right now. We were both in danger you know. How do you think I felt with everyone running for their lives and me being able to do nothing to help?”

Finally Mabel tossed the shower curtain aside and turned the water off. “That’s not your job, Dipper. I’m the big sister, so that means I-”

“There, right there!” Dipper accused. “That’s what’s not fair. We’re twins, but you’re always putting it on yourself to protect me even though I’m just as worried about you.”

“That’s not the same.”

“Except it is. That whole gnome debacle could have been avoided if you’d just listened to me from the start. I tried letting you do things on your own, and look where that got us.”

Mabel scoffed in disbelief. “So what? You want to be the big sibling and look after me from now on? Ha! I’d like to see that.”

Dipper rolled his eyes. “I’m trying to say that it’s unfair of you to think you’re the only one that gets worried. You’re my sister and I want to see you safe, but I still let you go out and make your own mistakes. I don’t smother you.”

Mabel blinked. Dripping naked, she stepped out of the shower and over to the sink. “Is that how you feel about me?”

Feeling sheepish, Dipper grabbed his arm and averted his gaze. “Sometimes.”

“Well… I guess it was kind of unfair of me to forget that you get just as worried as I do,” Mabel conceded. “And maaaybe I overreacted just a tad this time with the gobblewonker.”

“Not during the attack, though. Only after,” Dipper corrected. “When that thing was after us, you actually listened to me. You trusted me to make the right call and that’s what pulled us through.” He reached out and motioned for Mabel to come down to his level. She did, lowering her chin to the counter and extending a hand; whichever he’d prefer.

Dipper went for Mabel’s cheek and gave it an affectionate pat. “All I’m asking is that you trust me a bit more. Trust me like I trust you.”

Mabel sniffled and stroked a finger down Dipper’s back. “I’m still going to be worried about you, though.”

“Like I could stop you,” chuckled Dipper. “Hey, you forgot to tell Soos the whole story with the lumberjack guy. You know, where you started attacking him like you had rabies or something.”

Mabel giggled. “Hey, I was just trying to teach him a lesson about watching his step.”

“Animal control was called and the guy’s shoes were ruined,” Dipper deadpanned.

Mabel sighed fondly. “Yeah. I think I hate the taste of shoes.”

“Everyone does, Mabel. But you’re one of the few people who takes the time to make sure.”

Humming contentedly, Mabel picked her little brother up and carried him to the shower. “Want to join me?” she asked while stepping back in.

“Sure thing.” Though Dipper just expected their typical mutual wash, his sister had something else in mind as she casually tossed him in her mouth.

“Ooh yesh,” Mabel said through her mouthful. Naked Dipper was so much better than clothed Dipper. She couldn’t quite put a name on his flavor. She’d licked skin before, her own and that of others, but in those cases it had been tasteless at best and gag inducing at normal. But with Dipper, there was just some intangible quality that made him absolutely delicious. She was content to just chalk it up to being another minizora thing and leave it at that, but for right now she had the more pressing priority of running her tongue over every square inch of his body.

Mabel licked over Dipper’s face, feeling him smile. She licked under his armpits, which made him thrash about from being tickled. Over his butt got a similar result, but by far the most exquisite part of her brother’s body was his groin. Somehow that tiny penis and pair of balls had the strongest flavor of any part of him. And when she devoted special attention there, she giggled at how he grew erect. She loved how she could do this to him. For all their talk of trust and respect, Mabel would never relinquish the power of being the big sister.

Inside the moist maw, Dipper was moaning as he was pelted on all sides by soft flesh. When it was just his bare skin, the stickiness didn’t bother him as much. In fact, he rather enjoyed being in his sister’s mouth. He enjoyed being played with, of being tossed around and toyed with. Mabel knew all the right ways to touch him that just felt so incredible. And now that she was focusing on his penis, the little boy cried out in rapture as he bucked his hips into the slimy organ.

Mabel continued her affectionate tongue bath until she’d achieved her reward. A tiny but potent sprits of sweet and sour flavoring. It was the perfect dessert after a long day of monster hunting, a treasure that was hers alone to enjoy. She hummed, continuing to toss her brother around her mouth until finally that extra special flavor disappeared and she spat him back out. “Have fun?” she beamed, already knowing the answer.

Panting from his ordeal in Mabel’s hands, Dipper looked up and gave a weak-armed thumbs up. This was their way of saying that all was forgiven. From there they got cleaned up properly, dressed for the night, and went to bed. All was as it should be, with not a care in the world devoted to the old man and his death ray, nor the mysterious triangular constellation that briefly appeared in the night’s sky.
1213121111.title: Twin Confrontation

12131211111.content:
In the TV room, Dipper sat on his sister’s shoulder while they ate popcorn and watched the latest episode of Ducktective.

“That duck is a genius,” awed Mabel as she went through the motions of giving a single corn to her shoulder occupant.

Dipper shrugged, unimpressed. “Eh. It’s easier to find clues when you’re that close to the ground.”

“Speaking from experience?” teased Mabel as she poked him in the gut. “Like you could actually outwit Ducktective.”

“I’ll have you know that I have very keen powers of observation,” Dipper boasted. “For example: Just from smelling your breath, I know that you’ve been eating… an entire tube of toothpaste?”

“It was so sparkly,” Mabel confessed, sounding just a bit sick.

“Hey dudes. You’ll never guess what I just found!” declared Soos.

“Bur-” Dipper was silenced by a finger over his mouth.

“Buried treasure!” exclaimed Mabel. “Ha. I win.”

As it turned out, the ‘buried treasure’ was a secret door hidden behind the wallpaper. Within was a room filled with wax dummies of various historical figures. Grunkle Stan told the story of how he’d ‘purchased’ the figures years ago, but then locked them in here after the wax museum stopped being profitable, and also he’d just forgotten about them. When it was discovered that wax Abraham Lincoln had melted, Mabel had jumped at the chance to remake it into something new. When being offered free labor to resurrect an old and potentially profitable attraction, Stan was all too happy to oblige.

Later that day, Dipper was enjoying a rare instance of independence without being carried around by Mabel. It felt good to stretch his legs and do little things like get his own soda. Walking down the hall, he was enjoying a few sips when Mabel sprung out of nowhere, causing him to drop his drink.

“Dipper, I have to show you my ideas.” She held up a sketchbook. “She’s part fairy princess, and part horse fairy princess,” she described of the abominable centaur monstrosity.

“Mmmaybe you should carve something from real life,” Dipper suggested, not wanting to crush his sister’s artistic dreams.

It took a bit of trial and error, but eventually Mabel settled on sculpting a very special member of her family.

“Wow, dude. Your sister’s, like, really good at this,” Soos commented from the doorway.

“Yeah. Once she gets in one of these artsy moods, basically nothing can stop her.” Then Dipper got an idea. “Hey, Soos. I’ll pay you five bucks to go in there and tell her to stop.”

Soos glowered down at the little dude. “Dude, I’m no Albert Einstein, but I’m not stupid. I heard the full story of what happened to Manly Dan and there ain’t no way I’m sticking my hand in a fish tank filled with piranha.”

Dipper chuckled. “Yeah, fair point.”

Later still, there was a big ceremony for the reopening of the wax museum. At the ticket booth, Dipper sat alongside Wendy. She was the fifteen year old ginger who worked the Shack’s counter most days. Her body was leanly built with well-defined muscle, a modest chest for her age, and a rump that was nothing to scoff at. She had a fondness for flannel shirts and wore a fur hat.

Dipper was pretending not to notice the afore mentioned details as he sat in a tiny chair on the table. Technically his job was to guard the money jar, but he had the feeling that he was actually being used as just another oddity to attract customers. “I can’t believe how many people showed up for this. It looks like half the town is here.”

“I know, right,” agreed Wendy in her usual laidback demeanor. She was also pretending not to notice Dipper. She’d never seen a minizora before and there was something about this little cutie that kept drawing her eye. “Folks around here must be super bored. Either that or Stan bribed them.”

Dipper unfurled a green bill from his jacket. “He bribed me.” Wendy pulled out her own bill and they shared a laugh. This was nice. Aside from his mother and sister, Dipper had never really hung out with a girl before, especially not one this pretty. It wasn’t weird that he thought she was pretty, right?

When the unveiling finally got underway, it was tragically met with a lukewarm response from the audience. Fortunately, Mabel was not so easily deterred. “Thank you all for coming. I made this sculpture with my own two hands. It’s covered in my blood, sweat, tears, and other fluids.”

While the rest of the audience gagged at the implications, Wendy stole a wary glance at Dipper. Reluctantly, the minizora nodded that this was the case, to which Wendy commented, “Hehe, gross.”

“I will now take questions!” Mabel announced.

“Old man McGucket. Local kook,” he introduced himself. “Are the wax figures alive and – follow-up question – can I survive the wax man uprising?”

“Um… yes! Next question.”

A few more questions followed before Shandra Jimenez spoke up. In this one horse town, she was considered the only ‘real’ reporter. She was Hispanic with dark skin, high cheek bones, and one of the finest bodies in all of Gravity Falls. “Your flyer promised free pizza with admission to this event. Is this true?” Despite her dispassionate tone, this questions seemed to wake the audience up as everyone was up in arms. Literally. Some people had actually brought pickaxes and pitchforks to a wax museum opening.

“This probably isn’t good,” Wendy observed, bracing herself to run. She then remembered her table companion and suddenly felt awkward. Was it okay to pick up a minizora without asking, even in an emergency?

Sure enough, Stan dismissed what had apparently been the primary interest of the audience and attempted to flee with the money. This in turn led to a small riot in which chairs were thrown and poles were punched. Wendy, ever a girl of action, snatched Dipper off the table, stowed him in her breast pocket, and ferried him out of the danger zone.

Dipper wasn’t too worried about his predicament. He’d been picked up by strangers before, but Wendy wasn’t exactly a stranger. She’d never been overtly hostile and generally treated him with better courtesy than she did most patrons of the Shack. The inside of her breast pocket was hot and the fabric was a little itchy. It also smelled. Dipper knew that there was only one thing he could be smelling at this time and wasn’t sure how he felt about it.

“Hey! No punching the banner poles!” Mabel snapped, pointing at Manly Dan the lumberjack. As soon as the pair’s eye’s met, the man who resembled a shaved red yeti decided to be anywhere but near that sack of adorable crazy. Once the audience dispersed, Mabel casually walked over to Wendy and with her eternal cheerfulness, held out her hand in a gi-me gesture. Wendy obliged and surrendered the tiny twin. “I think that went well,” Mabel commented.

“Actually, yeah,” agreed Wendy. “Compared to how these things usually go, there’s almost no damage. Oh, and sorry little dude,” she said to Dipper. “For picking you up without asking, I mean. It was kind of a spur of the moment thing.”

“Oh hey,” Dipper laughed nervously. “It was no big deal.”

“Not big, but adequate sized,” Mabel commented to the confusion of the others. “You acted quick and decisive, prioritizing safety over personal autonomy. And for that, you have my respect.” She extended her other hand, which Wendy happily shook.

“Wow. That’s… unsettlingly authoritarian, but whatever.” The red head shrugged. “I just didn’t want the little guy hurt is all. Oh well.” She set her hands on her hips and surveyed the mess. “Looks like a lot of work to do. Think I’ll clock out early.” And she beat a lazy retreat.

Mabel grinned as she watched the taller girl go. “I like her.”
12131211111.title: Headhunters

121312111111.content:
Later that night, Dipper and Mabel were upstairs brushing their teeth. Mabel had just suggested a tooth brush race when they heard the cries of horror from downstairs. Being a couple of twelve year olds who’d already faced down two horrifying monsters in less than a week, they decided to run towards the sound of danger. That’s where they found the source of the commotion. Wax Stan had been murdered via decapitation and his head was nowhere to be found. It was so gruesome that Mabel fainted; (accidentally) crushing Dipper under her butt.

The police arrived in short order, given that this was probably the biggest criminal activity they’d seen in weeks. Even so, the sheriff seemed reluctant to even do minimal investigation, so Dipper volunteered.

“Thank you Dipper,” squeed Mabel, hugging him to her cheek. “I knew I could count on you.”

“Oh, well would you look at what we got in here,” taunted Sheriff Blubs. “City boy gonna solve the mystery with his fancy computer phone.”

“City boooy!” called the deputy. “City boooy!”

“You are adorable,” Blubs added, leading the both of them to laugh.

“Adorable?” Dipper asked. He’d been called a lot of names over his life and had learned to shrug off most of them, but for some reason this one really dug under his skin. When the cops left, Dipper was filled with righteous indignation. “That’s it! Mabel, you and me are going to find out who did this and get back that head. Then they’ll see who’s adorable,” he snarled, trying to look as tough as possible. Then he sneezed.

“Aww. You sneeze like a kitten,” Mabel cooed, finding his wrathful glare all the more endearing.

The next morning, the investigation was underway. The twins were taking photos for evidence, compiling a list of suspects, and consulting the journal for anything supernatural that might be related. Yet it was Mabel who found the first clue in the form of shoeprints in the shag carpeting.

“Dang. How did I miss that?” Dipper grumbled. “So much for being closer to the ground.”

“Some things you can only see from high up,” Mabel explained.

“Whatever. The point is that these shoeprints have a hole in the left shoe. That’s pretty unusual. And they lead to…” An axe was found just behind the chair. Dipper just glowered at the axe for a solid few seconds. “We’ve been here literally five minutes and already found the murder weapon, but a couple of ‘professional’ cops didn’t do jack,” Dipper ranted.

“Hey, maybe they were tired,” Mabel excused. “Or, you know, I hear towns like these include playing FPS games as part of their police exams.”

Dipper frowned. “Now it feels like I’m racing against someone without arms or legs.” He then slapped himself for daring to pity the enemy. “Doesn’t matter. We’ve still got a mystery to solve!”

After conversing with Soos, the axe was connected to Manly Dan, who frequented an intense biker joint downtown. Soos also tried coining the term ‘mystery twins’, but Dipper was in no mood for cute names. Grunkle Stan, upon seeing the kids with an axe and plans on confronting the possible murderer, cheered them on to “Avenge meee!”

Dipper was suffering an increasingly low opinion of the town’s collective IQ after Mabel’s fake IDs actually got them into the bar. Inside there were all manner of ruffians punching one another for no discernable reason. Still the picture of perkiness, Mabel deposited Dipper in her sweater collar and attempted to hold him close. However, much to her consternation, he wiggled free.

“Come on, Mabel. We talked about this already.”

“Now? You want to go off and do your own thing here of all places?” When Dipper just crossed his arms and impatiently tapped his foot, Mabel gave a conceding groan. “Okay, fine. But if you get stepped or sat on, that’s on you.” And they split up. Dipper went straight for Manly Dan while Mabel decided to destress by chatting up a very tattooed and burly man.

“Manly Dan, just the guy I wanted to see,” Dipper greeted, trying to look tough as he stood on the arm wrestling machine Dan was playing. “Where were you last night?”

“Punching the clock,” growled the lumberjack, sounding like he was perpetually on the verge of going into a blood rage.

“You were at work?”

“No, I was punching that clock.” He pointed out the window to a clock atop a crooked post. “It offended me with its incessant ticking.”

“Ten o’ clock, the time of the murder,” Dipper mumbled. He then regretted not bringing Mabel along as he dragged the axe over for inspection. “So I guess you’ve never seen this before?”

“Listen here, little girl,” Dan barked.

“Uh, actually-”

“I wouldn’t pick my teeth with that axe. It’s left handed. I only use my right hand.” He demonstrated this by ripping the arm off of the machine. “The MANLY hand!”

As Manly Dan proceeded to beat the snot out of what remained of the machine, Dipper backed away, feeling that he’d been sufficiently emasculated for one day. He caught up with Mabel doing some weird school yard fortune telling thing and gave her the update. They just had to run through the list of suspects and see who was left handed.

Unfortunately, that proved easier said than done. One montage later and it turned out that there wasn’t a single leftie in the whole town. Even when the twins thought they’d cornered someone, they learned far more than they ever wanted about Toby Determined. They did get an extra clue that the axe had no prints at all, but that just deepened the mystery. Worse, the cops laughed at them.

Defeated, the twins returned to the Mystery Shack to attend the funeral of Wax Stan. It was a tasteful ceremony held in the wax figures’ old room with all of their lifeless forms in attendance. To Soos and Stan it looked like the twins were down about the murder, but they were mourning another loss as the adults left the room.

“Those cops were right about me,” Dipper grumbled in Mabel’s lap.

“Come on, Dipper,” Mabel encouraged, petting Dipper with one hand and holding the axe in another. “We’ve come so far. We can’t give up now.”

Dipper sighed, hopped down to the floor, and headed for the casket. “But I considered everything. The weapon, the motive, the clues…” He climbed up to get one last look at the dearly departed, where he noticed something odd. “Hmm. Wax Stan’s shoe has a hole in it.”

“All the wax guys have that,” Mabel explained plainly. “It’s where the pole thingy attaches to their stand dealies.”

“What has holes in its shoes and no finger prints?” It didn’t take much before Dipper’s eyes went wide and his pulse quickened. “Uh, Mabel!” he whispered in alarm. “I think the murderers are-”
121312111111.title: Wax Murder

1213121111111.content:
“Standing right behind you,” finished Wax Sherlock Holmes as he and the other wax figures all came to life.

“Oh-my-gosh-oh-my-gosh-oh-my-gosh,” Mabel panicked as the axe was ripped from her fingers by Wax Lizzie Borden, the infamous axe murderer. Naturally, Mabel responded by immediately pulling her brother close for safety.

“Congratulations my two amateur sleuths. You uncovered the truth,” patronized the detective. “And now we’re going to bury you.” He pointed his magnifying glass like a weapon.

“But… how is this possible? You’re made of wax,” asserted Dipper in disbelief.

“Are you… magic?” asked Mabel, giving in to her girlish wonder.

“Magic. She wants to know if we’re magic?” mocked Wax Sherlock before slamming his fist on the casket. “We’re cursed!”

“Cursed!” echoed the other figures.

“Cursed to come to life whenever the moon is waxing.”

“Uh, sorry to interrupt, but that doesn’t sound like a curse,” Dipper piped up. “Curses have more of a negative implication. Like if you were the real guys who were turned into wax. That’d be a curse.”

“Yeah,” agreed Mabel. “Being able to come to life sounds like a blessing.”

Wax Sherlock, unable to think up a counterargument, decided to tell their backstory. After they were stolen from their previous owner, they were set up here for the wax museum. By day they were overpriced attractions, but at night they were free to do as they pleased. It was a pleasant life, all things considered, right up until the money stopped coming in and they were locked in here.

“Can I just say one more thing?” asked Dipper.

“Oh fine. Go ahead,” allowed an annoyed Wax Sherlock.

The minizora pointed at Wax Lizzie. “You have an axe. If you didn’t like being locked up, you could have just broken out at any night.”

“And go where, hmm? You want us to be caught out in the sunlight just like Wax Lincoln?”

“I’m also not seeing how the wax museum stopped making money,” Mabel added. “I mean, it doesn’t take much to maintain you guys. Stan would have just had to do a minimal cleaning, like, once a week, which isn’t that expensive. You’ve been locked up for years and you all look in pretty good shape.”

“Thank you,” said Wax Shakespeare.

“I just… I really don’t see why you guys would be locked up in the first place. At the very least you’d be making enough money to cover the cost of cleaning.”

Wax Sherlock snorted. “That’s because your uncle is a big fat jerk.”

“Granted,” allowed Dipper. “Hold on. You guys ever see Night at the Museum?”

“I loved that movie,” gushed Mabel. “Robin Williams makes everything good.”

“It’s this movie about museum exhibits that also come to life at night,” Dipper explained to the intrigue of the figures. “The museum was about to be shut down, so they solved the problem by the end by opening the museum to night guests. That way it’s like there’s a big animatronic t-rex skeleton in the front lobby and a Wax Teddy Roosevelt who can talk with people about the real Roosevelt’s life.”

Pipe in one hand and Wax Stan’s head in the other, Sherlock’s brow made a climb up his forehead. “What are you getting at?”

“Maybe you guys could do the same. Show Grunkle Stan that you’re really alive. We can basically employ you guys and extend the Shack’s open hours.”

“Hey, yeah!” cheered Mabel. “You can be the evening crew. Give tours, talk about yourselves, and jack up prices.”

“So you guys would be able to walk free at night, and the Mystery Shack would make more money. Everyone wins.”

“Uh, hold that thought.” Sherlock motioned for the other wax figures to all gather at the far end of the room while they discussed this alternative.

“Do you think they’ll buy it?” Mabel whispered through a forced grin.

“No clue, but try scooching closer to the fire,” urged Dipper. “Their wax, so we can just melt them if things get bad.”

“Good idea.” And she discretely shuffled her way over to the fireplace to await the figures’ verdict.

1. They refuse and things go mostly like in the episode.
2. They agree and become integrated into the Shack
1213121111111.title: Wax Man Uprising

12131211111111.content:
The wax conference concluded as the figures approached the twins. “Sorry kids, but no dice. We’ve been waiting ten years to get our revenge,” he flipped the Wax Stan head around in his hand, “and next time we won’t miss.”

“So you were trying to murder Grunkle Stan for real?” asked Dipper in alarm.

“Enough, you little pipsqueaks! Now that you know our secret. You must die!”

“You first!” Mabel then wielded a fire poker like a javelin, hurling it at Wax John Wilks Booth’s head and spearing it to the wall. “Haha, got’ch’ya!” Her cheer was short lived when the body kept moving and the remaining wax figures just looked peeved. “Oops.”

“The candles!” Dipper pointed over to where Grunkle Stan had set up a refreshment table, including a pair of electric candles. Mabel wielded hers like a sword easily enough. Dipper, through much effort, wielded his like a human trying to manage an artillery cannon without wheels. “Get back or we’ll melt you into candles!”

“Decorative candles,” Mabel added threateningly.

The wax figures were intimidated at first, but then they remembered that they had the advantage in both size and numbers. “You really think you can defeat us?”

“Eh. Worth a shot.”

“So be it. Attack!”

The first casualty of the battle was Dipper’s footing as the weight of the candle threw him off balance and he fell to the floor. When Mabel turned to retrieve him, she accidentally severed Shakespeare’s arms. Dipper recovered to find the wax figures closing in on Mabel from all sides, clearly judging her to be the bigger threat.

“Never underestimate the little guy,” Dipper muttered before rolling his candle with all due haste, melting a good many feet all the way up to the ankle. In one case, Wax Robin Hood tripped and knocked Wax Larry King over, who then fell neck first onto the candle and was subsequently decapitated. “Ha! Interview that, Larry King! You alright Mabel?” He turned to his sister, and were they not in mortal danger, he would have burst out laughing.

Mabel was using the severed Coolio’s head like a mace, swinging it by the hair to bludgeon the other figures, knocking them back while she retrieved her candle. With her primary weapon retrieved, the little girl made a lunge for Wax Lizzie, but came up short and only tore her dress open. The adrenaline evaporated almost instantly as everyone paused to gawk. “Uh… wow.”

Wax Lizzie’s hands shot down to cover her exposed groin. “Don’t look!”

“I mean… damn. I knew shaving down there was kind of a more recent thing but… wow. You’d need a freaking lawnmower to trim that bush.”

“Sh-shut up!” cried the wax woman.

“I’m more concerned that someone took the time to sculpt her that way,” commented Dipper. “All these other guys have their clothes as part of their bodies, but her…” He gestured. “Someone sculpted her to not only go commando, but also have a bush big enough to hide a whole person. Someone fetishized an axe murderer!”

As the other wax figures began snickering at Lizzie’s plight, her cheeks began to burn from embarrassment. They burned so hot that she ended up melting herself. Once everyone got the giggles out of their system, the fight resumed.

Wax Sherlock finally did something smart by tossing the Stan head aside and grabbing a real sword off the wall. Dipper’s candle was smashed in short order. In response, Mabel found a broken sliver of metal near the fire place and threw it to Dipper.

“Catch!”

It was hot on both ends, but not enough to harm minizora skin. “Uh, thanks, but how do I fight a sword with a toothpick?”

“Figure it out,” Mabel urged, once more being swarmed by the remaining figures. “Die Nixon!”

With Wax Sherlock in pursuit, Dipper could only avoid and evade his strikes. Thankfully he had a lifetime of experience to help him through, but he was ever on the retreat. He knew there was only one chance. The minizora dove out the window and began ascending the Mystery Shack’s roof, once more demonstrating the climbing skills of a mountain goat.

“You think you can outwit me, boy? I’m Sherlock-bleeding-Holmes! Have you seen my magnifying glass? It’s enormous,” ranted the wax man as he haphazardly swung his sword around and dislodged the big S from the sign. Eventually he cornered Dipper, pinning him to the shingled roof with his shoe. Wax Sherlock tried increasing the pressure to crush the boy like a bug, but the minizora only laughed.

“That the best you got?” he wheezed.

“Grr. So be it.” Wax Sherlock raised his sword high. “Any last words?”

“Yeah, actually. Got any sunblock?”

“Got any-?” Wax Sherlock was cut off by the drip-drop of wax dripping onto his nose. His hands were liquefying and he lost his grip on the sword. He then turned and beheld the golden glow of the sun peeking over the forested horizon. “… no.”

“Letting me lead you to the roof? Yeah, probably not your sharpest decision,” Dipper taunted.

“Outsmarted by a child in short pants, and a minizora at that. Nooo!”

Any second thoughts Dipper might have had for killing a person were rendered null at that moment. “Sucks to be you, buddy. All my life guys like you have been looking down on me. But in just another minute, I’ll be looking down on you!”

Sure enough, with each passing second, Wax Sherlock lost more and more height, along with facial features. And then, just as the wax man was finally shorter than the minizora and Dipper was about to deliver the last word, he sneezed. “Ha-ha-ha. you sneeze like a kitten,” ranted the wax puddle in a mad delirium. “Those policemen were right. You’re adorable. Adorablllllle.”

*Splat*

His thunder stolen, Dipper heaved a sigh and returned to the wax room. Mabel was just finishing up with chucking severed wax limbs into the fire.

“Dipper, you’re okay!” Mabel rushed over and scooped him up, holding him tight to her cheek. “You solved the mystery after all.”

“See, I told you I can handle myself,” he strained to say. Mabel’s grip was more constraining than Wax Sherlock’s shoe, so he tapped her cheek to signal her to loosen up. “And I couldn’t have done it without my sidekick.”

Mabel giggled and picked up the Wax Stan head from the floor. “No offense Dipper, but you’re the sidekick.”

“What? Says who? Are-are people saying that? Who’s saying that?” Dipper asked self-consciously.

“Aww, don’t be down. You’re still the best sidekick a hero like me could ever want.” And she gave him a big wet kiss that encompassed most of his head. “Ew. You taste like wax.”

When Grunkle Stan came in to the warzone of a room, he was immediately placated with the presentation of his missing head. His reward was some affectionate noogying. That was nice, but far more gratifying was when the police pulled up and the twins had evidence of having solved the case. It didn’t matter that no one believed them about the wax people. What mattered was the hilarious sight of two cops spitting scalding hot coffee in one another’s faces.
12131211111111.title: War of Wax

121312111111111.content:
It was early morning in the Mystery Shack when Soos was on break and decided to join Dipper and Mabel in the TV room. Mabel held her brother in her lap as her fingers idly fiddled with his tiny form. So long as his vision was unobstructed, he made no complaint, not even when she poked his butt.

“Hey, it’s that commercial I was telling you guys about,” Soos informed.

Said commercial was for some self-proclaimed psychic over at the Tent of Telepathy. That there was an unflattering video of Grunkle Stan towards the end only confirmed that these people were his direct competition for, as their dear old Grunkle would so eloquently say: “Fleecing roobs.” And when Stan forbid them from going to the show that evening, their childish rebellion left them with no choice but to visit.

With nothing better to do while they waited for the evening, the twins went up to their room to relax. After the door was locked and blinds closed, Mabel removed her sweater to give her chest some open air. “Ahh, much better.”

“Seriously? As far as summer days go, this one’s pretty mild.”

“What can I say? I’m just,” Mabel tittered, “one hot mamma.”

“Eh. I’ve heard worse,” Dipper allowed as he opened up the journal. He didn’t even make it to the second line before being picked up by his shirt. “Hey, what gives?”

“Just giving you an extra special study spot, bro-bro,” Mabel graciously said as she laid on her back and rested her brother down atop her chest. “Hehe.”

“Um, uh, sure, I guess,” Dipper accepted of his sister’s silliness. Mabel’s breasts weren’t anything to write home about, but they weren’t completely flat. There was enough there for Dipper to rest his head on like a pillow.

“Hehe. Comfy?” she asked, using her elbows to try and press her breasts together.

“Good enough,” answered Dipper distractedly, trying to ignore the way Mabel pouted.

“Hmph. I bet you’d notice if Shandra Jimenez put you on her chest.”

“Mabel, she’s like in her late thirties. Plus I’d bet those things are plastic. There’s no need to get-”

“Don’t you say it!” Mabel accused, her finger pointed like a deadly weapon at the boy resting against her tiny boob. “I am not jealous.”

“Hey, if anyone around here is going to be insecure about their size, it’s going to be me. Got that.”

Mabel huffed and turned away. “At least you could show me a little affection now and then.”

“Now and then? Mabel, I was literally in your mouth this morning.”

“That was me showing you affection. I’m always the one doing the petting, the hugging, the licking, and all that stuff. Maybe you could throw a little sugar my way once in a while.” Her tone was pleading and her eyes were doing that shimmery thing that she knew Dipper couldn’t resist.

“Okay fine,” Dipper surrendered, closing the book as he was clearly not going to get any reading done until Mabel was satisfied. “First, put this up so it won’t get damaged.”

Mabel happily obliged and set the book on her dresser. As she did, her frown started to turn upside down as Dipper undressed. She clapped her hands and kicked her legs in anticipation of the fun that was coming. “Ee-he-he! Naked Dipper is best Dipper.”

“Uh huh. Sure,” Dipper agreed dispassionately as he threw his underwear off to the side. Standing there in the buff atop his bare-chested sister, the minizora was still as soft as a noodle. Just being naked and looking at his half naked sister did nothing for him. It’d take some serious stimulation to give Mabel what she wanted, but that got Dipper to thinking. “So if you want me to show some affection for a change, then you’re gonna have to commit to it.”

“What do you mean?”

“I mean you gotta sit on your hands. Literally. If we’re doing this, then I’m in charge. You can’t do anything. For once, you’re the one who just has to sit back and let your twin have their way with you.”

“Oh wow. So forceful,” giggled Mabel as she slid her hands under her bottom. “I like it.”

Dipper gave a curt nod. “Good. Now, let’s see here.” After a second of surveying the smooth landscape beneath his feet, deciding a course of action, the minizora returned to his sister’s chest lumps and climbed up onto the nipple. Mabel moaned quietly, but that was just a taste of what he had planned. Dipper dropped down onto his belly, pressing his limp dick against the little girl’s nipple. “Ohhhh,” he shuddered, having not expected it to feel that good.

“I feel it,” Mabel moaned. “I feel your itty bitty weewee against my nippy. Tee-hee.”

“Baby talk only makes this weirder,” Dipper informed as he began experimentally grinding himself against the nub. He rotated his hips around in circles, trying to cover as much surface area as possible with his crotch. The texture of her nipple skin was different than her hands in a way that Dipper couldn’t put into words. It felt amazing, though. Mabel moaned all the louder as she fought to keep her body still. A grin grew across Dipper’s face as he came to terms with the control he now exerted over his sister. “Wow. So this is what it’s like to be in charge.”

“Pretty great, huh.”

“No kidding,” he agreed while pressing his erection into her hardened nub. The friction of foreign skin against his sensitive prick combined with the knowledge of who he was humping; all added up for some pretty amazing stimulation.

“D-Dipper,” moaned Mabel. “When you’re in my mouth, and I make you cum with my tongue, you taste sooo gooood.”

“I… figured,” Dipper panted, now getting into the swing of things. “It’s not just your tongue, though. I think every part of you is amazing.”

“R-really?” Mabel had never done much with her flat chest before, having always dismissed it as too underdeveloped to play with. However, as Dipper was demonstrating, she was a lot more sensitive around there than she’d initially believed. “C-can I play with the other one?” she begged.

The minizora shook his head. “Uh-uh. This isn’t about you feeling good. This is about me showing my sister some affection, remember. I’m showing you what a minizora can do, and you’re gonna sit back and take it,” he growled, trying to channel some of Manly Dan’s authority. “Damn, you’re sensitive.”

“H-harder!” Mabel begged. With Dipper’s stupid rule in place, she was powerless to do much. However, with him preoccupied with her chest, she was able to arch her back just enough to slip both hands beneath her skirt. The angle wasn’t ideal for doing much and still maintain discretion, but it would have to do. Unable to think clearly, Mabel attacked both her ass and pussy, make believing that her fingers were Dipper. Lots of little Dippers, all rubbing and humping to their little hearts’ content, and all at her command. They were doing this for her. The little Dippers were rubbing their little bodies against her most sensitive parts because she wanted them to, because they loved her and wanted to make her happy.

“Hegakurgurk!” Dipper gasped, his ejaculation jumping out at him like a snake. His body spasamed and he lost his grip, collapsing onto the erect nipple.

Somehow, Mabel was able to feel that tiny splash of liquid onto her nub. That combined with the stimulation from her hands to push her over the edge. Reflexively, she broke the rule by bringing the hand from her ass up and clamping it over her mouth to keep herself silent. It was a habit born out of having done this so many times at their parents’ home.

The two siblings, naked and half naked, laying atop the other and the bed respectively, panted. Their chests rose and fell with labored breaths, their bodies were all sweaty, and their groins were especially sticky. Dipper, to the surprise of no one, called upon his minizora endurance to recover first and stand. Hands on his hips and cock contentedly soft, he proudly surveyed his good work before smirking up at Mabel’s face.

“You cheated,” he playfully pointed out, indicating her hand.

Mabel, still recovering, scowled down at the minizora. Through her fingers she said, “Screw off.”

Dipper scratched his chin, pretending to think. “Hmm. Sure.” And he began walking off. “I need a shower anyway.” But before he could jump from the little girl’s body, a hand snatched him up and brought him to the little girl’s big glowering face. “Don’t tell me you’re going to be a sore loser about this,” he said with a punchable smirk. “Fair’s fair. You agreed to the rules, so that means-agh!” His lecture was cut short after being tossed in his sister’s mouth.

“Nom!” Mabel pushed him into her cheek like a chipmunk storing food, not really up to a proper taste session. She just casually licked and sucked as strength returned to her body. When feeling returned to her legs, she headed for the bathroom and poured herself a glass of water. With Dipper secured by her tongue, she drank around him in an effort to punish him. Now internally refreshed, she looked herself in the mirror and did her best to speak around her mouthful. “You’re the best brother ever, and I hate you for it.”

It was impossible for Dipper not to grin.
121312111111111.title: Siblings Passing the Time

1213121111111111.content:
With the twins cleaned up and the adults none the wiser, Dipper, Mabel, and Soos paid their visit to the Tent of Telepathy. At the entrance there was a man named Bud Gleeful. A portly man in a Hawaiian shirt, he was holding out a bag to accept ‘donations’ into what he called Gideon’s Psychic Sack.

“You think he knows what that sounds like?” Mabel whispered to her shoulder rider.

“Given what we’ve seen so far from this town, I have no idea.” Dipper looked around the tent. “This whole place is like a bizarro version of the Mystery Shack. They even have their own Soos.”

When the audience was seated, the lights dimmed and the curtains rose. The person at the center of all this hype was just a pale freckled kid. He’d be only half as tall without his hair and there was something off about how he would bat his eyelashes.

“That’s Stan’s mortal enemy?” Dipper said in disbelief, suddenly having a far lower opinion of the old man for considering this kid a threat.

“But he’s so… little.”

“Hey!”

“Little by big people standards,” assured Mabel.

Dipper continued to be unimpressed as Gideon went through his performance, discerning ‘secrets’ about his audience members that were obvious to anyone who wasn’t blind. “How are these people buying this? He’s just doing cold reading. It’s literally the oldest trick in the book.”

“How’d he do that?” Mabel awed after Gideon had guessed her name to the beat of an annoyingly catchy song.

“It’s literally written on your shirt,” griped Dipper. He did not care for how his sister was looking at this chubby kid like he was made of glitter. The minizora was all too glad when the show finally ended. “Man, that kid’s an even bigger fraud than Stan. No wonder our uncle’s jealous.”

“Oh come on. His dance moves were adorable. And did you see his hair? It was like… whoosh!”

“You’re too easily impressed.” The twins then descended into a poking war, laughing as they left through the parking lot and completely unaware that they were being watched.

The next morning, Mabel was feeling a little glum. She’d just bedazzled her face and Dipper didn’t seem the least bit impressed. Then when there was a knock at the door, she decided to cheer herself up by talking to a potential stranger. “Ahh! It’s wittle old you!” she gasped at the sight of Gideon’s hair, followed by Gideon.

“Heh-heh. Yeah, mah song’s quite catchy,” Gideon laughed a bit apprehensively. “Ah know we haven’t formally met, but after yesterday’s performance, Ah jus’ couldn’t get yer laugh out ‘f mah head.”

“Oh, you mean this one? Ah-ha-hahahaaa.”

“What a delight.”

The two continued their little back and forth, mostly about their mutual appreciation for sparkly things. Mabel even covered for him when Stan asked who was at the door. And then Gideon invited her over to visit his dressing room.

“One sec.” Mabel ran back to the dining room. “Hey Dipper. Gideon just invited me to his dressing room to play dress up. You wanna-”

“Oh, would you look at the time,” Dipper said, pointing to his nonexistent watch. “I have to be… somewhere!” And he made himself scarce.

Deciding that Dipper would be safe enough at the Shack, Mabel accompanied Gideon for a few hours of dress up. All the while she remained utterly oblivious to the subtle and less-than-subtle hints the short stack kept dropping. When she returned, showing off her new do, she was once more confronted by an unimpressed Dipper.

“Mabel, I don’t trust anyone whose hair is bigger than their head.”

“Oh leave him alone,” Mabel snapped. “You never want to do girly stuff with me. You and Soos get to do boy stuff all the time.”

“What do you mean? We did that… thing, yesterday.”

“That was a minizora twin thing, not a girly thing.” In no mood to argue, Mabel returned to Gideon for some quality feminine hanging out time. They’d found a nice roof high up on a cliff that provided a great view of the town.

“Ya know Mabel, when Ah’m up here lookin’ down on all them little ol’ people, Ah feel like Ah’m king ‘f all Ah survey,” he whispered in a low menace. “Ah guess that makes you mah queen.”

“Whaaat? You are being so nice to me right now,” Mabel gushed. She slapped him in the gut and said, “Quit it.”

“Ah can’t quit it, Mabel. Ah’m speakin’ from the heart.”

“From the where now?” Mabel asked, finally noticing the red flags. Sixty third one’s the charm, as they say. But alas, she was unable to get out of his invitation to a date.

Back at the Shack, Mabel was trying to get her mind off the not-date with some video games. “It’s not a date-date. It’s just, you know, I didn’t want to hurt his feelings, so I figured I’d throw him a bone.”

“Mabel, guys don’t work that way,” informed the wise tiny on her shoulder. “This is called ‘leading a guy on’. You’re building his hopes up, despite having no real intention of getting serious. I know I’d be pretty mad if a girl did that to me.”

Mabel scoffed. “Oh what do you know? Not like you’ve ever dated anyone.”

“Maybe not, but you know all those times you stuffed me in your underwear with nothing to do but read those minizora cutouts from your girly magazines? Well those things are mostly trash and even they agree that what you’re doing is, at best, a dick move.”

“You’re a dick move.”

When the doorbell rang, Mabel set Dipper aside to open it, expecting Gideon. She was right, but she hadn’t been expecting him to be on a horse, or to call her mi’lady.

“Oh boy.”

The longer the not-date at the second fanciest restaurant in town went on, the harder it was for Mabel to convince herself that this wasn’t a real date. There was an indoor fountain, aromatic flowers, more utensils than she knew what to do with, French stuff, and an overall creepy vibe as everyone – even the other guests – seemed to bend over backwards for Gideon. Was he some kind of cult leader or something? Mabel asked herself this after that one couple begged Gideon to bless their newborn baby.
1213121111111111.title: Wittle Ol' Me

12131211111111111.content:
Upon learning that that ‘little gremlin’ was dating his great niece, Grunkle Stan stomped right out of the shack to put a stop to this once and for all. He drove up to Gideon’s less-than-humble abode, fully prepared to curb stomp the little piglet, and maybe his stupid faced father while he was at it. Bud, however, proved his smooth talking prowess and quickly diffused the situation. And even as committed as Grunkle Stan was at the start, once the prospect of making more money was brought up, he was putty in Bud’s hands.

Back at the Shack, Dipper was sitting on the store counter while Wendy – without customers or Stan around – wasn’t even pretending to work.

“You seem down, squirt. Wanna talk about it?”

Dipper sighed. “I don’t know. Mabel being on a date is just kind of weird for me. Does that make sense?”

“Oh, totally. First time my brother brought home a girl, my first instinct was to kick that little bitch’s teeth in. It’s perfectly normal, dude.”

Dipper laughed nervously. “Did you… do it?”

“No way, man. Go around kicking little kids in the teeth? That’s how cops get called and you’re sent off to juvi for, like, ever. The trick is to play nice at the start. Smile, get to know ‘em, learn their weaknesses,” she added darkly. “That way, if it turns out they’re jerks, you can just blackmail them into breaking up.”

Dipper laughed more sincerely this time. “I can’t tell if that’s super sweet or super creepy.”

“Its family,” Wendy stated plainly while opening a soda. “They’re all a bunch of idiots, so you gotta do what you gotta do to keep ‘em safe.”

“Wow. You are really smart.” And pretty. Dipper looked around, wondering who’d just said that.

“Nah. My mom told me that. She’s good with this kind of stuff.”

“Well, you came from her, so you’ve gotta have some of her smarts too, right?”

“That’s sweet of you to say, but I’m pretty tame compared to my folks. People think my dad is intense, but mom can be a demon when she gets upset. This one time I brought a guy home, I’d left him in the living room to powder my nose. Anyway, just as I come back out, the window breaks. The dude actually jumped out the closed window to get away. Dad was sweatin’ bullets while mom…” Wendy trailed off, laughing nervously. “Anyway, the point is that it’s perfectly natural to not trust your family’s dates.”

“But this isn’t a date,” Dipper insisted. “Well, Mabel says it isn’t. Her words were ‘throw him a bone’,” he said with air quotes.

Wendy sucked in a breath like she’d stubbed her toe.

“I know, right.” Dipper fell back on the counter and stared up at the ceiling. “If I were there I could help. I could be a little shoulder angel and whisper what she should do to break things off as quickly and painlessly as possible.”

Wendy smiled kindly. “Mabel’s lucky to have a brother like you.” She tapped at the table as a thought occurred. “Um, this might sound weird, but would it be okay if I… pet you?”

Dipper frowned thoughtfully. “Huh. I think that might be the first time someone’s ever asked.”

“So is it weird?”

“I mean, only if we make it. Mabel and my parents just do whatever they want. Whenever some stranger tried reaching for me, Mabel would just bite their fingers. But if you’re going to ask, then sure. Go right ahead.” Dipper laid himself flat on the counter, suddenly feeling far more vulnerable than a few seconds ago.

Biting her bottom lip and with much trepidation, Wendy reached out with a single digit extended and touched Dipper’s chest. Nothing happened, but she still exhaled her relief. She didn’t know what she was expecting. She’d played with dolls before, but that didn’t seem like an adequate comparison. This was a minizora. His chest rose and fell with his breathing and he was warm to the touch. Wendy’s instincts told her that this was a fragile creature that needed protecting, but common sense suggested otherwise. Minizora were tough, people said. They could handle all kinds of things that would kill a regular person. And yet this knowledge contradicted so starkly with what she was feeling right now. At that moment, she wanted nothing more than to hold this little guy.

Dipper, meanwhile, was in a similarly perplexing predicament. A stranger was touching him, and he was okay with that. She was petting him, showing the same sort of everyday affection he was accustomed to from family. Much to his own surprise, he was totally relaxed, not even feeling the usual tension of going to the doctor. Did he trust Wendy that much? How far did that trust go?

That’s when the doorbell jingled, startling the counter people to straighten up and attempt to look as innocent as possible.

“Oh, h-hey Mabel,” Dipper strained to say. “How did the… what happened?”

Mabel gave a long and drawn out groan, not even looking up as she trudged into the shop.

“Whoa, dude. Normally I’d think she’d just broken up, but you said she didn’t even want to date him,” Wendy observed.

“She didn’t.” Full of purpose, Dipper hopped down the makeshift staircase from the counter and scurried off after Mabel.

Wendy smiled as she watched him go and rested her chin on her hand. “There goes a pretty cool brother.”

When Dipper finally caught up with Mabel, he found her having already withdrawn her limbs and retreated into her sweater like a turtle. “Mabel.”

“Mabel’s not here. She’s in sweater town.”

“Are you going to come out of sweater town?”

Mabel whimpered and shook her head.

“Then can I come in?”

After a second’s thought, Mabel stuck her hand out of the bottom and motioned him forward. Dipper climbed on and let himself be pulled up to his dower sister’s face. Everything was cast in shadow, but the minizora kept his eyes on what mattered.

“How bad was it?”

“I agreed to a second date.”

“How?” Dipper asked incredulously, his tone just making Mabel feel worse. “I mean, you had a plan. Say you just want to be friends, and then be friends. No more dates.”

“You don’t understand. He had a talking bird, and the rainbow machine, and this one lady said she’d die of sadness if I didn’t say yes. She even had a doctor confirm it.”

Dipper suddenly became less sympathetic. “So someone you never met just happens to be so invested in you dating Gideon that they’d die otherwise? And they just happen to have a doctor there to make sure you’re manipulated into doing what Gideon wants?”

“Well…”

“Mabel, he’s just like Grunkle Stan: a showman and a con artist. I’d bet anything that those people were just actors planted to guilt you into dating Gideon.”

“Now hold on a second. He’s not… that controlling.”

“Ah! You hesitated,” Dipper pointed out. “So you do think he’s that controlling.”

“Great news, Mabel,” announced Grunkle Stan with a beaming grin and a ‘Team Gideon’ shirt. “You have to marry Gideon.”

“What!?” the twins exclaimed together, both poking their heads out of the sweater.

“It’s part of my long-term plan with Buddy Gleeful. There’s a lot of cash tied up in this thing. I even got this shirt.” Then he wandered off, muttering about how bodies change.

“Okay, that’s it!” Dipper stomped his foot on Mabel’s palm. “Enough is enough. If you can’t break up with Gideon, then I’ll do it.”

“You will?” awed Mabel.

“Hey, remember that talk about the rabbits and feeling lousy.”

“Oh thank-you-thank-you-thank-you,” Mabel gushed, pelting Dipper’s body in grateful kisses while he offered up only a token resistance.
12131211111111111.title: It's (Not) a Date With Gideon

121312111111111111.content:
The next day, while Mabel stayed home to avoid the paparazzi, Dipper grabbed a ride from Soos to pay Gideon a visit. He entered the first fanciest establishment in Gravity Falls and it certainly fit the title. Seriously, how does a place like this stay open when the number of locals who can afford to eat here can be counted on one hand? Anyway, the minizora held his head high and strutted inside like he belonged there. Although he did find it odd that a place this expensive didn’t have some kind of security to keep people like him out.
Upon arriving at Gideon’s private booth, Dipper ascended the table cloth and cleared his throat.
“Ah, Dipper Pines. How are you? You look good, you look good.” Gideon’s greeting sounded like he’d been rehearsing for a school play. “You know Mabel has told me quite a lot about you.”
“Whatever it is, it’s all lies.” Dipper strained to smile at his bad joke.
“Really? Because whenever the topic of you came up, it was often accompanied with words like reliable, dedicated, fun, and various synonyms that made mah beloved ever so happy.” He laughed that cutesy laugh of his before shifting to a whispered intensity. “She seems quite fond of you.”
More and more Dipper was having a hard time understanding why Mabel couldn’t say no to this guy. If he’d been in her position, he’d have thrown himself out the window and booked it like Wendy’s old boyfriend by now. “Look buddy. We’ve got to talk. Mabel isn’t going to join you tonight. She, uh, doesn’t want to see you anymore,” he laughed uncomfortably. “Sh-she’s kind of weirded out by you. No offense.”
Gideon just kept on smiling that serene, creepy smile of his. The only indicator that he wasn’t the picture of happiness was the twitching in his left eye. “So, what yer saying is, you’ve come between us.”
“Look man, some people just don’t click. It’s not really anyone’s fault, except maybe yours. Uh, you’re not going to freak out or anything, are you?”
“Of course not,” Gideon tittered like a little schoolgirl. “These things happen. Bygones and all that.”
“Okay cool. Sorry again man, but I, uh, gotta go,” explained Dipper as he backed away, unwilling to turn his back on the giant shorty.
When Dipper made it back to Mabel and gave her the news, her hug about crushed the life out of him.
The next day, while everything seemed back to normal, Toby Determined called wanting to interview Dipper about the unusual happenings he’d seen in town. The minizora was all too excited, right up until he was given the time and place for the meeting.
“Who was it?” Mabel asked.
“Toby Determined. He wants to interview me, alone, after dark, in an abandoned building on the outskirts of town.”
Mabel blinked. “That’s literally the opening scene of the horror movie we watched last night.”
“Pretty generic, if you ask me,” Dipper agreed nonchalantly.
“You’re not going, are you?”
“Well obviously I have to. If someone’s going through the trouble of setting a trap, I’d like to know who they are so we can keep an eye out for next time.”
Mabel did not care for this answer and not-so-gently grabbed her brother. “But what if you get hurt?”
“Hey, no big deal. It’s not like I’m going alone.” He bounced his eyebrows suggestively and gave a winning smile.
“Wha? Oh. Ohhh! Hehe, good thinking.”
Entering the old warehouse at the appointed time, Dipper was greeted only by darkness. Was this actually just a prank and not a trap? The light at the far end of the room ominously shining onto a swivel chair suggested otherwise.
“Hello friend,” greeted Gideon, spinning around in his chair and, in place of a super villain’s cat, petting a little doll of himself.
Dipper blinked. “Somehow this is way creepier than the horror movie.” It was honestly rather impressive.
“Let me tell you, boy. This town has secrets you can’t begin to comprehend,” Gideon threatened, shaking his fist.
“The only secret here is how you can delude yourself like this. I told you, Mabel’s not into you.”
“You liar!” Gideon screamed shrilly. As he hopped off the chair and began marching toward the minizora, his hand gripped tightly on the green amulet on his shirt collar. “You turned her against me. She was my peach dumplin’!”
“Aaare you okay man?” Dipper asked, fighting his tiny instincts to run. Running just made the bullies want to give chase. Besides, he was confident he could take any blows this pipsqueak could dish out. And when his body was encased in a green aura that matched Gideon’s amulet, followed by being hurled across the room into the brick wall, Dipper had second thoughts about running. “Oh crap!”
Outside the warehouse, hidden behind a tree, Mabel was left to stew in her own thoughts as she searched for any signs of danger. In hindsight, that first date really had been a dick move, but letting Dipper break up for her had been an even bigger dick move. Gideon might have his… quirks, but he at least deserved an honest break up. As soon as this hole trap thing was sorted out, she’d march over to his house and do things right.
Inside the warehouse…
“Ahhhh!” Dipper was getting more exercise in the last few minutes than the last couple years. Everywhere he turned there was something floating, flying at him, dropping on him, or maybe gravity would just have a hiccup and he’d be the one sent flying. There just comes a point in a young man’s life when he can’t help but think that a bully giving swirlies is the lesser evil.

“Once yer out ‘f the way, Mabel will be all mine! Mwahahaha!”
“You really are insane,” Dipper spat as he was lifted high in the air. “If anything happens to me, she’ll know who to blame. She’ll hate you forever.”
“Oh, Ah don’t think so,” tittered Gideon as he levitated a pair of scissors up to the minizora. “You underestimate just how persuasive Ah can be. Tee-hee.”
Mabel threw the doors open. “Gideon, we have to talk,” she stated with calm firmness.
“M-Mabel? My marshmallow. Wh-what are you doin’ here?” asked Gideon in a rare moment of uncertainty. He knew things looked bad, and so quickly discarded the scissors in the hopes that Mabel hadn’t seen them yet.
“I’m sorry, Gideon, but I can’t be your marshmallow,” Mabel answered calmly, not even paying Dipper a glance. “And I need to be honest and tell you that myself.”
After all of his denial, Gideon finally looked crestfallen. “A-Ah don’t understand.”
With an inviting smile, Mabel approached with hands outstretched in friendship. “Hey, we can still be makeover buddies, right. Wouldn’t you like that?”
“Really?” asked Gideon hopefully, only for that hope to be snatched right off his neck.
“No, not really!” snarled Mabel, the magic amulet in hand and out of Gideon’s reach. The magic faded and Dipper dropped to the ground. “You were attacking my brother. What the hell?” And she slapped him across the face with a thunderous thwack.
“N-now Mabel, Ah can explain.”
“No. Fuck your explanations!” She slapped him every other word. “Fuck you! Fuck you forever! Go fuck yourself! You fuck!”
Every f bomb was like a stab into Gideon’s heart. How could his sweet peach suddenly grow so sour? Then the amulet started glowing again, only this time its glow encompassed Gideon’s body and he floated helplessly before Mabel.
“Let me make this as clear as possible,” Mabel hissed. “I will never date you. You crossed a line and now I will never even like you.” She then spent about a minute experimenting with the durability of Gideon’s face vs. the floor and walls. “If you ever come near me or my family again, I will end you!” Teeth bared, she crushed the amulet in her bare hand, ending its power forever and dropping Gideon. “Now get out.”
“Okay fine. Ah’ll leave,” Gideon conceded, backing away with a limp and clothes in tatters. “But Ah promise. This isn’t the last you’ve seen of Wittle. Ol’. M-”
“Get out!”
“Agh! Ah’m gettin’!”
Dipper waited until things quieted down. “W-wow Mabel. I-I’ve never seen that side of you be-”
“Wha-ha-ha!” Mabel cried as she flung herself onto Dipper, tears gushing from her eyes and onto his clothes. “You idiot! You stupid, stupid idiot! You knew it was a trap, but you still went anyway. That shit almost cut you with scissors. You can’t handle scissors!”
Dipper opened his mouth, but didn’t know what to say. He could point out that there were factors that couldn’t have been accounted for, that he’s withstood worse and maybe could have handled the scissors, or that Mabel had agreed to this whole plan, but he couldn’t see any of those arguments ending well for him. And with the tears of his beloved sister ripping his heart out, he finally settled on something to say. “You protected me.”
Mabel took a break from her constricting embrace and pulled back enough to look Dipper in the eye. She was ugly crying and hated that he was seeing her like this. However, there was something about his smile that lifted her spirits just a tad.
“I knew I’d be fine, because you protected me like you always do.”
Mabel fell right back to bawling, but with most of the fear and anger removed. Now there was only relief mixed with a bit of joy that everything was alright. No more words were exchanged as the pair sat there in the warehouse, holding one another for comfort.
When Gideon finally made it back home, the first thing he did was have Stanford Pines tossed out. The merger of their families was off. As far as he was concerned, this was a full and proper feud. It hardly mattered that Stan stole an expensive painting on the way out. Oh, there would be recompense and it would go far beyond petty thievery. This, Gideon knew with absolute certainty. He knew it because in a secret compartment at his desk, there was a book; an itty bitty minizora book. It bore no title. Just a little six fingered hand and the number 2 on the cover.
121312111111111111.title: Gideon's Rejection

1213121111111111111.content:
Over the next couple of days, Mabel was being especially clingy with Dipper, which he wasn’t too bothered by. They’d both gone through some pretty heavy stuff: him almost dying and her having to watch her most favorite person suffer. They were each other’s comfort object. Ever since they were little, their default response to any kind of stress had always been to seek out the other. That was the case now, with Dipper offering no complaint even when Mabel insisted on escorting or being escorted by him to the bathroom. And right now, the twins were undertaking a heavy emotional ordeal. They were going to be within two feet of one another, but not actually touch. This was an important step in their recovery process.
At the entrance to the gift shop, Mabel was sitting on a spinning globe. “Hehe. My butt is crushing Canada.”
“Mabel, do you believe in ghosts?” Dipper asked while flipping through the journal.
“I believe that you’re a big dork. Haha.” For her impudence, Dipper pressed a pencil into the globe, bringing it to an abrupt halt and sending his sister flying. “Ow.”
The bell rung and Stan poked his head in the door. “Soos. Wendy. I’m headin’ out. You two are going to wash the bathrooms, right?”
“Yes sir.” “Absolutely not,” they answered respectively, each with a firm salute.
“Haha. You stay out of trouble.” With his old man scowl delivered, Stan departed for parts unknown and deeds most likely of the extra-legal variety.
“Hey guys. What’s this?” Wendy called, gesturing over to a mysterious curtain in the corner. “Is it a secret ladder to the roof?” Pulling back the curtain, she revealed that it was just that.
Soos was reluctant, but the teen was easily able to bring the preteens onboard. She even showed them to her secret cot and cooler.
“Wow, did you put all this up here?” awed Dipper. “Huh. Funny I didn’t notice any of this when Sherloc-er, never mind.”
Wendy gave her hair a casual flip. “I may or may not sneak up here during work… all the time, every day.” She then grabbed a pinecone from a bucket and tossed it across the lot and hit a target that had been strapped to the plastic tiki tower. “Yes!”
“Oh I want to try,” squealed Mabel as she grabbed an armful and began chucking the things, each round coming up short.
Not wanting to be left out, Dipper figured he might as well try. His pinecone hit someone’s car and set off the alarm. At first his gut sank in fear that he’d just royally screwed up, but Wendy’s laugh said otherwise.
“Ha-ha-ha, jackpot!” Bending down with one hand on her knee, she extended her other palm down to Dipper’s level. “High five.”
Dipper suffered a momentary mental blue screen. The hand of someone other than a relative was reaching out for him in… comradery? What’s more, that hand was attached to a young woman with cute freckles and a lovely shade of red hair that was being picked up just right by the wind. And her smile…
“Don’t leave me hangin’.”
Dipper snapped out of it and delivered the high five. It was oddly exhilarating.
“Oh hey, it’s my friends,” Wendy said as a car pulled up. She then looked apprehensively at the twins. “Uh, you guys aren’t going to tell Stan, are you?”
With a resolute smile, Dipper made a zipping motion over his mouth and threw away the key, which Wendy mirrored. The teen then said “Later dorks,” before descending down some nearby trees with a level of prowess rarely seen outside of professional acrobats, or minizora.
“Later Wendy,” Dipper called after they’d already driven off. His laugh was forced and his waving was frantic. “Haaa, good times.”
“Uh oh,” beamed Mabel, not so oblivious when it came to other people’s relationships.
“What?”
“Somebody’s got a cru-hush,” she sang, poking him in the cheek.
“What? No. I just think Wendy’s cool is all. It’s not like I lay awake at night thinking about her.”
“Oh? So when I catch you staring blankly up at the ceiling at night, who are you thinking about?” inquired Mabel, continuing her poking assault.
“Her name’s Business. First name None-Ya.”
“You can’t fool me. I know when my little brother’s crushing on someone.”
“What? No you don’t.”
“Oh really? So if I were to, say, offer you this handkerchief that Wendy used to wipe her chest earlier,” Mabel said while producing said fabric from her pocket, “you wouldn’t be interested?”
“How much?” Dipper’s mouth said before his filter could switch on.
Mabel’s smirk was downright devilish. She had him cornered and they both knew it. “It’s actually clean,” she said before returning the white cloth to her pocket. “So, got a thing for red heads, huh?”
“No. I mean, I don’t know. Just… this one, I guess,” he admitted apprehensively. “C-can we just drop this, please?”
“Fine. Whatever you say, bro-bro. Just know that I’ll be here when you’re ready to talk. In fact…” Mabel then unceremoniously snatched up Dipper and stuffed him down the back of her underwear.
Wedged between her soft cheeks, Dipper was left to consider how surprisingly mature that response was, at least by Mabel standards. Still, with nothing better to do today, he decided to make himself comfy in the warm softness, pull out his flashlight and journal, and get some reading done.
The next day, Mabel seemed to have fully returned to her usual chipper self, as indicated by the “Random dance party for no reason!”
