As she and Wendy got their groove on, Dipper pretended to read, all while peeking over the top of the journal. He was starting to notice things about the red head. Her dancing really showed off how nice her hips were. While she lacked the perpetual sugar rush that was Mabel’s energy, her moves had a more mature elegance. That one move resembled a pelvic thrust, which set the minizora’s imagination into overdrive.
“Hey Dipper. You gonna get in on this?” Wendy called.
“Oh, I, uh, don’t really dance,” Dipper dodged with a blush, only to spy the sadistic gleam in Mabel’s eye. She was about to do her sisterly duty and embarrass him for her own amusement.
“Yeah, ya do.” She turned to Wendy. “Mom used to dress him up in a lamb costume and make him do… the Lamby Dance,” she said as if imparting some ancient and holy secret.
“Now is not the time to talk about the Lamby Dance,” Dipper said through gritted teeth.
“Whoa, lamb costume?” Wendy chuckled. “Is there, like, little ears and a tail, or-?”
Mabel immediately produced a picture for Wendy. “He used to be so cute. He’d prance around and sing a song about grazing,” she laughed with nostalgic fondness.
“Oh wow.” Wendy covered a hand over her mouth to stifle her giggles. She understood how embarrassing this was, but couldn’t tear her eyes away. “Just look at him. Aww, he’s so sweet I think I just got diabetes.” While the ladies laughed, Dipper was left to seethe in silent humiliation.
Then the clock chimed.
“Op. Quitin’ time.” Wendy pocketed her name tag and made for the door.
“Uh, hey wait,” Dipper called. “Maybe I-er-we could come with you.”
“Ooh, I don’t know. My friends are pre-tty intense. How old did you guys say you are?”
“Uh, we’re thirteen, so technically teens,” Dipper lied.
“Alright. I like your moxy, kid. Let me get my stuff.”
Mabel picked Dipper up and tutted her disappointment. “Lying to a girl just to hang out. Oh Dipper. I thought I taught you better.”
“You’ve taught me literally nothing about dating… which this isn’t. It’s just one group of friends hanging out with another group of friends, all connected through one mutual friend. It’s all very friendly, and nothing else.”
“Uh huh. Yeah. Sure,” Mabel teased.
“Hey, quick question. Um, why are you being so cool about this?”
“What do you mean?”
“Like, I’m not saying I like Wendy or anything, but if I did, I kind of expected you to be a little more, you know…” He gestured vaguely.
“Finger bitey.”
“That’s a good way of putting it.”
Mabel laughed and shook her head at her pitiable little brother. “Because I realized something, Dipper. You and me, we kind of, how do I put this? Suck. Yeah. When it comes to love, we kind of have sucky tastes in picking people to crush on.”
Dipper scowled. “That sounds like the worst revelation ever.”
“Buuut, we don’t suck at judging the other’s love interests.”
“I’m not following.”
“It’s probably a twin thing. We started out as the same cell, but then we became two. I think it’s like we’ve got one whole person’s worth of common sense between us. I tend to miss a lot of stuff that’s obvious to you, but you’re basically blind to stuff I can’t not see. So whenever one of us finds someone we like, we should trust the other twin’s judgement instead of our own. That way we can avoid the awkwardness of gang banging gnomes, magic creepoids, or that one girl with chronic diarrhea.”
Dipper shuddered with revulsion. He’d have been happy to never think about Patty ever again. But in thinking of her now, Mabel had warned him beforehand. “Hmm. You know, that’s not the worst idea I’ve ever heard.”
“High praise.”
“So, if I’m following, does this mean you approve of Wendy?”
“Does she still have all her fingers?”
“Uh, yeah.”
“Then yeah. I like her fine.” Mabel emphasized by clicking her teeth together.
1213121111111111111.title: Someone's got a Crush

12131211111111111111.content:
The meeting with Wendy’s friends went less than ideal. Nothing Dipper did impressed anyone and he kind of pissed off Robbie by calling his drawing of an explosion a muffin. The rest of the guys were pretty rough with one another and prone to frequent punching. The only other girl, Tambry, was so glued to her phone that it was a miracle she could walk. Since the twins didn’t take up much space, they were made to sit in the back of Thompson’s mom’s van with Tambry.

“So, uh, you like spending time on your phone, huh?” Dipper asked awkwardly, trying to break the ice while sitting in Mabel’s lap.

Tambry finally paused in her texting to give the pair a once over. “So you’re, like, twins?”

“Uh, yup. Sure are.”

“So are you, like, identical?”

Mabel and Dipper shared a look. It was the look of people who’d been asked a particular question so often that they’d put serious thought into starting a petition to get that particular string of words criminalized.

“No, we’re not identical,” Dipper said as politely as possible. “We’re a boy and a girl, not to mention the whole height thing.”

“Yeah. Plus I’m the cute one,” Mabel added.

Tambry hummed thoughtfully. “So, I’ve never seen a minizora before. What’s that like? Do you, like, get stepped on a lot?”

“Kind of, but almost never twice by the same person.” Dipper then gestured up at Mabel. “Guess why.”

“Oh yeah. I saw a photo of that on BookFace.” Tambry flipped through her timeline and turned her phone towards the twins. Sure enough, there was a photo of Mabel frothing at the mouth and biting into Manly Dan’s ankle while he wore an expression of abject horror.

“It was actually whipped cream, but I think it sent the right message,” Mabel added, almost bragging.

Tambry finally smiled. “You guys aren’t half bad.” And she went back to texting.

The van finally pulled up at their destination and they all disembarked.

“There it is, fellas. The condemned Dust 2 Dawn,” Wendy ominously announced to the awe of the others. The building had been fenced off and looked like it hadn’t seen human activity in decades.

“Why’d they shut it down?” Dipper asked, not wanting to show his anxiety at entering another abandoned building. “Some kind of health code violation or…”

“Try murder,” said one of the guys whose name Dipper had already forgotten. “Some folks died in there. The place has been haunted ever since.”

“This town has such a colorful history,” Mabel cheered.

“Wh-wha? A-are you guys serious?”

“Chill out, man,” Wendy said before poking his arm, what she felt to be an appropriate equivalent of a friendly punch. “It’s not that big a deal.”

While everyone else had to climb the fence, Dipper was able to just walk between the holes. Unfortunately, the doors were locked, but then Dipper got an idea. “Hey, let me take a crack at it.”

Robbie scoffed. “Yeah right. I can’t get in, but itty bitty pipsqueak is gonna break it down like-Agh!” He winced as a can hit him in the face. “Who threw that?”

No one gave any response; least of all Mabel who was innocently whistling.

“Come on, leave him alone,” Wendy pleaded. “He’s just a little kid.”

Dipper’s expression of hurt quickly morphed into determination and he snapped his fingers. “Mabel.” She manifested behind him. “Roof me.”

With a wide grin at the chance to show off their twin skills, Mabel picked up her brother. With him curled up in a ball, she took aim at what looked like a vent and tossed him. Everyone else was gob smacked, unable to believe what they were seeing as the little fella climbed. Mabel had only thrown him half way up, meaning he’d have to make the rest of the ascension on his own while the others watched. He disappeared. There was a commotion on the roof, like metal being punched, and then came silence.

Robbie scoffed and turned to the others. “Who wants to bet he doesn’t-”

“$100!” Mabel shouted urgently.

“Pssh. Like he’ll actually-”

With the door unlocked from the inside, Dipper was able to push it open and motion the others to enter. While the others congratulated the minizora, even giving him the nickname Dr. Funtimes, Mabel stuck by Robbie’s side.

“We can discuss a payment plan later. I’d prefer cash, but I’m willing to settle for the equivalent in fingers and toes.” Her ultimatum delivered, she merrily skipped on into the haunted shop.

“Oh man. It’s even creepier than I imagined,” commented Wendy as the group split up to explore the dark isles.

Everything was covered in dust and there were more than a few bugs scurrying about. The whole experience of a convenience store at night was pretty novel for all of them. It wasn’t long before Wendy found the light switches and, much to everyone’s surprise, they still worked. With that set, the games were on. They had a food war with expired pastries, dropped mints in soda bottles just because, and did pretty much whatever else they wanted.

Then Mabel squealed. “Oh my gosh, Smile Dip! I thought this stuff was banned in America.”

“Maybe they had a good reason,” Dipper observed responsibly. All the tape wrapped around the display saying ‘Do Not Sell’ seemed to predate the store’s closing. But the cheering of the teens throwing liquefied food at one another called him back to the fun, leaving Mabel to her own devices.

Up on one of the isle shelves, Dipper and Wendy were enjoying some (miraculously) still frozen ice cream sticks. After an initial period of awkwardness, Dipper agreed to sit on her knee.

“Haha. Dipper, this night is, like, legendary.”

“Really?”

“Just look around. The guys are bonding.” She pointed to where they were pouring ice into Thompson’s pants. “I’ve never even seen Tambry look up from her phone this long.” Tambry just looked up to check on the shelf sitters, but looked away the moment their eyes locked. “And your sister seems to be going nuts for that Smile Dip.” Pink sugary stuff stained Mabel’s hair and clothes. Her eyes looked glazed over as she seemed to be imagining eating something very large. It was unsettling to look at.

“You know, Dipper. I wasn’t sure if you could hang out with our crew at first, but you’re surprisingly mature for your age.”

“Yes. Yes I am, though that’s probably just cuz I’m a minizora.”

“Oh yeah. I think I heard that somewhere. You little guys mature, like, super quick or something.” That was the SFW version, though. When Wendy had read about this online, there had been lots of comments talking about the sexual side of things. Something about them evolving to develop early to ensure survival. There’d been a lot of talk about hormones, or maybe it was pheromones. Lots of people were arguing on the particulars. The overall conclusion was that even if a minizora kid looked like any regular kid on the outside, on the inside they were, like, twice as old. In that sense, depending on how you looked at it, Dipper was kind of like an adult in a little kid’s body. Wendy wondered if this new info made her feelings towards the little dude less or more awkward. Probably the latter.

“Yeah, definitely,” Dipper agreed, oblivious to Wendy’s inner turmoil. He was glad that from his position, he could sneak glances of her chest without her noticing.
12131211111111111111.title: The Inconveniencing

121312111111111111111.content:
Dipper had gone to fetch some more ice cream for everyone. “It’s really a shame this place shut down,” he said to himself as he opened the freezer door. “Not many places are this minizora friendly. I wonder if-” His train of thought was broken when he beheld a floating brain. The nervous system floated beneath it like the tendrils of a jelly fish, along with a gurgling mouth and a pair of eyes that got way too close. Naturally, Dipper screamed and shut the door before anything else could happen.
Then the teens all came over to investigate. “What was that? I thought I heard some lady screaming back here.” Said one of the no-names. “You freaking out kid?” asked the other no-name.
“No, no. I’m fine. Everything’s fine over here. Um, how are you?” Dipper’s eyes nervously darted about in search of some sort of distraction. “Hey look. Dancy Pants Revolution, the game that tricks people into exercising.” That worked and the teens all rushed over to play. After taking one last look inside the freezer and finding it empty, Dipper decided that it had just been some trick of the light and rejoined the teens.
Dipper’s smile was forced as he tried to play it cool. Then he looked at the reflective glass and saw everyone – including himself – as skeletons. He then slapped himself and the reflections went back to normal. “I’ll be right back.” He tried to phone Grunkle Stan. The good news was that it was minizora accessible. The bad news was that no one was picking up.
Dipper then returned to Mabel. He climbed on her palm and her fingers reflexively curled around him in a protective embrace. “Mabel, I need your help. I think this store really is haunted, I can’t get ahold of Grunkle Stan, and if I say anything to these guys,” he gestured to the teens, “then they’ll just think I’m a scared little kid or something. Uh, Mabel?” Her only answer was a low gurgle as pink foam poured from her lips. Dipper then climbed up to her shoulder and started slapping her cheek. “Mabel, how many of these did you eat?”
“Eleven… teeeeen. Blagh!”
“Oh man-oh man-oh man!” Dipper shook his hands as his body felt hot and cold all at once. They were in danger and his other half was in a sugar induced coma. How could things get worse?
Robbie then called everyone over behind the counter. There were a couple of chalk outlines of where the bodies had fallen. Everyone was impressed and, in typical teen fashion, decided to prove their bravery by getting inside the lines.
“Wait!” Dipper urged, positioning himself between the teens and what was definitely a bad idea. “Maybe let’s not do that.”
“Heh-heh. This guy’s scared.”
“All I’m saying is: Why tempt the fates? I mean, what if this place really is… haunted?” The fallout was as bad as he’d feared. Everyone was booing, his nickname was changed to Captain Buzzkill, and worst of all, Wendy looked disappointed with him.
Tambry just kept texting. “Status update. Trapped in convenience store with insane 9 year old.”
“I’m not 9!” Dipper stomped his foot like a petulant child and, also like a child, surrendered to peer pressure by laying down in the chalk outline. “I’m 13. Technically a teen.”
With his announcement made, it was like the whole store gave a groan. The lights turned an eerie green and the chalk outline began to glow. The change in scenery caused Tambry to look up from her phone just in time to vanish in a blinding flash.
“Whoa, what the hell?”
Dipper ran over and checked her phone. “Status update. Ahhh,” he read. Then the security camera flipped on with the girl inside and trying to break out of the glass. Everyone had the appropriate reaction of screaming like a bunch of sissies.
Thompson, who was still playing on the machine, was the next to vanish. He reappeared within the game screen and was pummeled by arrows. With nowhere to run, he curled up in a ball and started to cry. Tension only escalated when the doors closed on their own and no amount of force could break through.
“Everybody wait,” Dipper called, pulling out the journal and flipping to the ghost section. “Whatever is doing this has to have some kind of reason. If we can figure out what it is, thennn maybe they’ll let us go.”
When the white no-name made a sarcastic remark, his reward was to be transported within the art of a cereal box where the bird mascot tried to eat him.
Then, just as everyone was onboard with the only actual plan, Mabel floated about six feet above the ground. She had no pupils, her body glowed, and she spoke with a deep masculine voice. “Wel-commme.”
“They got Mabel!” Dipper cried.
“Welcome to your graves, young trespassers. Mwahahaha!”
“Look, we’re super sorry for hanging out in your store,” Wendy pleaded.
“Yeah. Can’t we just go now and leave forever?” begged Dipper.
The ghost possessing Mabel hummed. “Hmm. Okay, you’re free to go.” The doors opened. However, just as the guys tried to run, they were sealed shut all over again. “Ha! Just kidding.”
“You creepy freak! Just let us out already,” demanded the black no-name.
“Yeah, loser,” Robbie agreed.
“I don’t like your tone.” The ghost snapped Mabel’s fingers, turning the disrespectful teens into hot dogs and putting them on the rollers to cook. “It begins.” Gravity decided to take the day off as everything fell to the ceiling.
Wendy winced in pain. “Agh! Dipper. Dipper, where’d you go?”
“In here,” called a voice from within her shirt. In the fall, Dipper had somehow been wedged waste deep between Wendy’s boobs. Were they not in such great peril, they’d have both been more embarrassed. With the items of the store now swirling in a whirlwind, Dipper directed Wendy to run into an empty soda machine for safety.
Secure inside, Wendy caught her breath with her hand against her chest, along with the boy. Ever since meeting Dipper, she’d been secretly fantasizing about this exact thing happening; only in the fantasy she’d been a lot cooler and able to enjoy the moment without ghosts trying to kill them. “What do they want from us?”
“Revenge, I guess,” Dipper suggested while he tried to wiggle free. Wendy’s breasts were a lot bigger than they appeared through her casual clothes, and the way she was lying down squished them together pretty tightly. The rapid rise and fall of her chest made it hard for the little guy to keep his balance and he kept having to brace himself on his hands. He was touching her boobs, and they were warm.
“What did we do?” Wendy demanded of her boob sitter. Despite her panic, the little guy’s struggling against her sensitive area was causing her body to react very unfortunately. Her only hope was that he didn’t notice and think she was some kind of pervert.
The two had a back and forth until Dipper figured out the pattern. Everyone had been taken after doing ‘normal teen things’. “That’s it. Stay here until I get back.” Before she could stop him, he’d already hopped out of her shirt and hurried out onto the main floor/ceiling. “Hey ghost! I’ve got something to tell you,” he declared even as he was lifted up into the air. This whole thing was giving him some seriously bad flashbacks, but he still had a mission to complete and a sister to save. “I’m not a teenager!”
And just like that, the magic faded. The ceiling was still the new floor, but everything still dropped, including him and Mabel. Then a couple of ghosts – a man and woman in their late eighties – manifested. Were they not transparent and floating, their smiles would be quite charming.
“Well why didn’t you say so?” asked the man with a good-natured laugh. “How old did you say you were?”
Mindful of Wendy’s eyes upon him, Dipper sucked in a breath. “I’m… twelve. Technically not a teen.”
The ghosts then told their backstory. They hated how teens behaved in their store, eventually getting so fed up that they banned them all. In retaliation, the teens had some kind of rap battle dance off in the parking lot. The lyrics were so ‘hateful’ and ‘shocking’ that the pair were stricken with double heart attacks. It was the most tragically hilarious thing the minizora had ever heard.
“But, they’re my friends. Isn’t there anything I can do to help them?” pleaded Dipper.
In fact, there was. These ghosts wanted to see a minizora do a funny dance. When Dipper let slip that he knew one, they were even generous enough to provide him a lamb costume. As the minizora swallowed his dignity and humiliated himself before these strangers, Wendy was enduring her own brand of suffering. Seeing such a cute boy in such a silly costume was unbearable to behold, but she couldn’t tear her eyes away. She had to resort to biting her arm until blood was drawn to keep her imagination from wandering. She’d think about it later, though.
“That was some fine girly dancing,” congratulated the ghost. “Your friends are free.”
The lights returned to normal, as did gravity. Everything fell back to the old floor and the formerly captive teens crawled out of the wreckage, all suffering the spectral equivalent of a hangover.
“Evil,” Mabel burbled, her stomach expressing its hatred for her as she stared at a pink package. “Eeeviiil.”
With everyone still disoriented, Wendy saw fit to tell the story. Once the ghosts appeared, Dipper MacGuivered an array of slingshots that propelled him all around the room. He was like the world’s deadliest pinball and battered the ghosts until they ran away crying. While everyone was in awe, Wendy turned back to Dipper and made the zipping motion, which he returned.
On the ride back, Mabel was amazingly able to keep from spewing. Dipper, meanwhile, was thinking of Wendy. She’d been impressed by him, covered for him, expressed an interest in hanging out further, and her chest had been so soft. So… soft. All in all, he’d had worse nights.
121312111111111111111.title: The Lamby Horror

1213121111111111111111.content:
Grunkle Stan was in the middle of selling literal garbage to a local, who really ought to have known better, when the twins came in.

“Grunkle Stan, can we go to the diner? We’re huuungryyy,” Mabel pleaded, pinching her stomach and shaking it. Soon dipper started doing the same as both made sounds like they were dying. “If I don’t get something in my tummy quick, I might have to eat Dipper.”

“She ain’t bluffing, man,” deadpanned the minizora. Mabel had only ever swallowed Dipper by accident. The exception being that first time back when they were three and she was trying to get him away from some bullies. Later, after he’d been spit up and cleaned, she’d apologized until she lost her voice. Even so, it was fun to freak people out with the threat.

Stan agreed, leaving the idiot locked in the gift shop. Greasy’s Diner was a local joint with a lot of character, which was a nice way of saying it wasn’t up to code. There were even woodpeckers and beavers chewing on the wood. Their server was Lazy Susan, a woman about Stan’s age with a dysfunctional left eyelid. After some rather forced banter, Stan ordered the cheapest item on the menu for himself and leftovers for Dipper and Mabel to split.

“But Grunkle Stan, I want pancakes,” whined Mabel.

The old man was as stingy as ever, but then Dipper saw his chance to shine. At the far end of the room was a machine called Test Your Manliness, with the promise of free pancakes for winners. Cracking his knuckles, he said, “Don’t worry guys. Pancakes are on me. I’ll win us some by beating that manliness tester.”

After a second of disbelief, both Mabel and Stan burst out laughing.

“What? What’s so funny? It’s got a setting for minizora, so I can do it.”

“Sorry Dipper, but you’re not exactly Manly Manington,” cackled Mabel.

“Hey. I am so Manly… Many or whatever.”

“Face the music, kid,” Stan lectured. “Even by tiny people standards you’ve got no muscle, you smell like baby wipes,” he didn’t notice Mabel’s eyes guiltily darting around, “and let’s not forget last Tuesday’s… incident.”

“Hey, Baba is awesome, but that doesn’t matter. Come on, guys. I’m plenty masculine. Look at this chest hair.” He pulled down his shirt, catching the mid-morning light just right and magnifying it back at his family.

“Ahh! My eyes!”

“It burrrns!”

Blushing, Dipper decided that he was getting nowhere with just words. “Fine, oh family of little faith. Get ready to eat those words, with a side of pancakes.”

Dipper hopped down and marched over to the machine, climbing the little staircase on the side to the minizora setting. It had a scaled down handle and everything. Channeling the strength that had defeated gnomes, wax dummies, and a small army of bugs across the years, Dipper grabbed that handle and squeezed with all his might. The bottommost bulb blinked and the machine spat out a card, which Dipper thoughtlessly read aloud. “Cutie patootie?”

Mabel screamed, burying her face in her sleeve and banging on the table as tears poured from her eyes.

Manly Dan, in a rare moment of sympathy for the pipsqueak, decided to do the poor kid a favor. After gently setting him down on the ground, careful not to provoke the wrath of the minizora’s rabid guard dog, the man ape pushed his pinkie against the lever. The machine overloaded and pancakes were flung out to every plate in the diner. “Pancakes for everyone!” While everyone cheered at his display, Manly Dan checked on the person he actually wanted to impress.

Mabel gestured for him to move along, so he did; but only because it was his decision, dammit!

Dipper just sat on the floor, picking up the pieces of his shattered masculinity, when a red head showed up. She wasn’t the one from the Shack, though. This lady was much older, maybe early thirties. She looked like a super model with an hourglass figure, tremendous tits, and a luscious ass that Dipper wouldn’t mind sitting on him. Who just thought that?

She squatted down closer to Dipper’s level, thankfully wearing pants. “Hey there, sugar. Don’t let yourself get down, none.” Her voice was like honey. “Say, yer that Dipper kid Wendy told me about,” she inquired, reaching down with her thumb and trigger finger to shake.

Dipper swallowed what felt like a lung and accepted the offer. “Oh, uh, Wendy t-told you about me?”

“She sure did. Mah little girl said you were quite the hero the other night.”

“Oh, so you’re Wendy’s mom.” Dipper forced a smile, remembering that this was the woman with the power to make guys fling themselves out of closed windows.

“Don’t mind mah husband, none. He’s just got his own special way of showin’ he cares.”

“That’s, aha, nice to hear, but doesn’t help much.” Dipper gestured up at the machine. “Even by tiny standards, I’m a wimp.”

Mrs. Corduroy smiled flatly. “Ya really shouldn’t listen to what some dumb machine has to say. There are lots of ways to be a real man, even for a minizora. Ya just have to find the one that fits yer style.”

“I appreciate that. I really do, but I think I just need some alone time to figure things out.”

“Well, suit yerself.” She stood and was about to walk away, but stopped herself. “Just one more thing. If ya happen on some still water ‘n’ see yer reflection in it, don’t sing. Only princesses do that, ‘n’ that’s about as far from manly as anyone can get.”

Dipper laughed, once more thanking the woman for her kindness, and departed.

Grunkle Stan turned to Mabel. “You just gonna let him go like that?”

“He’d just tell me not to follow,” Mabel sighed. “He’s trying to be more independent and I’m trying to let him. Our therapist said it’d be healthier for both of us.”

“Egh. Head doctors are all quacks if you ask me, though I guess this one’s not totally wrong. A lucky minizora has family that’ll look after them, but things can sometimes go overboard. Ya get overprotective, smothering, and worry yourself sick. A little distance here and there really is for the best for all sides. Gives them some independence from feeling stifled and gives you a break from worrying.” Grunkle Stan then took a sip of his coffee.

“Wow. That’s almost exactly what our therapist said.” Mabel’s awe then turned to suspicion. “How do you know so much about minizora?”

Stan averted his gaze. “Oh, you know. A guy my age hears things. No big deal.”

“Makes sense to me,” allowed Mabel, fully accepting of this explanation.
1213121111111111111111.title: Manly Mini

12131211111111111111111.content:
Trudging down the sidewalk in a funk, Dipper had gotten careless and been stepped on quite a bit. Nothing was broken, but what hurt more was how most of the people didn’t even pay him a second glance as they kept on walking. Deciding he needed to be away from people, Dipper ran out into the woods. There he found some suitable twigs to practice bench pressing. He only made it to 4 before calling it quits.

Laying down on his back, he asked of the sky, “Is it physical? Is it mental? What’s the secret?” Figuring that he had nothing better to do than drown his sorrows in food, Dipper pulled out a tiny bag of beef jerky.

Not a second later, the ground began to rumble as a distant creature roared. Animals of all sorts fled as if from a natural disaster and even Manly Dan was there. “For the love of all that’s holy. Ruuun!” And he did, the dumbass not even noticing the tiny person near the log.

The minizora tried to flee, but the shaking of the ground somehow caused some trees to fall and block his path. Dipper narrowly avoided being crushed as the thunder of footsteps approached. He smelled the creature before he saw it: a putrid combination of B.O., salt, and dried sex fluids. It was big, maybe ten feet tall, with the horns and face of a bull, the body of a man, muscles for days, a blessed skirt mercifully wrapped around the waist, and enough chest and back hair that he could probably survive a collision with a truck, even without the muscles. And to top it off, the thing grabbed a male deer from a bush and used it’s antlers to scratch his ass before tossing the buck aside. Then the thing looked at Dipper.

“Please don’t eat me,” Dipper begged. “I haven’t showered in a week. And I’m, like, all elbows. Elbows and gristle.”

“You,” the creature boomed, pointing a finger accusingly at the tiny. “Gonna finish that?”

Dipper looked down and saw that he was still holding the bag of jerky and quickly threw it towards the creature. “By all means. Go ahead.”

“Thanks.”

The creature introduced itself as a manotaur named Chutzpar. Chutzpar proceeded through a sequence of manly displays by punching trees and head butting rocks. He then demonstrated the ability to smell emotional issues, prompting Dipper to tell his story. Despite first impressions, the manotaur proved to be a very good listener and showed quite a bit of sympathy for Dipper’s struggles with the little guy’s perception of himself as a man. Ultimately, the manotaur agreed to Dipper’s request for pointers on manliness, but only if the minizora climbed his back hair and held on all the way to his lair.

The lair pretty much embodied everything one would expect from a stereotypical man cave, which, coincidently, was the place’s name. There were weights for lifting, foosball, mini-fridges overflowing with beer, and broken controllers piled so high that they reached the ceiling right alongside a game station.

Chutzpar picked up a bone to ring a gong. “Fellow manotaurs. I bring you a tiny hairless child.”

“S’up,” Dipper squeaked. With all the other manoutaurs having such manly names, he introduced himself as “Dipper the destructor,” which they found adequate.

Chutzpar rang the gong again. “Dipper the destructor wants us to teach him the secrets of our manliness.”

The other manotaurs deliberated on this, which is to say things broke out into a fist fight for no discernable reason. In the end they chose to deny his request. But Dipper, having just seen one of these guys punch himself in the face, decided to exploit their apparent weakness for his own advantage.

“Denied? Okay fine. Obviously you guys think it’d be too tough to train me. Maybe… you’re not man enough to try.”

There came a collective sucking of air that actually pulled Dipper forward just a tad. His tapping into their insecurities had convinced them. And so the training began.

“Being a man is about conquering your fears. So your first test is to stick your hand into the pain hole.” This announcement made the other manotaurs wince. The otherwise innocuous hole in the ground had a little sign and everything.

Unwilling to back down on the first trial, Dipper sucked in a breath, got on his knees, and plunged his fist into the hole. At first, nothing happened. “Um, okay. So is there going to be a-ow! Hey, what the-ow!”

The manotaurs collectively flinched, but quickly came out of it when they noticed the hairless child’s cries weren’t in agony, but annoyance.

“What the hell is in here?” Dipper hissed. “It’s, like, really itchy or something. Was there a time limit?”

Many jaws dropped. “Itchy? The last guy to stick his fist in the pain hole screamed for three straight days,” Chutzpar informed in disbelief.

“So I have to stay like this for three-ow!-days?” Dipper demanded irritably.

“Uh, no that’s fine. You can stop now.”

The remaining trials were just as awkward for all involved. The manotaurs again showed remarkable consideration by scaling everything down for Dipper. Instead of pulling a cart full of manotaurs, it was a tiny cart full of mice. Instead of walking across the heads of crocodiles in a lake, he had to walk across the heads of snakes. And on it went. After a good few hours of montage training, Dipper was allowed to relax in the Man Cave’s natural hot springs. There he beheld the most frightening ordeal yet: naked manotaurs. The less said about what lay under their manly skirts the better, although Dipper was certain he’d be seeing those… things in his nightmares for the rest of his life. Then again, this did prompt his curiosity.

“Thanks a lot for taking me under your wing, guys. Though I’ve been wondering something. Are there, like, fem-o-taurs or something?”

That set them to uproarious laughter. “Of course not, Destructor,” Chutzpar said. “We manotaurs are the greatest force of masculine energy in the known universe. We don’t even have X chromosomes,” he said as though it were obvious.

“Oh. Okay. So then… how do you reproduce?”

“We butt fuck. MANFULLY do we butt fuck!”

A long and terrible silence followed. Dipper stared up at the ceiling and questioned every life decision that had led him to this awful reality in which he was imagining… that. After spending so much time with the manotaurs, he’d absorbed a bit of their culture. So it seemed like a perfectly sensible idea to punch himself in the face in the hopes of giving himself amnesia. Then he remembered how often the manotaurs liked to hit their heads against things, and suddenly had a lot more sympathy for their awful plight.

Dipper muttered under his breath. “This is proof that there is a god… and that he hates us.”
12131211111111111111111.title: Man Trials with Manotaurs

121312111111111111111111.content:
Despite the 49 trials before, there was still one last challenge, and it was the deadliest of them all. The first step was a ceremony in which Dipper was stripped down to a loincloth and covered in manly removable tattoos. The permanent ones would come later. Dipper was then introduced to Leaderaur, a great black manotaur roughly 40 feet tall whose lower half was smaller than his fists. With those fists he reached into his chest and ripped out one of his own ribs, which had already been fashioned into a spear. Dipper’s task was to do a heroic act. He had to go up to the highest mountain and bring back the head of the manotaurs’ mortal enemy, the Multibear. By conquering him, Dipper’s manformation would be complete.

Once the spear had been trimmed down so that Dipper could actually wield it, the mission was on. After everything he’d already endured, a perilous trek across the wilderness was practically a pleasant stroll through the park in comparison. Whatever else could be said about the manotaurs, they sure knew how to set up a solid workout routine. The burn in his muscles as he ran was amazing. And with the loincloth covering practically nothing while he moved, the breeze across his privates was also refreshing. He moved with confidence, free of fear of being stepped on or carried off by wild animals. Such liberation was exhilarating. When he stopped at a stream for water, he even shared a knowing nod with a wolf. It was the most amazing thing ever!

While he tried to focus on the trial, planning out strategies for taking down a creature that was tough enough to challenge the manotaurs, Dipper’s mind kept wandering back to home. He thought of Mabel; cute and well-meaning, but often overbearing. Had she come with him, he’d have never been allowed to make it this far, yet he did. This was his accomplishment. A skinny, noodle armed minizora was actually scaling a literal mountain like it was a jungle gym. Body pumping full of adrenaline, Dipper really hoped that his erection would go down before he made it to the top. Luckily, the sight of so many bones littering the cave’s floor managed to do the trick.

Spear at the ready, Dipper entered into the black abyss. Examining the bones, he discerned that they were mostly deer and other moderate to large sized animals. “So this thing is at least as big as a manotaur. Hmm. I probably should have asked what a Multibear was before coming up-” *Grrr* “-here.”

Then it revealed itself. The beast resembled a chimera, the mythical creature that was a combination of multiple animals, only in this case they were all bears. It was like someone hacked the creature creator in Spore and just kept adding bear parts. It had bear bodies for limbs, heads and regular limbs seemingly for decoration, and three asses in back. Probably best not to think about that.

“Bear heads, silence!” declared the eloquent central head while smacking one of the lesser growling heads. “Child, why have you come here?”

“Multibear, I seek your head,” Dipper declared. “Or, at least one of them. Any chance you could just give me a spare?” Alas, negotiations broke down, and the fight commenced.

It was a harrowing ordeal. Dipper had never before faced that many claws or teeth all at once. Overpowering his foe was out of the question, but Dipper knew he had other strengths. The Multibear was unaccustomed to fighting a foe so tiny, so his blows were awkward. In observing its movements, Dipper further discerned that the many bear heads were not in complete harmony and could be provoked into independent action. Diving into the creatures thickly matted hair, he began a mosquito strategy of stabbing somewhere sensitive, and then running before the Multibear could smack itself. This was repeated everywhere that looked sensitive, driving bear paws to smack several bear heads unconscious. The finishing blow came after the enemy kneed itself in the fourth groin and it fell with a calamitous crash.

Dipper ascended to the central head and took aim at the throat. “A real man shows no mercy!”

The Multibear conceded his defeat with surprising grace. His last request was to die listening to his favorite music. After turning on the old cassette player, it turned out that the song was Disco Girl by Baba, the same one that Dipper had been mocked for liking earlier. The two got to talking. When the manotaurs said that the Multibear was their mortal enemy, they’d actually meant that he was just some guy who kept to himself and listened to music they didn’t like. The truth revealed, Dipper could not bring himself to harm a kindred spirit, and marched his barely covered ass back to the Man Cave and threw down his spear before Leaderaur.

“I’m not gonna do it,” Dipper announced to the shock of the manotaurs.

Leaderaur was angry, or possibly indifferent. He kind of only had the one expression and tone, so it was hard to tell. “You were told the price of manhood is the Multibear’s head.”

“You know, screw that. You keep saying that being a man is all about being tough and agro all the time, but I think that’s bull! I may not have muscles, or hair in certain places, but the Multibear is just a nice guy who doesn’t want to hurt anyone. What about cutting off his head is even remotely heroic?”

Leaderaur hopped down from his stone throne and backhanded it into oblivion. Yup, definitely mad. “Kill the Multibear or never be a man!” he roared in Dipper’s face, but the tiny stood his ground.

“Then I guess I’ll never be a man.” His mind made up, Dipper allowed himself to be booed off the stage and left the Man Cave. After making a pit stop at the Shack to wash off the tattoos and get a new change of clothes, he tracked Mabel and Stan back to the diner, where apparently Mabel had been trying to ship Grunkle Stan with Lazy Susan.

“Dipper! Bro-bro, where ya been? I-” Mabel’s peppiness evaporated as she looked over his bruises and her demeanor turned dark. “Does someone need to die? You can tell me if someone needs to die.”

“No, it’s fine,” Dipper glumly dissuaded.

“Good,” Stan said between bites of pie.

“It’s just these half man half bull humanoids were hanging out with me.”

“Here we go,” Stan added dismissively.

“But then they wanted me to do this really horrible thing, but it just wasn’t right. So I said no.”

His attention primarily on the pie, Grunkle Stan said, “You were your own man and you stood up for yourself.”

“Huh?”

“You did what was right even though no one agreed with ya?” Stan said around his mouthful. “Sounds pretty manly to me, but what do I know.”

Dipper beamed. Maybe there was hope for him yet.

Mabel, meanwhile, was studying the minizora more intently. “Is it me, or did you get a little bit of muscle in the last few hours?”

“Well, I did just climb a literal mountain and defeated a composite bear monster, so I’d hope so.”

“Here.” Mabel handed Dipper a fork, which he easily lifted over his head. Curious, Mabel just kept adding on more silverware, making it six pieces before it was too much and Dipper dropped them. “Oh my gosh, this is amazing! You used to only be able to hold up three. My little brother is so strong now.” She sucked in a gasp and dropped her chin to the table. “What else can you do?” she asked with a breathy undertone.

With a smirk on his face and hands uncaringly in his pockets, Dipper gave Mabel a knowing look. “Oh, you know, probably nothing special.”
121312111111111111111111.title: Man Test

1213121111111111111111111.content:
(Originally by chaos)

In Wendy’s room, the red head had invited her friend Tambry for a little girl’s night. Lately that just meant that Tambry would be on her phone all night while Wendy watched cheesy horror movies. Mostly they ignored one another, but this night would soon take an interesting turn.

“Hey Wendy, come check what I found.”

Wendy scooted over across the bed to investigate what had provoked Tambry to speak. Whatever it was, it had held the girl’s attention a lot more than normal, so Wendy was at least curious. She was almost disappointed when she saw the black woman. She was in her early thirties with her huge tits hanging out and staring excitedly at the viewer. “You’re watching porn?”

“You sound surprised.”

“I don’t know. I guess I was expecting something a little… more. You seen one porn video, you’ve seen ‘em all,” Wendy said disinterestedly, noting the odd way Tambry was smiling. “Hold on, what kind of porn is this?”

“Minizora porn.” As soon as the words left Tambry’s lips, the black woman pulled out and held up a large dildo to the camera. A minizora was sitting on the tip of the sex toy, smiling excitedly and waving to the camera. The little guy was Caucasian, maybe late teens, and not bad on the eyes. The volume was off, but the two appeared to be introducing themselves and exchanging playful banter.

Before Wendy even knew what had happened, her jaw had dropped in astonishment as she found herself unable to look away.

Tambry giggled and paused the video just as everything was getting lined up. “That Dipper’s pretty cute, wouldn’t you say?” She didn’t wait for an answer. “After he saved us from those ghosts, I got to thinking. He deserves an award for being so brave, if you know what I mean.” Tambry motioned like she was giving a blowjob and made gagging sounds.

Wendy rolled her eyes. She knew of her friend’s promiscuous side, but it had never been an issue until now.

“But since Dipper’s too small for the regular way, I figured I’d do a bit of research,” Tambry explained, licking her lips. “It’s actually pretty amazing the kinds of stuff you can do with minizora. And all of it is super hot.”

“You slut,” Wendy chided good-naturedly with a friendly shove. “You’d do anything, or anyone, just to kill time in this boring town.”

“Like you wouldn’t?” challenged Tambry.

Wendy had to avert her gaze. She’d had rolls in the hay with guys before. While she didn’t see herself as being as bad as Tambry, she was far from a prude. However, Dipper was different. He was more than just a random fling. He was a friend, and one that she suddenly felt uneasy about letting Tambry near. “You know he’s only twelve, right?”

“So? He’s a minizora. I’ve seen videos with them as young as eight, and its all perfectly legal.”

Wendy blinked, gob smacked by this revelation. She knew her friend didn’t have much in the way of standards, especially given the selection in this town. However, Wendy’s building frustration asserted that Dipper was still different, no matter what the laws or her friend said. Her mental image of Dipper depicted a young boy too sweet and innocent for the corrupting likes of Tambry. But at the same time, her mind couldn’t help but wander. Dipper was awful cute, after all. She liked him as a friend, a good friend, but couldn’t stand the idea of frightening him off with her stupid mixed feelings.

“Think you can hold off on this whole ‘reward’ thing?” implored Wendy. “Consider it a favor to me, for that thing I helped you with.” Not willing to say the words out loud, Wendy set a hand on Tambry’s, hoping the connection would help her friend see reason.

It didn’t work.

Tambry’s eyes widened and her smile grew wide as she finally set her phone down. “Oh, I see what’s going on here.” Her eyebrows bounced suggestively, making Wendy fear for the worst. “You want the first shot at him.” Tambry continued before Wendy could sputter a coherent denial. “Fine. I’m cool with that, but don’t think you’ll get away without spilling the details.” She slid off the bed and made for the door. “Think I’ll go get some more snacks. Don’t run off and fuck the little dude without me.”

“I don’t wanna fuck the little dude!” Wendy shouted after Tambry, throwing a pillow just as she turned the corner. Incensed, the red head snatched up a handful of popcorn and angrily chomped it. “Great. Now she’s gonna start nagging about it,” she grumbled, already imagining Tambry asking if she’d ‘popped her minizora cherry’. That would be just like Tambry. “You just don’t get it. He’s just a good friend.”

“Now what’s this Ah hear ‘bout ya fuckin’ a li’l dude?”

Wendy’s heart sank as things went from bad to worse. There in the doorway stood her mother. Sheela wore tight daisy duke shorts and a crop top that accentuated her voluptuous figure. With no means of escape, Wendy grabbed another pillow, slammed her face into it, and screamed in anticipation of the inevitable headache. “I didn’t say nothing, ma. Please drop it.”

Sheela gave a kind but knowing smile; her default expression. “Ya sure there ain’t somethin’ botherin’ ya, baby girl? No pint-sized boy stole yer heart, did they?”

Wendy groaned even louder into the pillow. Her mom had a way of digging right to the core issue. Somehow, much to her daughter’s consternation, she always seemed to know when her ‘baby girl’ was having issues. Whether it be a fight with a boy or teenage angst, Sheela knew. She knew and always made it a point to be there to offer motherly advice, whether Wendy liked it or not.

“He’s just a friend,” Wendy asserted her exasperation.

Sheela gave a smile that seemed to ask ‘Are you trying to convince me, or yourself?’ “A friend’s jus’ a friend ‘til ya get too friendly, baby girl. Don’t get all hung up on the petty details. If ya like a guy, put yerself out there ‘n’ take the risk. It’s what makes life worth livin’.”

Wendy’s mouth twisted as she tried to form some rebuttal, but her mom’s words had the insufferable power of asserting themselves in her brain. Theoretically, purely hypothetically, it wouldn’t hurt to see if Dipper was interested. More than once she’d caught him staring at her, though that might have just been him being wary of being squished. If she was careful, she could discern if there was something there without jeopardizing their friendship, right?

“Best make up yer mind quick, baby girl. If Ah were you, Ah’d grab that boy, take ‘im home, ‘n’ introduce ‘im ta every inch ‘f mah naked body,” Sheela purred, miming as if she were holding something small and stroking it across her body like a bar of soap. She squealed happily like she’d just eaten something especially delicious. “The things Ah’d do with a man that small. Mmmh! Ah bet them tiny hands could reach all kinds ‘f places.”

“Jesus God, ma! Why?” Wendy whimpered helplessly, wishing for the first time that she was at work right now.

With her message delivered, and giving one last self-satisfied smirk, Sheela made her departure. She felt no shame about sharing her more perverse thoughts with her daughter. As a mother, she saw it as her duty to impart her baby girl with all her wisdom, especially about the bedroom. Her daughter would thank her someday, especially if this boy turned out even half as good as her gut suggested.
1213121111111111111111111.title: Night at the Corduroy’s

12131211111111111111111111.content:
“And so the mighty hunter stalks his prey,” Dipper narrated. He kept a low profile, hand on the ground in search of tracks, wielding a weapon, and was back to only wearing his loincloth. The time was night and there were only a few patches of light to illuminate his way. “The tracks are fresh. I must be getting close.” He ran up ahead a short ways, only to stop and duck behind some cover before scanning the area. “Though focused on his prey, the hunter must also be mindful of his surroundings. For in this vast, untamed wilderness, there could be competition. Or worse… predators.”

“Hehe-he.”

Dipper rolled his eyes and set a hand to his ear. “Hark, what’s that? Could it be the wind, or some foul creature with really bad teeth?”

“Grrr.”

“Regardless, the hunter must be on guard.” Dipper ran out into the open, weapon at the ready, and charged for his next hiding spot. “The hunter feel’s wary. He’s certain that he’s being stalked, but from where?” As he scanned his surroundings, he scratched under his loincloth, turning around so that any potential ‘predators’ could see what he was doing. Again he chose to ignore the giggling. “Hmm. The brave hunter knows of only one type of beast in this area that could be hunting him, but where is it? The beast is known for its less-than-graceful movements, big feet, and general lack of any kind of stealth ability, so how could it be hiding?”

“Grrr!”

Dipper smirked at this reaction, though his pulse did race. He heard movement behind him and spun around. “Though the hunter is brave and fierce, being tiny, in the dark, and knowing that some terrible creature is hunting you can make anyone nervous. Ahh! There it is again.” He spun, this time following the movement in the dark for a short ways before losing track. Then it spoke.

“Fee, fi, foe, fum! I smell the flesh of a yummy minizoram,” boomed the beast in a low yet feminine voice.

“Not bad,” Dipper nodded respectfully. “But you’ll have to do better if you wish to best me, monster.”

“Mwahahaha! Tiny fool. You dare come into my territory and think that you’ll walk out alive?”

“That is the general idea. Yes.”

“Well too bad. Cuz I crave minizora flesh, and you, ain’t goin’, no-where. Haha-hahaaa!” She sang in reference to one of her favorite movies.

Dipper was growing more anxious by the minute. The beast was moving more now, hopping from place to dark place. He held his weapon close as his vision could only reach so far, yet he couldn’t keep the smile off his face. “Th-the hunter is not afraid. H-he will best you, vile demon. He will claim what is his and return triumphant to his sister!”

“Oh, a sister?” said the beast, intrigued. “My yummy morsel has a sister? Heheheee. Tell me about her. Is she cute?”

Dipper wobbled his hand uncertainly while wearing a shit-eating-grin. “Eh. She’s alright.” He then felt a mighty thud just behind him, followed by a gust of hot air on his back. Knowing what was coming, he spun around to behold his doom.

“Boo.”

“Gaaah! The giant face of the monstrous Mabel!” Chin to the ground, her face was illuminated by one of the few lamps in the room, which casted some extra menacing shadows. Her eyes were wide with anticipation and her grin was fighting against her malicious persona. And Dipper knew, just beyond where he couldn’t see, she most likely wasn’t wearing anything more than underwear.

“Time for din-din.”

The monster opened its mouth and stuck out its tongue, but Dipper wasn’t having it. Spoon at the ready, he swatted the slimy appendage away and took advantage of the distraction to flee. “Not tonight, big head.” But as he turned to face ahead, he saw movement incoming through the darkness. “Oh no!” He knew what it was and tried to duck by rolling underneath. It worked and the hand past right over him. Those agility tests were already paying off.

“Hey, no fair!” whined the monster. “Get in my mouth.” She stood tall and surveyed the area. In the attic, the space between the beds was littered with obstacles like stacks of books, discarded clothes, that one overturned nightstand, and anything else that gave her prey ample places to hide. “Grr. I’ll find you eventually, you little sweetie. Then we’ll see who has the big head.”

“It’ll still be you,” Dipper called from his hiding spot, immediately regretting his decision.

Grinning wide, her braces gleaming in the florescent light, Mabel stomped through the obstacles, but not so hard to disturb those down stairs. Breaking character, she casually observed, “It was nice of Grunkle Stan to install that extra insulation. Gives us more privacy.”

“Especially with how cheap he is,” agreed Dipper. “Say, why do you think the Shack is so Minizora accessible, anyway?” He dared peek out of his book tent, finding Mabel’s bent over backside wiggling in the air as she investigated somewhere else. Her panties were pink and frilly. And, from experience, he knew this pair to be especially soft.

“Don’t know. You should ask him some time.” She lifted her head high and made a show of sniffing. “I smell *sniff-sniff* minizora sweat.”

Dipper lifted his arm and sniffed under his pit, but didn’t smell anything. He might have said as much, if his cover hadn’t been swiped away.

“Ah-ha!” Mabel lunged down for another grab, but a spoon smack to the knuckle made her retreat. “Ee! Ow, not so hard,” she hissed while rubbing herself.

“Oh my gosh, I’m sorry!”

“Well you should be. With how strong you’ve gotten, I might get nerve damage.” She sucked in a shocked breath. “Or maybe I’ll have to get my finger amputated!” With Dipper’s deadpan upon her, she added in even greater distress, “Then how am I gonna poke your tummy like the Burypills Flour Boy?”

“With nine other fingers, I’m sure you’ll get by.”

“Ha! Joke’s on you. I only have seven other fingers. The thumbs don’t count.”

“Mabel, that’s pedantic even for me.”

“Wait, so does this mean I’ve out-Dippered Dipper?” she asked elatedly.

Dipper rolled his eyes. “No, but it does mean you-”

“Got’ch’ya!” Again Mabel lunged, but this time she succeeded in scooping up the tiny boy. Beaming in triumph, she brought him up to her face.

“Hey, that’s cheating! We were in timeout.”

“Pssh. I never called timeout, so it’s fair play.” Mabel waved dismissively as she opened her fingers, allowing Dipper to stand freely on her palm. It also let her more easily admire his barely clothed form.

“You said you were hurt. That’s an automatic timeout.”

“Nuh-uh. That rule is only if you get hurt. I could break all my arms and legs and we’d still be playing.” She sounded almost bragging. “Unless, of course, you chickened out and surrendered.”

Staring up at her in defiance, Dipper’s spoon was propped up by his side like a spear. He looked quite regal, and even a little photogenic. Careful not to disturb him, Mabel held her hand steady as she reached for her phone and took a picture. “Oh yeah. Very cool.”

Dipper rolled his eyes. “I still say this win is illegitimate.”

“Well, I’ve got you now, so I don’t really care,” Mabel giggled cutely. “So then, brave hunter,” she tittered again, “what do you think I should do with you?”
12131211111111111111111111.title: The Hunt

121312111111111111111111111.content:
Satisfied that the door was locked so that no one could intrude on their fun, Mabel decided to hold off on devouring her prey right away. Once they’d cleaned up enough to avoid any nasty surprises in the morning, Mabel leaned back in bed and dropped Dipper on her sternum between her flat breasts, petting him gently as she hummed a soft tune to herself.

“Not that I’m complaining, but this isn’t exactly what I was expecting,” Dipper thought aloud, risking ending this relaxing moment.

“The way I see it, I’m cute, kittens are cute, and since kittens like to play with their food, I figure I should try doing the same. I’ll push you around a little before I’m ready for the real fun. It’s like foreplay, only better because you’re also small and cute.”

“Interesting logic,” Dipper observed as she started poking around his loincloth.

“I still can’t believe you went on that whole big adventure without me. You must’ve been so scared.”

“At first, yeah. The manotaurs made Manly Dan run away screaming. But once you stop and talk to them, they’re really not all that bad.”

“Except with the Multibear,” Mabel reminded coldly. In her mind, all bullies were undeserving of any respect.

“Yeah. They were bullies, but other than that, they were alright. Pretty easy to manage once you know how to manipulate them.” Dipper lifted his hand and grabbed Mabel’s finger. She stopped immediately, likely expecting him to say he wanted to get up or something. Instead, he just ran his hand along her digit, petting her in return as they both stared up at the ceiling.

“This is nice, just the two of us,” Mabel hummed contentedly. “So did you really talk to a wolf?”

“It wasn’t really a talk. More like a moment of shared understanding. I can’t really explain it, though. We just sort of… clicked, and then went our separate ways.”

Mabel blew a raspberry. “Boo. I would have pet it.”

“And that’s why I got to go on the big adventure of self-discovery in nature while you got to stay home and ship Stan. Did that actually work out?”

“Don’t think so, but it was still fun.” Then Mabel recalled something. “You know, Stan said some things about minizora.”

“Oh yeah?” Dipper asked, bracing himself for something stupid, offensive, or both.

“Yeah. He said that when minizora have loving families, they tend to get overprotective, which just stresses them out a lot. He said that a little distance can be good for both of us, making you feel less stifled and me less worried.”

Dipper craned his neck to look up at Mabel, awed by such insightful words from the con man. “And?”

She sighed. “At first I was just doing stuff with Stan to take my mind off you. He kept saying you’d be fine and I believed him. Honestly, it was kind of nice being able to do stuff without you for a change.” It sounded like a hard confession. Mabel lifted her head to look down at the boy on her chest, eyes apologetic. “And you?”

“I guess it was kind of the same for me. I don’t think I’ve ever run so far on my own in my life. It was freaky at first, not having you as my safety net, but then it got exciting. I did all that amazing stuff on my own. I proved I could, and now I feel a lot tougher for it.”

Mabel then poked under his armpit, making him giggle. “You’re still a scrawny minizora, though.”

After being allowed to push her finger away and getting his laughter under control, Dipper sighed. “I still missed you, though. It was nice doing stuff by myself, but the whole time I kept thinking about you. What you’d say if you saw me doing that stuff. How the manotaurs would try to stop you from stopping me.” He snickered and rested his head back on her chest. “Mabel vs. a pack of thirty manotaurs. Seems like an even fight.”

“Yeah, well I’m glad to have you back, too. I’m also glad you kept your new underwear.”

“It’s a loincloth.”

“It’s cute and makes you look like an authentic jungle boy. Now if we could only get you a tan so you’re not so pasty.”

“I’d say that’s your fault. You’re the one always covering me up whenever it gets too hot out.”

“Hey. Old habits are hard to break, especially for a big sister looking after her baby brother.”

“Little,” Dipper asserted flatly. “I tolerate being called little, but I draw the line at baby. I was born first, remember. So technically-”

“Actually,” Mabel cut in authoritatively, “I’m the big sister. Always will be. And you’ll always be my adorable itty bitty wittle bwo-bwo.”

“Keep up the baby talk, and I’ll go find the spoon and smack you again.”

Mabel laughed. “Sure. Go ahead. I’ll wait, wittle bwo-bwo.”

Dipper rolled his eyes. “Eh, too tired. Bed’s too soft.” He yawned. “Remind me to do it tomorrow.”

Mabel yawned as well and flipped off the last light. “Sure thing.”
121312111111111111111111111.title: Bedside Chat

1213121111111111111111111111.content:
Grunkle Stan had cleared out the big room over on the side of the Mystery Shack to get things ready for the party. It wasn’t anyone’s birthday or anything. Stan just hoped that presenting himself as a fun loving guy would make him look more trustworthy, which in turn would make it easier for him to con people. Once the old man got sick of the kids just fooling around with silly string, he sent them to his personal copy machine to print out some flyers.

Mabel threw the tarp off the old machine. When Stan had said that he’d “fixed it up,” he apparently meant that he’d slapped some duct tape in random places and didn’t even bother to dust.

“Well this is a fire hazard just waiting to happen,” Dipper commented as parts sparked. “Does it even work?” Clambering up to the controls, he tried messing with the buttons while Mabel rested her arm on the scanner. The machine roared to life and scanned the arm. And after belching out a cloud of black smoke, a sheet of paper was produced with the arm on it.

“Ha, success,” Mabel cheered, holding the paper in one hand and a cup of soda in the other. “Hey, want to copy our butts next?”

Dipper gave his sister a no-nonsense scowl and crossed his arms. “I’m very disappointed with you, Mabel.” Then, just as her smile started to fall, he added, “That’s like asking if I want to breathe. Of course we’re copying our butts!”

Mabel’s joy was short lived as the paper began to move on its own and crumbled. She dropped it and backed up to a safe distance, grabbing Dipper along the way. The paper continued to shimmer, wrinkle, and flatten itself on the floor until the black-and-white image became colored. The arm swelled until it popped right off the paper, now three dimensional and capable of autonomous movement. Reaching out as though in silent pain, it started to crawl towards the twins.

“Ahh, stay back,” cried Dipper, jumping out of Mabel’s hand and positioning himself between her and the arm. There was something almost poetic about his enemy being a copy of the very thing that had always brought him such comfort.

“Back you fiend!” Not knowing what else to do, Mabel splashed her drink onto the arm. It sizzled, bubbled, and then dissolved completely, leaving nothing behind but a puddle of soda mixed with liquefied paper.

“Oh my gosh! Mabel, I think this copier can copy human beings!”

Mabel sucked in a breath and got down to her brother’s level. “Do you know what this means?” But before he could answer, she sprayed him with silly string. “He-he, you let your guard down.”

Dipper waved his arms frantically as he dug his way out of the pink substance. “Come on, Mabel. This is serious. This is like, like an actual cloning machine. It just did your arm, and it moved on its own. Severed arms aren’t supposed to move on their own.”

“Oh my gosh, you’re right.” Then Mabel looked thoughtful; a dangerous expression on such a cute face. “So does this mean we’re not going to copy our butts anymore?”

“I… don’t know.” Dipper admitted. “Hmm. Let’s think about this for a second. This isn’t some wild animal or sapient phenomenon like the last few times. This is just a machine. It can’t do anything without someone to turn it on. It copies people, but since Grunkle Stan’s had it for years and never noticed anything weird, it must also work on paper just fine. And apparently things supernaturally copied can be destroyed with just a bit of soda, so as long as we keep some nearby, we can keep things under control. If this were an SCP, it’d probably be considered safe.”

“I’m not hearing a no~ho,” Mabel sang.

“But that brings up the ethical questions,” Dipper continued, starting to hyperventilate. “Are these things alive? Do they feel pain? If I copy my face, is that a person? Did I just create a person without a body? How long could something like that survive? There’s just so much we need to consider before-”

“Too late!” Mabel was sitting on the copier, skirt up and panties around her ankles. The machine buzzed to life, but at least produced a copy without any black smoke this time. As before, the paper crumbled and shimmered until the copied part popped right off.

“Yup. That’s your butt alright,” deadpanned Dipper. He’d recognize that thing anywhere, though it was more than just her butt. It was Mabel’s cheeks, taint, slit, a couple of flailing stumps where the legs should be, it went up about an inch past her hips, and all encased in her skirt.

“Wow, this is amazing,” Mabel awed, picking up her own bottom. *Pfft* “Ew, it farted on me, hehe,” she was having too much fun to be grossed out as she started dancing with her disembodied pelvis. “Oh wait, no. I farted on me, haha. This is great!”

“This is wrong on so many levels. I don’t even know where to start,” Dipper grumbled. “Does that thing even have a stomach? Where did the gas come from for the fart?”

Alas, Mabel wasn’t listening. She’d taken to feeling up her clone segment, which was apparently very interesting. “Oooh! I’m so soft and squishy. Hmm. A bit too squishy right here. Dipper, am I fat?”

“After all the running from monsters we’ve done, I don’t think we could be out of shape if we tried.”

“Oh good. But what’s with this smell?” She pressed her nose in between the stumps. “Is that how my kitty always smells? Here, you check.” Whether deliberate or by accident, Mabel dropped the clone ass right on top of her tiny brother.

“We just discovered cloning and you want me to smell your clone’s butt?” Dipper asked incredulously as he was pinned down by the familiar set of soft, warm cheeks.

“Not my butt, my kitty. I want to make sure it doesn’t smell weird. You know, for hygiene purposes,” she added bashfully. “You smell me all the time, so you’d know what’s different.”

Dipper rolled his eyes and took a nasal inhale. “It smells fine.”

“Really?”

“Yeah, just like it always does, which I’m pretty sure just raises more questions.”

“Good point,” Mabel agreed. “For example: if I wanted to go out and make sure you weren’t kidnapped by crazy bull monsters with weird penises, would this make a good cage?” she asked while patting the clone’s butt.

“First of all, I wasn’t kidnapped. It was voluntary. Secondly, we both know you’d sooner shove me in your own underwear before using… whatever that is.”

“Eh. True.”

“And thirdly, how are you being so calm about this!?”

“Because you're overthinking things, which leads to stress. While I go with the flow,” Mabel bragged, “which leads to sunshine and peace.”

Dipper’s eye began to twitch. He hated when Mabel used actual logic against him instead of Mabel logic.

Now what?

Ignore the printer and party?
Keep playing with the printer?
Take a break to 'destress'? *hint-hint*
1213121111111111111111111111.title: Party Planning

12131211111111111111111111111.content:
After disposing of the clone, the twins had agreed to a truce regarding the machine. They’d wait until things were less busy around here so that they could ‘experiment’ in peace. In the meantime, Stan was giving out tasks for the party. Soos was the DJ and, because Mabel wanted to try and make some new friends, Dipper volunteered to man the ticket booth with Wendy. And given that they’d have to stay there, together, all night, it was the best possible scenario.

“You dog, you,” Mabel teased when they were back up in the attic, poking Dipper’s shoulder as he straightened his bowtie.

“I have no idea what you’re talking about.”

“Dipper, you obviously have a thing for Wendy. You couldn’t have been more desperate when you agreed to be with her.”

“Yeah, yeah. Whatever. But I’ll have you know that I have a plan to make sure my night with Wendy goes perfect.”

“Plan?” Mabel whined her disappointment. “You’re not making one of those overcomplicated listy things, are you?”

“You say overcomplicated, but I say thorough.” Dipper extracted a piece of paper from his vest and unfolded it until it was three times his size. “Step one: get to know each other with playful banter. Banter is like talking, but smarter.”

“So smart it loops right back around to being stupid.”

“Yeah, see, this isn’t banter. This is what I’d like to avoid with Wendy. The last step will be asking her to dance.”

“Dipper, you and me talk like regular people, and that’s what you’re trying to avoid?”

“Well…”

“Oh, little brother.” Mabel shook her head, sat down, and gently set him on her knee. “Allow me to impart my wisdom. You see, back before I learned that Gideon was a horrible, horrible monster who deserves to suffer and die alone,” she explained cheerfully, “we would just talk and do things we both liked. I’d say whatever came to mind, he’d comment, and we just went back and forth like that. That’s what I liked about him. He was easy to talk to. And that’s what I’ll be looking for tonight with friend making; people I can talk with. Whatever happens with Wendy, I guarantee the real first step isn’t banter, it’s talking.”

Dipper was speechless. What could he say after a lecture like that?

Pleased by his reaction, Mabel touched under his chin to close his jaw. “Remember we agreed to trust each other with our love lives? I’ve done my part and given my opinion. It’s up to you to make the final choice.”

Once the party finally got underway, things went about as well as could be expected. Soos was goofing up picking the right sound effects, Stan was charging an exit fee, Mabel was optimistic as ever, Dipper was mortified that his sweaty pits would stain his shirt, and Wendy played it cool despite having similar worries.

The ticket stand was surprisingly packed, keeping the two pretty busy. Telling himself that Wendy was less scary than the Multibear, Dipper decided it was on him to break the ice. “So, uh…” His mind blanked. Crap-crap-crap! He had to say something. Anything! “Uh… have you ever heard of a Multibear before?” Why!?

“Oh, did my dad tell you that one?”

“Huh?”

“Yeah. He’s got all kinds of stories about the stuff he claims to see out in the woods.” Wendy tapped her fingers as she listed them off. “The Multibear, gnomes, tiny deer, a magic mailbox… Oh, my favorite is the Hide Behind.”

Dipper touched his chin in thought. “That sounds familiar.”

“Yeah. It’s this thing dad’s never actually seen. No one has, because it always hides behind stuff whenever people look its way. The only proof that it’s even there are its weird footprints and this buzzing sound it makes as it follows you,” Wendy laughed. “Can you believe that? It’s a monster that just trolls people, following them and freaking them out. Man, if I were a monster, that’s what I’d want to be.”

“Oh, that’s interesting. You wouldn’t want to be, like, a mermaid or something?”

“No way, dude. Mermaids live in the ocean, which is, like, half fish piss. That’s gross,” she snickered as Dipper did the same. “Besides, the only thing they wear is seashell bikinis, and I don’t really have the figure for that.”

“I think you do,” blurted the tiny before he could stop himself.

“Huh?”

“What?”

“What’d you say?”

“Nothing.”

“Oh-ho, no. You’re not getting out of this that easily.” Her attention fully on Dipper, Wendy still managed to trade tickets for money and count the change. “You definitely said something.”

“You can’t prove that.”

Wendy glowered, trying to look menacing as she loomed over the puny child. With Dipper unflinching, her façade lasted a whopping couple of seconds before she descended into giggles. “Wow, dude. You’re really something, ya know that.”

“I am?”

“Yeah. I mean, if I were your size, and someone this big was trying to push me around,” she gestured to herself, “I’d probably start squealing inside an hour.”

“No way. You’re way tougher than that.”

“Aww, you think so?”

“Yeah. You could easily go an hour and a half.”

Never one to let such impudence stand, Wendy set her fingers in prime flicking position right beside Dipper. She waited, giving him a chance to tell her that this wasn’t okay. With his defiance holding fast, she carefully delivered a flick to the back of Dipper’s head, which he laughed off. “Watch that mouth of yours, little man. You never know what kind of mess it might get you into.” She got back to work, not hating it nearly as much as she’d expected.

With her attention back on the customers, Dipper allowed his eyes to crawl up and down the red head’s body, focusing on a couple potential messes he wouldn’t mind getting into.

Meanwhile, inside the party hall, Mabel was taking a break after shaking what her momma gave her. Upon seeing something interesting, she took her own advice and said the first thing that came to mind. “Wow, you’ve got an animal on your body! I’m Mabel.”

Grenda was a big girl. Not fat, as it was clearly all muscle. Her arms were about as thick as Mabel’s torso and she was about a head and a half taller to boot. She was also a bit more developed chest wise. Her voice was pretty deep, but Mabel found it cute. Beside her was Candy. She was tiny, Korean, and had an even cuter voice, which for some reason Mabel pictured coming out of an elongated rainbow horse thingy. She had a bunch of forks strapped to her fingers which she used to eat popcorn. “Improvement of human being,” she’d called it. And just like that, Mabel knew she’d found her people.

When Soos made an announcement of a party crown award, for some reason bad girl music started playing. Coincidentally, a blonde girl and her cohorts approached the stage. She wore hoop earrings and mostly purple attire, her hair was teen pageant huge, and Mabel’s eye twitched when she saw the size of her chest.

“Who’s that?”

“The most popular girl in town, Pacifica Northwest,” informed Candy.

“I always feel bad about myself around her,” Grenda added.

Pacifica was demanding that the crown simply be given to her, but Soos insisted that it be a competition. “Ha, who’s going to compete against me, Pacifica?” she asked, taking a microphone and gesturing into the audience. “Fork girl? Thunder thighs?” She and her cronies laughed, although they were the only ones. Everyone else just stood by, looking helpless.

“Hey, I’ll compete!” Mabel exclaimed, ever the picture of glee, although internally was a different matter. She’d just decided to like Candy and Grenda, which made Pacifica’s comments unacceptable. However, she was still willing to give the bleach blonde a chance and offered the hand of friendship. “Hi, I’m Mabel.”

Pacifica looked at the offered hand like it had just come out of the sewer. “Ha, that sounds like a fat old lady’s name.”

“I choose to take that as a compliment.”

Pacifica’s grin grew smug. She knew she had this in the bag. “May the best partier win.” Then she and her cronies danced a retreat into the shadows.

Mabel waved goodbye. “Nice meeting you… dead girl,” she added under her breath, much to the approval of her new friends.
12131211111111111111111111111.title: Let's Party!

121312111111111111111111111111.content:
“No way. You’re full of it,” Wendy waved dismissively, showing excellent multitasking by taking people’s money while finding the time to talk to Dipper.

“I am not. I could totally take the Multibear,” asserted the minizora. At his size, he had to run around the table to get the tickets and the money where it needed to go. This was probably a job one big person could do by themselves, but he was content just being on support if it meant talking to Wendy.

“Yeah, right. Dad said he once saw the thing use deer antlers to pick its teeth. How would you deal with something like that?”

Dipper smirked. “Easy. See, the Multibear’s weakness is its many heads.”

“What, like a hydra?”

“Not exactly. See, all the heads share control over all the limbs. Normally they’re mostly in harmony, but distract them with enough pain, like by kicking it in the balls, and you can trick the lesser heads into beating themselves up for you.”

“Oh man!” Wendy laughed, wiping tears from her eyes. “You are too much, little man.”

“Really? I’ve always thought of myself as just the right amount.”

Unlike Dipper, Wendy’s filter was working perfectly fine, which she used to stop herself from making an age inappropriate joke. Not for his sake, but there were some little kids and their parents buying tickets, and she’d have preferred to avoid a lecture. She couldn’t remember the last time she had this much fun while on the clock and not ditching. All in all, everything was going perfectly fine, which was why things had to go wrong.

Robbie showed up. With his usual aloof attitude, he said, “Hey Wendy. So there’s this lame dance going on. Care to join me?”

“Oh gee, Robbie, I’d love to, but I’ve kinda got a job to do out here.”

Robbie scoffed. “Since when do you care about work?”

“I… don’t know.” It was a fair question.

“Come on, babe.” He extended his hand. “Shorty here can take on ghosts. I’m sure he’ll be fine by himself.”

“Uh, I don’t know. Dipper?” She turned to the minizora, eyes full of concern.

It would have been the easiest thing in the world. Easier than failing to fly. Dipper need only say that he needed Wendy’s help, or that he wanted her to stay. Both were good, though the former was less embarrassing. He just had to give some indicator that he didn’t want Wendy to go, and she wouldn’t. Easiest thing ever. “Nah, I’m good. If you want to dance, then go for it.” In his head, Dipper proceeded to scream every expletive in the English language.

“Well, if you’re sure.”

“Oh he’s sure,” assured Robbie before pulling Wendy inside.

As Dipper swore at himself, he paused in selling tickets long enough to climb up the wall and peek through the window. Wendy looked to be having fun, dancing with Robbie. The minizora returned down to the table about a second before Wendy turned a concerned look back towards the window, her dance moves less energetic than usual. Had their eyes met, maybe they’d have realized a thing or two. But since that didn’t happen, things inevitably got crazy.

It didn’t take Dipper long to reach the (il)logical conclusion. Grunkle Stan wouldn’t allow him to back out on his promise, but he was allowed bathroom breaks. He took advantage of this loophole to make for the copier and laid himself on the scanner. The clone was almost completely identical in both behavior and appearance. The only obvious difference was that his colors seemed slightly muted and his hat lacked a pine tree. They even thought alike, agreeing to the name Tyrone after Dipper drew a 2 on the clone’s hat.

It was only after agreeing to the plan that Dipper remembered that he’d seen this cliché before and how it always went sideways. “Hey, we’re not gonna get jealous and turn on each other like the clones in the movies, are we?” But Tyrone assured him that Dipper could trust himself, and also that he could just be disintegrated with soda, demonstrating a terrifying lack of self-preservation.

Whatever. With Tyrone manning the ticket stand, Dipper was free to enter the dance floor. He was immediately reminded why he generally hated dancing.
