The music was so loud that it drowned his voice out and people were so focused on wild movements that they ignored anything or anyone that might be underfoot. In under a minute, he’d suffered 17 encounters with shoes, scuffing his vest. He only barely made it to the chairs for cover when his phone rang.

“Hey buddy. It’s me, you,” Tyrone said. “I just now remembered why we hate dancing.”

“I know, it’s terrible. I can’t even get near Wendy and Robbie’s showing off his guitar. Ahh! Now they’re sitting on the couch. We’ve got to do something.” That’s when he noticed a bicycle. “I just got an idea.”

“I got the same one, but we’re gonna need help.”

“Also, how are you calling me?” Dipper asked. “It’s the same phone, so shouldn’t it have the same number?”

“No idea, man. Might want to tell Grunkle Stan about it, though. Selling clone machines for cheap could bring in some extra money, so long as he’s honest about them dissolving.”

While Dipper was spiraling with the clones, Mabel was dealing with her own challenge. It had come to the singing part of the competition and Pacifica had just delivered a beautiful solo. Mabel might have been moved to tears, if the blonde bitch hadn’t just said more mean things about her new friends. Her counterattack involved the eightiesest, crowd pleasingest, rock balladest song at Soos’ disposal. And with the passion she put into those words, the crowd had no choice but to love it.

That’s when Dipper set his plan in motion, having several of his clones steal Robbie’s bike and having the stupid emo wannabe give chase.

“Oh wow, that sucks.”

“Dipper!?” Wendy asked in alarm of the minizora on the couch arm. She couldn’t see too well in the dim light, but it looked like his vest had been scuffed. Did he seriously risk getting stepped on just to bail on selling tickets? More so, Wendy felt a knot form deep down in her gut. She’d just left the little guy alone with all those strangers. Who knows what could have happened. “What are you doing here?”

“Don’t worry. I got someone to cover me. It’s cool.”

“Uh, okay,” she agreed uncertainly. Wendy chose to trust Dipper’s judgement. He knew more about being a minizora than she did, so if he thought he was alright in here, then she had no room to argue. The music then shifted to something soft and smooth, perfect for romantic dancing. “Oh man, I love this song.” Still sitting, Wendy swayed to the beat, trying to focus on relaxing.

“Hey, goofus,” Mabel greeted. The competition was on hold, so she decided that her services as a big sister were needed. “Now’s your chance to ask-mmm.”

Dipper needed to use both hands to seal his sister’s lips shut. He then allowed himself to be carried out of earshot before releasing his grip.

“Who’s responsible for this?” Tone dangerous, Mabel pointed to the scuff marks around his clothes.

“No one. I, uh, didn’t see their faces.” Dipper waved his hand, wanting to hurry things along. “There’s no need to make a scene.”

“Fine, whatever. But this is your chance to ask Wendy to dance. Come on. Gooo!” Whisper cheering, Mabel set her brother back down on the floor.

“R-right,” Dipper agreed. Being set back down, he started marching forward like a malfunctioning robot. What happened to the easy talking he’d been doing earlier? Dammit! Fortunately, the teeny actually managed to make it back to the couch. Unfortunately, thinking that he was still with Mabel, Wendy got up and went elsewhere. Double dammit!

With his plans falling apart all around him, Dipper proceeded to spiral further out of control with his clones. There were clones to manage the music, to keep an eye out for Robbie, and in general take control of all factors on the dance floor to ensure optimal dancing conditions. And as the old saying goes, the more complicated something is, the easier it is to break.
121312111111111111111111111111.title: Double Dipper

1213121111111111111111111111111.content:
The first break in Dipper’s plan was in cloning himself. The first break he actually noticed came much later. With everything set exactly as he believed it should be, Dipper headed for his own position, only to run into…

“Wendy? Wh-what are you doing here?”

“Just waiting for the bathroom, dude.” Leaning casually against the wall, she then got a wicked idea and adopted a playful smirk. “You’re not going to try sneaking a peek under the door, are you?”

“Wh-wh-what!? N-no! No, I would never do anything like that to you!”

“Not to me, huh? So other girls, then? Am I not good enough for you?”

Hands balled into fists, Dipper’s whole body began to shake as he turned redder than a tomato.

“Hey, hey. Chill, little dude.” She knelt down on one knee and began stroking his back as she’d seen Mabel do. “I was just kidding around.”

Dipper’s breathing evened out and he returned to his regular color. “You know I’d never do that though, right?”

“Yeah, man. I know you’re better than that.”

As good as that was to hear, Dipper still found himself staring at his feet.

Wendy’s smile also fell as it finally clicked. “Someone told lies about you, didn’t they?”

Dipper adjusted his hat so that his face was hidden.

Heaving a sigh, Wendy sat herself down beside the little man. “Ma always told me to never listen to what dumb-asses had to say. If they can’t see how great you are, then just let ‘em stew in their own misery, because that’s all they’ve got. They’re just a bunch of miserable losers with nothing going for ‘em except bringing others down to their level. Don’t let ‘em, dude.”

“And what would you know about it?” Dipper grumbled, suddenly not so enthused about dancing.

Wendy was a little upset by his tone, but decided to let it slide. “I know what it’s like to have my head shoved in a toilet, for one. I also know what it’s like to have a bunch of scum bags talk behind my back.”

After rubbing his arm against his eyes, Dipper finally lifted his hat to look up at Wendy. “You?”

“Yeah,” she laughed uncomfortably. “Believe it or not, grade school was pretty much hell for me. Every day it was some new rumor, pushing in the hallway, stealing my homework, you name it.”

“But… your parents.”

“Yeah, I know. My dad could beat up any other dad in town and ma could… Uh, the point is that I didn’t want to bother them. My folks were my heroes and I didn’t want to let them down by looking weak.” As Wendy explained, indulging in memories she’d tried to bury, she felt her own eyes start to water.

“So, what did you do?”

“The only thing I could do.” Windy downed half of her drink. “I found someone weaker than me, and then I beat the shit out of the shits who were beating him.”

Dipper’s cheeks swelled like a frog’s as he contained his surprised laugh.

“Yeah, it was the damndest thing. For some reason I could never stand up for myself, but it turned out a lot easier to stand up for others. I started fighting back and, of course, only then did the school take notice. My folks were called, but I never got it too bad. Pretty sure they suspected what was going on, but were letting me handle things my way.” Wendy chuckled quietly to herself. “So I kept getting into fights until the bullies got the message and backed off. That’s actually how I met the crew. We were all getting pushed around, but together we were able to start pushing back.”

“Wendy, you’re… amazing,” Dipper said in awe.

“Nah, dude. You’re amazing. You stood up to a pair of ghosts while I was cowering in a soda machine. You really think those shitty people who lied about you could do better?”

Averting his gaze, Dipper started to chuckle.

“So keep that in mind the next time people start talking shit about ya.” With her fist, Wendy gently pushed against Dipper’s side. “Don’t let the bullies bring you down to their level, man. It’s the only way you’ll really lose.”

At long last the bathroom door opened and out stomped a very irate blonde girl in purple.

“Yeesh, finally! Been holding it in for ages.” Wendy set down her drink, stood, and entered, but paused before closing the door. “Oh, and Dipper. Just so we’re clear, if I catch you peeking, I’m flushing you.” They shared one more laugh before she departed. In truth, she had no idea what she’d do. Would she just pretend not to notice? If she did catch him… She’d overheard Mabel talk about punishing him more than once. Maybe, with Mabel’s permission, she could-No! Nope! Bad brain. Don’t go there!

Outside, Dipper felt like a great weight had been lifted off his shoulders. He and Wendy had just made a real connection. Nothing could ruin this moment.

“Hey, Dipper,” snapped Tyrone. He was being flanked by several other clones, all looking most displeased. “What are you doing here? We’re already 42 seconds behind schedule.”

“Guys, the most amazing thing happened. I ran into Wendy by accident and we… we made a connection!”

“That’s nice, but not the plan,” Tyrone dismissed, pulling out the list and reciting the steps.

“Wow, is that what I sound like? Uh, guys, maybe we don’t need the plan anymore. Maybe I can just talk to Wendy like a normal person.”

“You shut your whore mouth!” accused 6.

“Well, if you’re not going to stick to the plan, then maybe you shouldn’t be the Dipper who dances with Wendy,” 5 suggested to the agreement of the others.

“Guys, we said we weren’t going to turn on each other,” Dipper intoned, bracing himself to run.

“I think we all knew we were lying.”

Dipper held out his hands. “Hold on a second. Before this gets nasty, can I just say one thing?” The clones seemed reluctant, but gave their permission. Dipper urgently pointed behind them and shouted, “Oh my god, a naked manotaur!” As the clones screamed in horror, Dipper tried to make a break for it, but the others quickly caught up and overpowered him, dragging him off to be detained.

The alliance between the clones inevitably broke down as they began fighting for dominance. No one knew what to do anymore and some clones along the outskirts were still doing their jobs. Dipper, meanwhile, was able to take advantage of the confusion and herd almost all of the clones back to the bathroom hall. There he found and spilled Wendy’s discarded drink, finally putting an end to 90% of his mess… by watching himself melt and cry out in mildly bummed pain.

“I am going to make my therapist a fortune.”
1213121111111111111111111111111.title: Don't Let Them Pull You Down

12131211111111111111111111111111.content:
The final break came as Mabel and Pacifica were awaiting the final song before the judging.

“Pacifica, I just want to say that whoever wins, it’s been a super fun party.” Again Mabel offered the hand of friendship.

“Aww, it thinks it’s gonna win,” condescended Pacifica. “Hey, you hear people clapping for the weird girl? Yeah, me neither.” And she walked away, strutting like she owned the place, right out of Mabel’s reach.

Having just made some new friends, Mabel was in an extra good mood. She didn’t even really care about winning. What mattered was watching her friends smile as she stood up for them. Speaking of support, she just spied her oldest and most favoritest supporter of all time on the dance floor. “Hey! Hey, Dipper,” she called, cup of soda in one hand and the other waving frantically as she ran over. Something looked weird about him. He seemed unusually stressed and maybe a bit off color. Did he bomb with Wendy? And why was he putting himself in needless danger out in the middle of the dance floor? “What are you doing here without W-whoop!”

The taller twin tripped and fell with a low thud. No big deal. Dipper wasn’t the only tough twin around and she’d dealt with worse in just the last few weeks. Except down here on the ground, she was given front row seats to where her soda spilled. Her eyes went wide as the thing’s form lost its cohesion quickly; its cries were more annoyed than pained. It was all over in just a few seconds and no one else saw a thing. Someone distracted by dancing even callously stepped in the puddle of remains like it was nothing. The thing that used to look like Dipper had been reduced to goop. Then there came a snapping sound as Mabel felt her smile grow wide. It was so big that it threatened to split her face in half. If it weren’t for her eye twitching, Mabel would have looked like the happiest girl in the world.

She picked herself up and brushed herself off. No big deal. She turned bodily towards the copier. There was something important that she needed to deal with, but no big deal. Mabel maneuvered her way through the crowd, not offering her usual words of encouragement as her eyes never strayed from her target. It was no big deal. Then, as music and general noise blared all around her, someone stepped right in her path. Okay, possible big deal.

“Hey, where do you think you’re going, weirdy?” demanded Pacifica haughtily.

“Just got something to take care of. It’s no big deal,” Mabel answered, sounding distant. She tried to move around, but her path was blocked yet again.

“Ha, I knew it. Weird girl knows she can’t win, so she’s chickening out before she can suffer a humiliating defeat. I don’t blame you, really,” Pacifica said while examining her nails. “It’s to be expected when you go up against… Hey, get back here!”

“Just gotta take care of something,” Mabel said, still smiling and distant. “It’s no big deal.”

Pacifica snapped her fingers and her cronies blocked Mabel’s path. “No one turns their back on Pacifica. Do you have any idea who I am?” Then something extra unsettling happened. “Hey, why are you laughing?” Mabel was chuckling under her breath. It was a low and sinister sound. The cronies could see her face, and so backed away. With her allies beating a slow retreat, the rich girl started to think that she’d made a mistake.

“No,” Mabel giggled. “I have no idea. Before today, I’d never even heard your name. But let me tell you something about me.” Mabel spun around, turning the full force of her glower on Pacifica, making the blonde pee a little. “My second week here, I killed, like, ten people. I threw a fire poker through a man’s eye and tossed another man’s sonnet spewing head into the fire. And as I watched him burn, you want to know what I felt? Nothing!” Mabel’s laugh was growing just a bit maniacal. “I was content, because I cared nothing for those people. They got in my way and threatened my happiness, so I gave them what they deserved.” She stepped into Pacifica’s personal space; almost nose-to-nose and forcing the other girl to lean back. “Guess who’s standing in my way now.”

“Me,” Pacifica squeaked like her lungs were full of helium.

“There’s a smart bitch. And they say blondes are stupid. Hehe. So what do you think you should do now?”

Pacifica’s answer was to fall backwards with a suspiciously heavy thud, eyes open but otherwise unconscious.

“Good choice.” And Mabel turned back around. Except instead of resuming her mission, she looked into her new friends’ eyes and felt her conviction waver. She’d just shown the ugliest side of herself. Would they hate her for it? That was about the second or third most awful thing that could happen right now.

“Oh. My. Gosh! That was amazing!” Grenda boomed.

“You are everything I want to beee,” Candy added.

Mabel’s smiled remained, but softened a bit as she felt 20 lbs. lighter. “Thanks guys. I really needed to hear that right now. Now if you’ll excuse me, there’s a thing I need to do.”

“Oh hey, can we come with you?”

“Yes. Share with us your secrets,” Candy begged.

“I’d be delighted. It’s always better to do things with friends.”

Later, Dipper was feeling a little down on himself. In all the commotion with the clones, he’d lost track of Wendy. When he’d found her again, she was talking and laughing with Robbie, seemingly having a really nice time. But as down as he felt, there was still a spark of hope deep down. He hadn’t actually lost Wendy. She was still very much his friend. They’d had a real talk, just as Mabel had said, and right now that was enough to satisfy him. Dipper decided that it would probably be a good idea to unplug the copier to avoid any future temptation. When he arrived, he was greeted with the most interesting sight.

“Die! Die! Die!” Mabel was standing on top of the machine, going nuts with a golf club.

“Whaaa!” Some big girl was absolutely waling on the poor contraption with her bare fists, ripping it to pieces.

“He-hehehe!” A Korean girl had burst out from one of the side compartments like a gleeful chest burster, miscellaneous wires in hand and laughing hysterically.

Then, even more frighteningly, all three girls came to a dead silence after Dipper sneezed. They all froze and stared at one another for a good long while. Dipper blinked and, in classic Weeping Angel fashion, all three girls manifested directly before him, chins on the ground, rears in the air, and staring transfixed at his tiny form. Their collective breath was hot and smelly.

Mabel broke the silence and pulled out a cup of soda. “Dipper, I swear to god, if you melt, I’m gonna kill you.”

“Wait, wha-ahh!” The contents of the cup were dumped on the mini. “Hey, what was that for?”

“You know what,” Mabel replied, eyes narrowing dangerously. Dipper didn’t need to inquire further.

“Oh. My. Gosh. He’s so cute!” Grenda gushed.

“I just want to pick him up and keep him in my purse like a celebrity dog,” Candy added.

“First things first, girls. Dipper, these are my new girlfriends. Candy and Grenda.” Mabel gestured to each of them. “Second things first. Are there anymore?” Her tone grew low and dark.

“What? Uh, no. No I got them all. At least… hold on.” Dipper counted on his hands.

“Dipperrr,” Mabel growled.

“Okay, there’s only one I can’t account for. Wait, you didn’t happen to-?”

“Yeah, I took care of it. Not by choice, but it’s gone now.”

“What are you two talking about?” asked Grenda.

“That copy machine can copy people,” Mabel blurted without a second thought. “Doofus here said that we should be careful with it, and then made a bunch of clones behind my back.”

“Ohhh, that sounds fun,” whined Candy. “Why did we destroy it? I could have used a study buddy.”

“Because somebody broke his own rule, and now the game isn’t fun anymore.”

“Aww. Too bad,” Candy said, not pressing further. “Wait. You hear that?”

All four listened. There was quite the commotion coming from the main room, including the voice of Soos. “And the winner is Pacifica!”

“The competition. I missed it!” bemoaned Mabel.

“There, there,” Candy soothed, petting the larger twin’s hair. “It is fine.”

“Yeah. You totally would have won if we didn’t destroy this machine.” Grenda gestured to the smoking hunk of metal. “But that was also pretty great. You’re pretty great, Mabel.”

“Aww, you guys.” Still on the floor, Mabel pulled the other two into a hug and they all laughed.

Feeling like a third wheel, Dipper cleared his throat. With his eyes he asked if he was allowed to leave.

“No way, bro-bro.” Mabel grabbed him and stood, the others following. “I’m not letting you out of my sight for the rest of the night. It’s the only way to make sure you don’t try any more stupid stuff.” There came a small explosion from the machine.

“You sure? Because I think it’s-”

“Don’t care!” Mabel stuffed him into her shirt collar and led the charge back to the dance floor. “Come on girls. This thing’s going all night!”

And it did. For a good many hours. Wendy eventually joined the other girls on the mostly cleared floor, feeling so much livelier than before. Mabel was even gracious enough to donate a few strands of her hair to wrap around Dipper’s waist as a kind of lifeline while he boogied on her shoulder. So, in a way, Dipper and Wendy did get their dance.
12131211111111111111111111111111.title: Mabel Smiles

121312111111111111111111111111111.content:
There was an unusually heavy amount of traffic as Stan drove the twins through town. Mabel was keeping herself entertained with nacho earrings and Stan was fighting the urge to road rage. However, the old man’s anger turned into fear when he finally noticed all the horses and covered wagons. “Oh no. Not today!” He started driving like a maniac, spouting a bunch of nonsense about getting away. As Mabel slipped and slid in her seatbelt, she pulled Dipper from his minizora car seat and pressed him tightly to her chest where he’d surely be safer. When Stan finally stopped, encircled by some wagons, Mabel looked out the window and saw an adorable baby cow with a bell around its neck.

“I’ve got a good feeling about today.”

It was Pioneer Day. No longer fighting it, Grunkle stan got out of the car and explained. “Every year these yahoos dress up like idiots to celebrate the day Gravity Falls was founded.” He then threatened to break Toby for talking with an accent.

The twins, however, were enthralled by the many attractions on display. Candle dipping, gold panning, and a marriage between a man and a woodpecker were the closest. As the twins got ready to enjoy the festivities, Grunkle Stan sent them off with a warning. “If you two come back talking like these people, you’re dead to me.”

Then, with a couple of preteens being forbidden from doing something even moderately fun, the unexpected happened.

“There’s a carpetbagger in the turnip cellar.” “Well hornswaggle my habbersack.” They then spat on the ground and Mabel carried her brother off for fun and adventure.

“Dead to meee!” Stan shouted after them.

Sheriff Blubs was on a stage, welcoming everyone to the opening ceremony. Behind him and the deputy sat four people dressed in period appropriate attire. There was Pacifica, a little brunette girl half her age, and presumably their parents, all wearing self-satisfied grins. That’s when Pacifica took the mic. “Howdy, everyone. You all know me, Pacifica Northwest, great-great granddaughter of town founder Nathaniel Northwest.” She gestured to the regal statue behind her. The audience applauded. “Now if you’ve got the pioneer spirit, we ask you to come on up and introduce yourself.”

Mabel gasped. “I get participation!”

From her shoulder, Dipper frowned. “I don’t know, Mabel. Isn’t that girl kind of like your arch enemy?”

“That’s water under the bridge,” Mabel laughed. But as she ran up on stage, she stowed Dipper in her sweater collar where he couldn’t be seen.

Pacifica held out her hand in welcome before looking. “Our first newcomer is M-Mabel!?” she squeaked and stepped back. “Wh-what are you-?”

“Yeah, let’s get this pioneer day started,” Mabel cheered, turning the mic around for this next part. She whispered, “Look Pacifica, I just want to apologize for what I said the other night.”

Pacifica remained frozen, barely even breathing.

“You caught me at a bad time and I said some things that were 100% true, but shouldn’t have said out loud, so I’ll make you a deal. Whatever this thing is between us, it stays between us. Friends and family are off limits. Break that rule, and I’ll mess you up worse than infamous axe murder Lizzie Borden, got it?” Her smile was the very picture of chipper the entire time, leaving not even Pacifica’s family to suspect what was really being said. Then Mabel turned the mic back and started cheering “USA! USA!” to the audience’s delight.

Finally regaining her composure, and not wanting to look weak in front of her family, Pacifica scoffed. She convinced herself that this weird girl was just blowing hot air, though her terms seemed reasonable enough. No need to bring outsiders into their feud. “I’m sorry to break it to you, but Pioneer Day is for serious people, and you look and act ridiculous,” she carefully mocked. She pointed to Mabel’s sweater. “I mean, a puppy playing basketball? Are you always this silly?”

“Hey, I can be serious.”

“You do have nachos hanging from your ears, hun.”

Suddenly feeling self-conscious – an unusual sensation for the taller twin – Mabel departed the stage, hand on her collar to keep her passenger from moving too much.

“Don’t tell me you’re actually listening to her,” Dipper chided once they were out of earshot. “You’re Mabel. You run through self-important twerps like her like copy paper.” When Mabel sighed despondently, Dipper considered a new approach. “Hey, let’s get you some old timey butterscotch.”

Grunkle Stan, meanwhile, had gotten into a bit of a mess. After losing his temper, he’d been thrown into the stocks. There he met up with Gideon, who’d finally felt well enough to walk around without a limp. The tiny troll hadn’t yet perfected his next diabolical scheme and was just out to unwind and enjoy the day like everyone else. And with Stan helpless before him, Gideon decided that the best way to do so was to pelt the man with tomatoes.

While that was happening, Mabel was sitting at the base of the statue, petting the little boy in her lap while scarfing down candy. “Dipper, can I ask you something. Do you think I’m… silly?”

Dipper wasn’t sure what the right answer was, but decided to go with his gut. “I know that you’re caring, friendly, and can tough it out against people ten times your size.”

“That’s nice of you to say, but you’re my brother,” she sighed and slumped in her seat. “Ugh, I knew it. The nacho earrings. The sweater. I thought I was being charming, but I guess people see me as a big joke.” She then discarded the nachos, pulled off her sweater so that only her pink undershirt was left, and tied the purple fabric around her waist like a belt.

“Come on, Mabel. You love that sweater.”

“I did before Pacifica ruined it for me. Grr, she ruins everything!”

“So kick her butt.”

“That wouldn’t change the fact that she’s right, though.”

Dipper shook his fists with brotherly rage. “Pacifica! Why does she think being related to the town founder means she gets to treat everyone else like garbage?” Looking up at the statue, Dipper’s memory was jogged and he pulled out the journal to flip through its pages. “Wait, I think I remember reading something about Nathaniel Northwest. Of course, this is perfect!” He held up the journal for Mabel to read the tiny print with him. The author speculated that Nathaniel wasn’t the real founder of Gravity Falls and that the secret lay within a document taped to the page. However, the author had never been able to crack the code.

Dipper gawked after unfurling the paper and beheld its many strange glyphs. “Oh man! If this cover-up is true, then it means Pacifica’s whole family’s a fraud. This could be a major conspiracy.”

Mabel’s eyes went wide. “Wait, conspiracies are super serious, right?”

“Oh yeah, definitely.”

“Then if I help you crack the code, then no one will ever call me silly again.”

Dipper smirked up at her. “Yeah, duh. Like there was a chance you wouldn’t want to get involved in something like this.”

“Very true. Plus you’d need someone to reach the high shelves, anyway.”

“Mystery twins?” Dipper extended his fist for a bump.

“I thought you hated that.”

“Eh. I’m starting to accept it.”

Mabel bumped his tiny fist and the pair were off, utterly oblivious to the eyes upon them as they went.

Where should things go from here?

Follow the episode with the 'Mystery Twins'?
Forget the episode and have fun at the fair?
Is there a second encounter with Pacifica?
Something totally random?
121312111111111111111111111111111.title: Pioneer Day

1213121111111111111111111111111111.content:
Dipper decided that the logical first step for their investigation was at the local library. All the records were old and almost nothing had been uploaded online, there was even an old timey projector, so they had to research the old fashioned way. Dipper was gung-ho with this plan, but Mabel struggled almost from the start. This kind of book learning had never been her strong suit. While he cross-referenced the symbols on the parchment to other old texts, she was trying to figure out if reading upside-down would help her focus.

Then Dipper thought he’d made a discovery. “Hmm. Maybe if we use fire, it might light up some hidden message!”

“It’s so obvious. Also, I made a hat,” she bragged, pointing at the parchment now folded into a paper hat. Her sense of pride quickly fell after she’d realized what happened. “Ugh, I just did something silly again.”

“Hey, wait. Mabel, you folded it into a map.”

“I did?” she took the hat off to examine it. Sure enough, there was a dotted line and an x and everything. “Wow, how lucky is that.”

“Not luck. It must be part of the code the author never figured out. Mabel, if we-” But before Dipper could explore further, they were alerted to the ringing bell of the sheriff and deputy. Apparently they were looking for a couple of kids for ‘secret reasons,’ which they proudly boasted about.

Going into stealth mode, the kids snuck out of the library and made for the destination on the map, the Gravity Falls Museum of History. It was easy enough to get in. Pioneer Day was their busiest day of the year, and they even gave out complimentary balloons. As best as Dipper could interpret, the next clue lay within some abstract triangular painting.

“We’ve got to figure this out quick. I don’t think those cops were at the library to check out books.”

“I don’t think the one with the bell can read,” agreed Mabel.

Not knowing what else to do, the twins just stared at the painting in search of some elusive pattern. Sure enough, Mabel once more cracked the code by lying upside down on a bench, prompting Dipper to do the same.

“You figured it out again, Mabel. You’re on a roll!”

“Hehe, thanks. I think I’ve seen that somewhere in the cemetery.”

“Hmm. Are you noticing a pattern here?”

“What do you mean?”

“Well, looking at things upside down isn’t that big a deal. I would’ve gotten here too eventually,” he explained defensively. “More importantly, you folded the paper into a hat. And you did so in precisely the way that everything lined up to send us here. What kind of mad genius are we dealing with?”

Mabel sucked in a breath. “Does this mean I’m a mad genius, too?”

“If it does, then dad owes me $50,” Dipper muttered. “At the very least it means that whoever wrote this document, you guys might be on similar wavelengths or something.”

The two got right side up, but did so too quickly and suffered a momentary head rush. Mabel, ever the clumsy one, landed with Dipper squished beneath her butt. “Hehe.” She then wiggled her rump around, feeling him squirm helplessly between her skirt-clad cheeks. “You alright, bro-bro?”

Before Dipper could deliver a scathing retort, the cops showed up. In a panic, Mabel clenched her butt cheeks together to hold Dipper in place as she ducked out of sight. Eavesdropping, she confirmed that the two were definitely after a pair of kids. She waited until their backs were turned and made a break for it; brother now in hand because running like that would have just been ridiculous. Luckily, the cops got stuck in the doorway and she made her escape.

Meanwhile, Pacifica decided to skirt the rules just a tad when she saw Stan still locked up. She offered to free him in exchange for him admitting that the Northwest family was the best in town. It’d be like doing Mabel a favor, but in such a way that would surely piss her off. It was the perfect crime. Unfortunately, when she offered him paper so that she’d have this confession in writing, Stan refused to cooperate and wrote something highly inappropriate. And with Mabel not around, Pacifica felt safe with plausible deniability as she set the tomato armed populace on the guy.

Out in the cemetery, the twins stopped by the statue of an angel with her hand extended and pointing at something.

“Alright Mabel. Have at it.” Dipper gestured up.

“Say what now?”

“You’ve figured out all the other clues so far, so let’s see if third time’s the charm. I think the statue is pointing at the next clue, but how would Mabel solve this mystery?”

“Hmm. That’s a good question. How would Mabel solve this mystery?” Mabel nodded, attempting to look serious as she studied the finger. Her reputation was on the line and Dipper trusted her to figure things out on her own. She’d hate to disappoint him. Then she got a funny idea, scaled an adjacent statue, and stuck the finger up her nose. “Ahh! She’s picking my nose. Haha.”

There came a crack as the finger bent and the headstone beneath opened up to reveal a secret passage.

Staring down into the deep dark cavern, Dipper blinked. “That was somehow not at all what I expected, but also exactly what I expected. Good job, Mabel.”

“Ha! Who’s silly now, Pacifica?” she challenged as she carefully extricated her nose.

“That would be you,” Dipper stated flatly as he awaited to be picked up and set on her shoulder.

“What? You’re on her side now?” she asked, depositing him where he belonged.

“No, Mabel. Don’t you see? Paper hat, upside down, picking your nose,” he listed. “Those were all silly things that were exactly what we needed. Your silliness is solving this mystery.”

“Whoa! In that case, double take that, Pacifica!”

“Just watch your step. A place like this is bound to have booby traps.”

Mabel snickered. “Hehe. You said booby.” She then glanced down at her chest. “Speaking of, do you think Pacifica’s are bigger than mine?”

“Mabel, history changing conspiracy hunting isn’t the time for that sort of thing.”

“Exactly. It’s silly, and I thought silly was solving the mystery.”

Dipper threw back his head and groaned as his words were turned against him. “Mabel, some girls get lucky and develop early. Most of them get addicted to the attention and become haggard prostitutes by age 20. Your body will develop at its own pace, and you can laugh at Pacifica when you’re still cute and she’s half plastic.”

“Aww. That’s so sweet of-” Mabel stepped on a switch that made a loud click and sunk into the floor. “Uh oh!”

One daring escape from some poison darts in the wall later, and the pair found themselves in a dusty old hall that might have been someone’s study. There were shelves lined with books, all kinds of old documents, and even an old projector like they’d seen back in the library. Mabel gravitated towards a folder labeled ‘Classified: Do Not Read’ in big red letters, and quickly got to reading, learning all sorts of secrets about America’s (apparently) freaky leadership.

“Hey, Ben Franklin secretly was a woman!”

“Then that would also make him a lesbian,” Dipper added. “Dude was a notorious whore monger, ya know. I always liked to think he – or I guess she – reincarnated as Winston Churchill.”

Eventually, they found what they came here for. Nathaniel Northwest wasn’t some great pioneer turned town founder, but a waste shoveling village idiot. Whoever wrote that line must have been pretty vindictive. Regardless, the true founder was Sir Lord. Quentin Trembley, III, Esq. But before the twins could investigate further, the coppers finally showed up, the tall one half covered in darts.

The twins are captured, as following the episode's plot?
Wendy steps in?
Pacifica steps in?
Gideon steps in?
1213121111111111111111111111111111.title: Mystery Twins

12131211111111111111111111111111111.content:
With nowhere to run, it didn’t take much to convince the cops to spill everything they knew, especially after revealing that they’d only found this place by following the trail of candy Mabel left behind. Blubs even had a film reel in his hat that conveniently explained everything, despite this apparently being a matter of national security. Quentin Trembley was the 8th and a half president. Despite winning the 1837 election in a landslide, he quickly gained a reputation as America’s silliest president for declaring war on pancakes, appointing 6 babies to the Supreme Court, and banning pants, among his more mild activities. He was booted out of office and disappeared into the valley that would one day be known as Gravity Falls. All records of him were erased with Harrison replacing him as president and Northwest as the town founder. Trembley’s body was never found…

“Until today,” Blubs finished, pointing to a large orange block containing the man from the film.

“Hey, that’s pretty - *Thwonk* - hey!” Mabel cried. Her wrists and ankles had been handcuffed while she wasn’t looking.

“The fool thought he could live forever by encasing himself in peanut brittle,” Blubs explained mockingly.

“Yeah, that’s great and all, but why did you cuff me?” Mabel demanded.

“One, because finding Trembley has been our special mission. Two, you two are under arrest for learning the secret. And three, because everyone has seen that video of you with Manly Dan, and that’s just not something we feel like dealing with.”

“So I cuffed ya while you was distracted by the film,” bragged deputy Durland. “We-hehe!”

As upset as Mabel was, she had to shrug her acceptance at that last one. “Okay, fair enough. So what are you gonna do with us?”

“Nothing bad. Just gonna escort you and all this stuff back to Washington. You ain’t comin’ back by the way,” Blubs informed frankly. “Say, where’d the little guy g-Ow!” Blubs looked behind to find a dart sticking out of his behind. “Now how did-?”

“Youch!”

“Durland!?”

“He got me in the nose.”

“Well find him. He can’t have run far.”

“Who says I’m running?” Dipper intoned threateningly. On a table near the wall, he’d found himself a mini catapult. Beside it was a pile of darts that had fallen off of Durland. “Let us go, or the next one’s going right for the eye.”

“Yeah, Dipper! Show no mercy!”

“Gladly,” Blubs answered. The short fat guy grabbed a book and threw it towards Dipper, smashing the catapult. But just as the minizora jumped down in preparation for his next move, he’d landed right in Durland’s hand.

“You let my brother go right now, or I swear I’ll go Black Knight and bite your legs off!” snarled Mabel. Alas, her captors were not appreciative of the joke. It took several chains and a long stick with a hook before the cops felt safe enough to transport the little girl and her brother onto the train for their journey.

Dipper and Mabel were stowed away in a large wooden crate, along with the entrapped former president. Fortunately, Dipper had some old tools in his vest pocket and was able to unlock Mabel. Unfortunately, the box was sealed tight and the only hole in the wood was too small even for him.

“I can’t believe I left a trail of candy wrappers,” Mabel bemoaned, back to the wall as she slid down to the floor. “This is all my fault. Pacifica had me pegged all along. I’m just a failure like that-”

“Enough!” Dipper shouted, stomping his foot down. “I’m sick of you talking about yourself like this. Why do you let her get to you?”

“I-I don’t know. She just has this… way of getting under my skin.”

“Well stop it. You’re Mabel Pines, remember. Your silliness got us into this mess, maybe it can get us out.”

“How would that work?” Mabel demanded, staring down at her tiny brother as she absentmindedly ripped a chunk off of the presidential block, trying to drown her misery in sweets. In so doing, she set off a chain reaction that set the whole thing to crumble. With the block now in shambles, the perfectly preserved man inside finally spoke.

“‘Tis I, Quintin Trembley!” And then he ripped off his pants in an impressive show of strength, leaving only his pantaloons.

“Ha! Told you,” Dipper declared his vindication, once more reciting all the silly things Mabel had done to get them this far. “You’re not silly. You’re brilliant! Just like this guy with no pants.”

“I’m as smart as a pantsless president!”

From there, the two brilliantly silly people contrived an exquisitely silly plan of fitting through the tiny hole. It didn’t work, but somehow it did cause the crate to collapse around them, which was also good. Afterwards, following a brief chase on the top of the train, Dipper managed to convince the cops that Quentin Trembley was still technically the president, who then ordered them to forget that any of this ever happened. Dipper then amended that the cops should actually report that the kids were a false alarm and Blubs was the one who really solved the case. Unfortunately, Trembley had been reduced to dust and there wasn’t anything to send back. Most of the papers, however, would have to continue on their journey, though Dipper did snag a few of the juicier secrets for himself on the way out.

The three returned to Gravity Falls, chatting the whole way as Trembley revealed a few more embarrassing secrets about the other presidents. But as a reward for their services, Mabel was appointed as a congressman, complete with a fancy top hat. Dipper was offered some supportive words for his efforts in uncovering the deeper secrets of the town, along with a limited edition negative 12 dollar bill and the Presidential Key.

Upon seeing Pacifica, Mabel gave the girl a low-key heart attack when she ran over. Luckily, it was just so that she could brag about her amazingly implausible adventures and not because she was going to take revenge for her Grunkle. Alas, Pacifica wasn’t buying it and promptly dismissed Mabel, sparing a brief glance towards Dipper as she huffed away.

Dipper was not amused. “Aren’t you going to tell her about her great-great grandpa?”

“You know what, Dipper. I’ve got nothing to prove. With your help, I’ve learned that being silly is awesome.” And she slipped her sweater back onto its rightful place.

“Well I haven’t learned anything,” Dipper huffed. Pulling out his smartphone, he quickly logged into his favorite conspiracy website and uploaded photos he’d taken regarding the Northwests. It took the internet practically no time to go viral with the story. “Hey Pacifica!” He whistled for her car to stop. “Check SecretConspiracies.com. Nathaniel didn’t found Gravity Falls and your whole family’s a sham. Deal with it!”

It took only a second for the blonde girl to check her own phone and cry out in alarm. “What!? Mom, dad!”

Dipper, meanwhile, was in awe of what he’d just done. “Man, revenge is underrated. That felt awesome!”

“Thanks for looking out for me, bro-bro.” Mabel picked up the minizora and planted a big wet kiss on his cheek. “I can always trust you to have my back.”

Next episode?
See what else there is to enjoy on Pioneer Day?
Return to the Shack for some 'relaxation'?
12131211111111111111111111111111111.title: Irrational Treasure

121312111111111111111111111111111111.content:
With the dance being such a financial success, Grunkle Stan decided to take things to the next level. It was, in his proud words, the cheapest fair money could rent. While he oversaw most of the work, including the rigging of certain attractions, he tasked the twins with slapping fake safety certificates on anything that looked too dangerous.

12 o’clock rolled around and Stan was living it up in the dunk tank. He was shouting at everyone who got near, pointing out their various physical flaws and making himself nice and hateable. Everyone bought balls to try and dunk the jerk, but the target was rigged to be effectively immovable, barring some supernatural phenomenon. Still, Stan was making a considerable profit from hurling insults at people, and couldn’t be happier for it.

Dipper, meanwhile, had graduated to hand-holding with Wendy… sort of. They were now comfortable enough with each other for her to carry him around in her hand. Her open palm was pretty steady, calloused from hard work, but overall soft. It was nice.

“And then he threw the book at me.”

Wendy snickered, holding her question mark shaped treat in the other hand. “What, like locked you up?”

“No. First, he threw an actual book at me. I was too dangerous with that catapult,” Dipper boasted. “That’s when they caught me, and then I was locked up.”

Wendy shook her head and wiped away a couple of tears. “You’re a riot, little man. You know, you should write all this down. It’d make a great story.”

“You think so?”

“Yeah, totally. Going on all these adventures with all the supernatural stuff in town. I know I’d get a kick out of it. Just one thing, though.” Wendy’s smile shrunk a tad. “For real, though. Did all this stuff really happen, or are you just weavin’ a yarn?” she asked in imitation of her mother’s accent.

Dipper shrugged nonchalantly. “Eh, who can say? Multibears and presidents encased in peanut brittle? That stuff’s about as silly as ghosts in a convenience store, and who’d ever believe that?”

Wendy’s eyes widened and she laughed nervously. “Heh-heh, sure.” Suddenly feeling awkward, she was relieved when her snack dripped on her shirt sleeve. “Ah, boo. I’ll be right back.” She set him down on the ground near a booth and went to get cleaned up. Once she found the wipes, she took a bit too long as she thought things over. “He can’t be serious, can he?” she muttered to herself. “I mean, dad always had those stories, but they’re just stories, right? They can’t be real. Then again, I did see ghosts with my own two eyes, so if they’re real, then…” She slapped herself. “No, stop it, Wendy! You can’t think about it like that. He’s just a nice guy telling stories to make you laugh.” She blinked upon recalling an awful truth. “… exactly how dad started with mom.”

Wendy’s mom never got tired of telling the story of how she met up with her husband. He was as much a muscle head back in high school as today and she’d initially dismissed him as beneath her. She’d only gone out with him on a dare, but then he saved her after an unfortunate encounter with a mugger; unfortunate for the mugger, who was hospitalized for six months after having a whole car engine surgically removed. She gave him a real chance after that and started listening to what he had to say. The more she listened, the more she wanted to hear. And when he proved just as good a listener, it was inevitable that things got physical.

Wendy usually tuned her mother out around that point, or at least tried to, but none of that was relevant now. “Me and Dipper are just friends who liked to talk. I talk with all my friends. It’s no big deal,” she rationalized. “Except, is he being serious when he talks about all these adventures? Did he really face down monsters, showing off the same machismo that dad-” *Fwack* “Nope!” She slapped herself again. “Don’t go there, brain.”

Over at the concession stand, Mabel had moseyed up to her little brother with two hands full of cotton candy. “Look at you two, being all romantic at the fair.”

“I know. Isn’t’ this amazing. I just dove in. I said ‘Hey, want to hang out at the fair?’ and she was like, ‘Sure.’ It totally worked. All your advice about just going for it. It’s finally paying off.”

Mabel shook her head with a self-satisfied smirk. “When are you going to learn, Dipper? I’m always right about everything.” Then she frowned. “Hey, do you smell a gallon of body spray?”

Robbie showed up, looking as forcefully indifferent as ever. “Hey, you dorks seen Wendy? I got some super tight jeans and thought she’d wanna check ‘em out.” He planted his foot on a box and started flexing to the disgust of the preteens.

“Hey, yeah. I think I saw her in the Bottomless Pit. You should really go jump in there,” Dipper offered helpfully.

“Maybe I will, smart guy,” Robbie sneered. The teen looked like he was about to step on the minizora, but one look at Mabel’s death glower made him realize that he liked living too much and he turned away.

“That guy’s a jerk.”

“Yeah, but he’s a jerk with tight pants and a guitar. I need to keep him away from Wendy at all costs,” Dipper reasoned.

Mabel nodded. “Yeah. All you’ve got are smarts, cutes, body odor that can’t be smelled a mile away, and a loincloth. You don’t stand a chance,” she teased.

“Mabel!”

“Take it easy there, bro-bro. Whatever happens, I’ll be right here. Supporting you every step of the-Oh my gosh a pig!” And just like that, the little girl ran off to the booth that was giving out pigs, leaving her littler brother alone.

Dipper was fine, though. He hooked back up with Wendy shortly after as she carried him over to one of the prize booths.

“Whoa, check it out. I don’t know if it’s a duck or a pig, but I want one.”

“Then I’ll win it for you.”

“That’s really sweet, dude, but these things aren’t exactly minizora friendly.” Wendy gestured to the balls that were bigger than him.

“Don’t worry. My uncle taught me the secret to these things. You aim for the carny’s head and then take the prize when he’s unconscious.”

“Hehe. Nice. Alright then.” She set him on the counter. “Give it a shot.” She didn’t think he could actually do it, but it seemed too mean to deny him the chance.

What Wendy didn’t know was that there was this trick for minizora that Dipper had found online and been practicing ever since he heard about the fair. By stretching his muscles in just the right way, he could create a bungie effect that could easily meet carny standards. He just had to get his aim down. However, what Dipper didn’t know was that this was a fixed point in the timeline. Specifically, this was the point that causality decided to dick around with him and Wendy. So when he threw the ball, it ricocheted back and smacked her right in the face.

“Agh! My eye!” It had swollen to an awful shade of purple.

Mortified beyond rational thought, Dipper ran off to fetch some ice. On the way back, some bald fat guy in a gray jumpsuit tripped over the ice and about crushed the minizora beneath his big fat butt. By the time the jerk regained enough sense to flee the scene; it was already too late as Dipper beheld the horror.

“Robbie, thanks. That’s really sweet. The gesture and the flavored syrup,” Wendy said as he pressed the frozen treat against her eye. But when he popped the question and asked her to go out, she answered far quicker than she’d ever done before. She’d had a number of boyfriends and liked Robbie fine, but deep down this seemed like the perfect out. If she had an actual boyfriend, then maybe her mind would stop drifting to those fantasies about tiny people.

Mabel came up to Dipper, overflowing with joy at the chance to show off her new pet Waddles. When Dipper gave no response, it didn’t take a rocket scientist to figure out what had gone wrong. “Oh,” she said while watching the teens run off together.
121312111111111111111111111111111111.title: At the Fair

choices: Get Wendy to Get the Pig
1213121111111111111111111111111111111.content:
The rest of the fair day was spent with mournful sighs as Dipper hardly even moved. Mabel tried everything from tickling, to funny sounds, and even dressing Waddles up in cute costumes that she already owned for some reason.

“Mabel, do you ever wish you could go back and undo just one mistake?”

“Come on, bro. We could solve this in ten seconds flat if you just let me break the guy’s legs,” Mabel stated frankly as she played with Waddles. Alas, she was being ignored.

“I mean Wendy only went out with Robbie because he had the ice,” rambled the minizora, “and she only needed ice because of the baseball, and I would have had the ice if it weren’t for… That guy!” Dipper pointed at the fat guy in the gray jumpsuit. “Hey you, tool belt. You ruined my life!” accused Dipper as he marched up to the oblivious man with Mabel close behind. “Hey, I’ve seen you before. Have you been following us around?”

Wanting to get in on this, Mabel added, “And why are you bald? What’s that all about?”

Stuttering something about a compromised position, the bald man fiddled with his watch and made his suit run through all kinds of bizarre colors and backgrounds. “Come on, stealth mode. Aw, dang it!” And he brought out a screwdriver to perform some adjustments.

“Wow, that’s amazing,” awed Mabel. “Are you from the future or something?”

The fat guy was starting to sweat. “Wh-what? No. Who told you that? Uh, memory wipe!” He threw a blue cloth at Mabel’s face.

“Did you just throw a baby wipe at me?” Mabel asked, more surprised by the absurdity than angered.

The man finally caved and spilled all his secrets. His name was Blendin Blandin, a time traveler from the year twenty shneventy twelve. His mission was to stop a number of time anomalies that were centered around this time and place, but he’d yet to find any. When the twins professed skepticism, he demonstrated how to use his time traveling measuring tape by disappearing and reappearing in a completely new set of clothes. Ultimately, the poor guy seemed awful tired, so Dipper suggested that he take a break and enjoy some rides at the fair. Mabel even gave him her remaining tickets. The twins shared a knowing look as Blendin stripped off his belt and got onto a ride.

“Grunkle Stan would be proud of us,” Mabel snickered as she pilfered the tape.

Back in the Shack’s dining room, the pair awed at the item that sat on the table before them.

“This is it, Mabel, our ticket to any moment in history.”

“Let’s go get two dodos and force them to make out.”

“What? No.”

“Then let’s go get some cute and tiny dinosaurs just before they die, force them to make out, and then we can have an army of adorable ancient lizards!”

“Nnn-maybe,” Dipper allowed. “Let’s just do something small for starters. Like, for example, going back and fixing my baseball throw.”

“Great idea! Oh, and I can come too. That way I can relive the greatest moment of my life. Winning Waddles.” She kissed the pig on the head and shot Dipper a coy look. “Jealous?”

The minizora rolled his eyes. “Let’s just get this over with.”

The time was rolled back by six hours. Perfect. Mabel re-won Waddles in no time flat and, just for kicks, admitted to the carny that she was a witch before he could even ask. Dipper, however, wasn’t so lucky. The ball hit Wendy in the eye all over again and Robbie appeared to comfort her. Although he wondered if time might conspire to undo new outcomes, Dipper reasoned that all he really needed was to try again. So he did, and hit her in the eye. He tried again and again, changing every variable he could think of. Half the time he hit the milk bottles, a few times he hit the carny, but the end result was always the same with Wendy taking a baseball to the face; except for that one time where time decided to be extra dickish and pelt her with a whole sack full of balls. One time the ball knocked him into Wendy’s cleavage, which was almost the best possible outcome, if it didn’t somehow hit her eye a split second later.

As Dipper ran through the math, he realized that what he was missing was help. If he could just enlist Mabel to be in the right place at the right time, then he’d be golden. In a good mood after more than a dozen wins with Waddles, she was fully onboard, confident that another win was in the stars for her. It worked! Dipper finally won the stuffed creature of indeterminate species without injuring Wendy. Granted, also ending up in her cleavage would have been a nice bonus, but this was still acceptable, especially now that Robbie lost his chance to ask Wendy out.

Dipper went on a few rides with Wendy, just enjoying himself as he sat in her hand, when Mabel came up screaming. “Hey, what’s-?”

“Ahh!”

“Uh-”

“Ahh!”

“Are you-?”

“Ahhhhh!”

Dipper and Wendy waited until Mabel finally calmed before trying again. “What’s wrong?”

“We messed up the timeline. Pacifica saw the flyer and won Waddles before I could. She took Waddles, Dipper!”

“Timeline?” questioned Wendy.

“Oh, that’s, uh, nothing.” Dipper motioned for Wendy to set him on Mabel’s shoulder. “Hey, I’m real sorry about that.”

“It’s okay.” Mabel then took the time tape out of Dipper’s vest pocket. “We just have to go back in time and do things-”

“Mabel, no!” Dipper took the tape back.

“Uh, does someone want to catch me up here, cuz I think I missed a step,” admitted Wendy. “Timeline? Going back? And who’s Waddles?”

“He’s my new pet pig,” Mabel cried, too distressed to think as Dipper urged her to hush. “Or at least he was supposed to be. We keep redoing the day and I’ve won him, like, twenty times. But now he’s gone and I gotta get him back.”

Wendy blinked and then fixed her gaze on the measuring tape. “Okay. Maybe there was something in the food I ate, cuz it sounds like you guys are talking about time travel.”

Dipper laughed nervously. “Wh-what? That-that’s silly. Don’t be silly, Wendy. Heh-heh.”

“Okay, my bullshit meter is going off like crazy. You two better start talking sense or… or else I’ll find Pacifica and take this pig for myself,” she threatened, shaking a fist for emphasis.

Mabel blinked. “Uh, yeah. I’d be fine with that. So long as you bring him right back to me.”

“Mabel, why didn’t you just beat up Pacifica and take Waddles yourself?” Dipper demanded.

“She had guards. Guards with tasers. You know I hate tasers. But with Wendy’s help…”

“What? Oh no, man. I’m not getting tased again. Not after last time. Ugh. Can you please just tell me what’s going on here?”

“Uh, can you give us a moment, please?” Dipper requested.

“Fine. One minute. But if I don’t get a straight answer, I’m chucking you both at the carny,” Wendy growled and stomped off.

“Why didn’t you just tell her we’ve got a time machine?” Mabel asked.

“Yeah? And tell her what? That I went back in time a bunch just to stop her from dating Robbie? Mabel, listen to me. I’ve done the math. In any other timeline, Wendy ends up going out with Robbie. I can’t mess this up.”

“But if we don’t go, then I’ll lose Waddles forever!”
1213121111111111111111111111111111111.title: Retry

12131211111111111111111111111111111111.content:
As expected of two siblings when tensions were running high, they started to quarrel. Dipper could be an evasive little scamp when he really put his mind to it. And in the scuffle, the tape was pulled out too far, sending the twins hurling through time. When everything stopped tasting purple, it appeared that they were on some dirt road in an unfamiliar wilderness.

“When are we?” Dipper asked, brushing himself off.

Mabel beamed at the chance to smart off. “The real question is ‘when’ are w-oh. Oh you already said it.”

“Yeah, same thing. Hey, do you hear that?”

“I feel that.” The twins turned to see an incoming stampede of buffalo. Screaming, Mabel grabbed Dipper and started running as fast as she could. She wasn’t watching where she was going and ended up off a cliff, and luckily right into a covered wagon full of settlers dressed like they were ready for Pioneer Day. In this case, a pregnant looking woman with a half dozen kids of varying ages.

“You sent us back 150 years, genius!” Dipper snapped, calming as he pinched the bridge of his nose.

Then one of the dirty children in the wagon approached and pointed. “Hey look, ma. She’s got one of them there tiny wingless fairies like what they got up in the cities.”

“Oh goodness!” said the woman, cheeks flushed. “Ah’ve heard about the… skills of you tiny folk. Might Ah interest you in stayin’ a while?”

Dipper blushed, too paralyzed to speak. While the other boys in the wagon looked curious, all of the ladies looked curious. Mabel’s grip on her brother grew possessively tight.

“Hey look, ma,” said that same kid. “That girl’s got silver in her mouth.”

“These are called braces.”

“Mabel, no! You can’t go messing with the past.”

Then Mabel remembered her wrath. “Oh, says the guy who’s spent all day messing with the past and cost me my pig? I’ll mess with whatever I want.” She pulled out a calculator and handed it to the dirty kid. “Check it out. A magic button machine. Shoes that blink.” She stomped on the floor, making them light up to the awe of the settlers. And after promising the women they could vote in the future, she even taught them to high five.

Dipper tried to steal the tape back, but mistyped a button and sent them too far back. Before they could get eaten by a dinosaur, Mabel pressed buttons wildly until they were sent (presumably) too far forward. The setting could only be described as post-apocalyptic with cities in ruins, twin moons, an eerie green hue over everything, laser blasts everywhere, and a giant floating baby with an hourglass on his head shooting eye beams and laughing at those who stood in his way. Dipper managed to get them back to the right century at least, but Mabel was on the run. Their connection to the time tape meant that they were always the same relative distance apart, no matter where or when they ended up. They ran past the day at the lake with the Gobblewonker, past the wax museum reopening, past the gnome incident, and several more events they didn’t recognize before ending up back at the Shack in a winter before the sign had gone up. The tape overheated and the pair disappeared in a flash of light, mere seconds before a man with a familiar face poked his head out the door to check on the noise.

When everything stopped spinning, the two stumbled their way out of a portapotty, gasping for fresh air. They were back in the ‘present’, specifically the one where Wendy got the prize and Pacifica got the pig. Dipper then immediately scaled up the potty out of his sister’s reach.

“Mabel, give it up. It’s over. I’ve worked too hard for this.”

“But what about Waddles?” she cried actual tears.

“What about me and Wendy? I thought you said you supported us.”

“I… I don’t know.” Head hung low and heart in tatters, Mabel went over to the totem and started thumping her head to it, mumbling Waddles every now and then.

“You’re not guilt-tripping me, Mabel,” Dipper intoned, though truthfully it tore him up to see her like this. “Come on, Mabel. You’re gonna forget about this in a day. In fact, I’ll prove it.” He pulled out the tape and traveled a day forward, finding most of the fair taken down but Mabel in the exact same spot. “Okay, maybe in a week.” He tried again to identical results. This was distressingly familiar. So he tried a month, finding her looking filthy with roots climbing up her legs. But then he saw something else. “Hey, Wendy.” He ran towards her, hoping to salvage this otherwise horrible outcome.

The redhead was heading for the Shack, likely to begin her shift, only for her mood to instantly sour when she saw who’d called her. “Oh, it’s you.”

The disgust in her tone killed Dipper’s momentum instantly. “Uh, hey Wendy. H-how’s it going?”

“You’re a real piece of work, you know that.”

“Huh?”

“Don’t you huh, me. You flake on me all summer and now you expect to talk like we’re friends again?”

“Again? You mean we’re… not, anymore?”

Wendy shook her head with a sneer. “Dude, just look at your sister. You honestly think I’d ever want to hang out with someone who’s that crappy to their own family?” She turned away in a huff. “I thought you were supposed to be better than that, but I guess I was wrong.”

“I…” Dipper tried to speak, tried to deny it, but she was already out of earshot. Sniffling and rubbing his eyes dry, he knew that there was only one choice to make. Pulling out the tape one last time, he returned to that fateful moment.

“Wendy, I just wanted to say that people make mistakes. And when they do, you should forgive them. Also, that tight pants are overrated.”

“Dude, you lost me.”

“I know,” Dipper conceded. Once more he went through the motions, barely even paying attention as he trusted the ball to find its mark. It did, and Robbie showed up to do his part as well. “It is done.” The minizora was then swiped off the table and pulled into a bone-breaking embrace.

“Dipper! Thank-you-thank-you-thank-you!” Mabel cheered as she swung him around, dancing in joy. When Waddles made pig noises, she added, “He’s saying ‘thank you’ in pig.”

“I couldn’t break your heart, Mabel,” Dipper assured, patting her cheek. “Plus it’s not like Robbie can date Wendy all summer, right?”

Then Blendin returned to swipe the tape back. “You two!” he accused. “Do you have any idea how many laws you just broke? I-I’m asking. I wasn’t there with you, but it was probably a lot,” he finished uncertainly.

That’s when a couple of jacked-up dudes in future armor appeared. They listed off the repercussions of the twins’ actions and set the blame squarely on Blendin, given that his machine had been used to travel to all affected time periods. They were deaf to Blendin’s rambling stuttering excuses, trying to pin the blame on Waddles of all people as he was dragged off to be arrested. Why they didn’t just flash away was anyone’s guess. They did, however, stick around long enough to be offended by Grunkle Stan, leading to the old man finally getting dunked after the target was incinerated. Everyone cheered.

The twins got an ice cream to split with Dipper riding on Mabel’s wrist and Waddles being carried beneath her other arm. After realizing that they might have caused the anomalies that Blendin had originally been sent to stop, Dipper’s mood was once more soured by the sight of Robbie sharing a caramel apple with Wendy. It didn’t take Mabel long to realize that this was a prime chance to be a good big sister and sick Waddles on the smelly emo. Waddles only got the apple, but purely by coincidence and not at all planned, Robbie backed up into a pot of hot water that spilled onto his tight pants, making them extra tight and constricting his sensitive bits. Once more, everyone laughed. Wendy even tried to cover her snickering at her new boyfriend’s expense.

Feeling just a bit better, Dipper went over to Waddles while he nibbled on the apple and scratched him behind the ears. “That’ll do, pig. That’ll do.”

Waddles squealed happily and leaned appreciatively into the scratching.
12131211111111111111111111111111111111.title: Time Traveler's Pig

121312111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
After all the money he’d just made, Stan was in a good mood and so was easily swayed into keeping Waddles. The porker was already house trained, but still had to stay in the laundry room at night. And while Mabel had every intention of sneaking him up to her room now and then, tonight would not be one of those nights.

“So, bro-bro. Like what you see?” Having deposited Dipper onto her bed, Mabel leaned back against the headboard with her legs spread wide. She’d stripped down to just her undies, leaving basically nothing to the imagination.

Still fully dressed, Dipper swallowed.

“You did a really great thing today, so I figured you earned some big sis lovin’, which is where I come in,” Mabel explained giddily. “Tonight, it’s anything you want.”

Dipper smirked, accepting the challenge. “You and Wendy making out and using me as a double dildo.”
