1213121111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
As it turned out, the people of Gravity Falls loved Halloween so much that they celebrated it twice a year. With Summerween upon them, the twins were initially uncertain. Halloween in the summer just seemed unnatural. They got over their reservations as soon as Soos reminded them of the free candy.

The local shopping center was decked out in seasonal decorations like plastic skeletons, plastic bats, fake tombstones for sale, and all the fake blood anyone could ever need. Dipper and Mabel were having a time in the costume isle.

“Hmm. Something sweet, or scary?” Mabel asked, choosing between the cupcake and the slasher killer with the hockey mask. “Sweet or scary? Scary or sweet? So many decisions.”

Dipper huffed his disappointment at the lack of costumes his size.

“Hey, don’t be down. Mom’s not here, but I’ve been helping her make your costumes for years.” Mabel beamed and added, “You’re like my very own dress up doll.”

“Yeah, yeah,” Dipper sighed and pushed her finger away. “But if we’re gonna coordinate, then we need something with a second half. Slasher killers are all solo acts.”

“Oh, how about that?” Mabel pointed to a creepy doll covered in scars. “I could stick my finger up your butt and make you my evil ventriloquist dummy.”

“Mabel, be serious.”

“Dipper,” she deadpanned. “I’m always serious when it comes to butts. Always!” She turned her attention back to the costumes. “We could do PB&J, but that be too uneven. People might ask questions instead of giving us candy.”

With Mabel in shopping mode, Dipper descended down her body to the floor to do a little shopping of his own. He had no money, but it was still nice to look at things at his own pace and pretend like he could buy them. Then, after heading down a few isles, suddenly the ground left him behind as he was hoisted into the air by an unfamiliar hand.

“Goodness, well look at you!” Gushed the strange woman. She had an east coast accent, probably a tourist, fat, maybe late thirties, with hair cut in what would someday be known as the Karen style, and gaudy clothes to match. “Ain’t you just the cutest little dolly.”

Dipper struggled to free himself, but she had a death grip on him. “Lady, put me down. I’m a minizora, not a doll!”

“Oh my. A… talking dolly?” she gasped in faux shock. “Well, you’re just the best souvenir I could hope for.”

“Excuse me?” Dipper asked, more shocked by her audacity than afraid.

“All the brochures played this town up like some big deal, but it’s been disappointment after disappointment. And after that brute busted my car, the least I’m owed is a little sweetie like you to keep me company.”

“Uh, lady, you know this is kidnapping, right?”

She scoffed dismissively. “Kidnapping only applies to people, sweetie. And since you don’t have a barcode, that makes you free merchandise. My favorite.” She tittered like she thought she was clever. “I think I’ll keep you in my underwear drawer. Pull you out on those cold, lonely nights. If you’re good, I might even feed you.” She tittered again as she brazenly slipped a few fingers into the front of her pants for her captive to watch.

Just as Dipper was about to scream out, the woman covered his mouth with her thumb.

“Ah-ah, sweetie. No need to be making a ruckus. You’re mine now.” Then a hand appeared on Karen’s shoulder.

“Excuse me, but Ah believe ya were asked ta put the boy down.”

Karen spun around to see who had dared to touch her, adopting a haughty smirk like she owned the place. She was totally unimpressed by this younger woman’s perkier tits, clothes that hugged her trim figure just right, pert buttocks, and a face that wasn’t wrinkled from a lifetime of frowning. “And who are you supposed to be?”

“Mrs. Corduroy,” Dipper called after briefly wiggling free, only to be silenced again.

“Please, call me Sheela,” Wendy’s mom said with a smile to Dipper. That smile turned blood curdling when she switched to Karen. “Ya’ll can call me Shiva, Destroyer ‘f Worlds fer all Ah care. Jus’ hand the boy over ‘n’ things don’t have ta get messy.”

Karen, unused to such remarks, foolishly stood her ground. “Excuse me, but are you the manager here? Because if you aren’t, then you have no right to tell me what I can and can’t do with my purchases.”

Sheela made a sound of understanding. “Oh, Ah see. So Ah’m dealing with this level of stupid today. Well fine. Ah’ll try to put this in words you’ll understand. Put the boy down, or else.” For the briefest second, it almost looked like her eyes glowed red.

“Uh, ma’am, I think we might have gotten off on the wrong foot,” Karen said hesitantly. She was finally sensing the danger she was in, though not the direction it was coming from. “This poor thing is called a minizernum. He’s mine, you see. He’s just throwing a little tantrum. Chronic liar, you see. I just need to get him home and put him to bed. He always feels better after a nap.”

Sheela Corduroy just stood there, arms folded under her ample chest and looking thoroughly unamused. “Now Ah’m insulted that ya think Ah’m that stupid.” She extended her hand. “This is yer last chance. Hand over the boy, or Ah can’t be held responsible fer what’ll happen.”

Karen sneered and pulled Dipper close to her chest. “Oh please. If you lay one finger on me, I’ll call the police and have you arrested. You can’t do a damn thing.” Her smirk was triumphant and punchable.

“Oh, Ah know,” Sheela agreed, resigned to the inevitable. “Ah gave ya’ll fair warnin’, so now Ah’m jus’ gonna stand here ‘n’ watch her get busy.” She gestured behind Karen.

Before Karen could inquire further, it was like the whole isle dropped fifty degrees. The overweight woman brought her hands up to heat them with her breath. Her breath was visible. That’s when Karen became aware of a presence behind her. Despite growing up in the luxuries of the suburbs, her inner animal finally awoke to the sensation of being hunted. She was being hunted by a predator.

The predator was short, scrawny, with long hair and dressed like an adorable cupcake. Its hair flailed about like it was enchanted. In the now flickering florescent light, the predator’s teeth had an eerie glow and her eyes seemed to have no pupils, yet there was no question where her death glare was fixed.

Karen spun around, turning her back on Sheela. “H-hey you. D-don’t you come near me.”

The predator gave a long exhale, sending forth a white cloud that froze Karen’s shoes to the floor.

Sheela once more extended her hand into Karen’s line of sight. “The boy,” she said expectantly. “Last chance.”

“F-f-fine! Here.” Karen roughly slapped Dipper into Sheela’s hand. “Stupid tiny. Too ugly for my liking, anyway.”

Sheela snorted a surprised laugh as she tenderly comforted Dipper. “Wow. Ya know, the Darwin Award ain’t actually a competition, honey.”

Karen just looked at the other woman in a perpetual sneer. “What are you ta-?”

A thunderous roar shook through the isles. It was like an earthquake, shaking merchandise right off the shelves and causing most shoppers to fall. Karen only barely held her footing when she saw the beast charging for her, mouth open in a lust for blood.

Sheela, deciding to be merciful, turned Dipper away from the carnage. She smiled sweetly down at him, petting his tiny shivering body. “Well howdy there, cutie. Havin’ a rough Summerween?”

“Uh, a little,” Dipper said distractedly, fighting with all his might not to stare at the woman’s perfect boobs.

“Well don’t you worry none. Ya’ll’ve been in Gravity Falls long enough that folks recognize ya as one of our own. We ain’t like them entitled twats.”

Dipper snickered, once more getting sucked into the black hole that was Sheela’s fantastic chest. “Yeah. You guys are… nice.”

“You ain’t half bad yerself, sweetie. Ohh, Ah could jus’ eat ya’ll up.”

There came a throat clearing. Down below, Mabel was looking up with her hand held out expectantly. Her rage state had passed, but her vacant expression showed that she was still very stressed and needed her comfort object returned. As for Karen, well, Mabel was just a kid who’d acted in self-defense. It was probably fine.

Being the good and lovely neighbor she was, Sheela returned Dipper to his sister, making her spring back with light and life. Cordial greetings were exchanged and, in gratitude for her service, Mabel agreed to loan Dipper out to Sheela whenever she asked.

***

“Okay, I was sensing some bullshit for a while, but I draw the line at that last part,” asserted Wendy. “Ain’t no way Mabel would ever agree to that.”

Sheela giggled at her daughter’s reaction as she arranged the decorations for the house. “Yer free ta think what ya want, but Ah’m telling ya, that’s exactly how it happened.” She faced her daughter and pushed her boobs up. “Boy couldn’t tear his eyes off me.”

Wendy turned away with a blush.

“Aww, don’t be down. There’s no need to be jealous. After all, with yer genes, you’ll look at least this good in a few more years.”

Mabel was having a blast preparing for Summerween, though she still wasn’t ready to let go of Dipper just yet. The less said about that incident at the store, the better, but suffice to say that everyone got exactly what they deserved. “I’m so excited!”

“We’re gonna have the best costumes, get the most candy,” Dipper listed.

“And have the biggest stomach aches ever!”

“Dude, I’ve never seen you guys so pumped,” commented Soos in his luchador costume.

“Well, back home, me and Dipper were kind of the kings of trick or treating,” Mabel humbly bragged and pulled out a photo album to show Soos. “Twins in costumes. The people eat it up.”

Soos, however, was wary. After turning off the lights and shining a flashlight under his chin for atmosphere, he told the kids about the Summerween Trickster. It was the local legend of a creature that eats children who lack the Summerween spirit.

“Is that true?” Mabel asked of her shoulder boy.

Dipper pulled out the journal. “Hmm. I’m not seeing anything here, but this is number 3. The author could have written about it in one of the first two, but I don’t think we should worry.”

“Yeah! We’ve got spirit out the wazoo! Whatever that is.” After popping a sweet in her mouth, Mabel unwrapped one for Dipper and he started coughing.

“Ugh! What is this stuff? I’ve never even heard of these brands. Gummy chairs?”

“Huh. I never thought anything gummy could ever not be appetizing, but there it is,” Mabel observed. “This is all cheapo loser candy.”

“Quiet your discontent, children,” Soos warned. “Lest the Trickster overhear.”

“Oh right. Um, wow, this candy is sooo good,” Dipper loudly called. Sitting on Mabel’s shoulder, he tapped at her neck.

“Huh? Oh. Yeah. I just love-love-love it!” Smiling, she stood and carried the bowl to the outside trash.

“Yup. It’s sooo good, we’re gonna be extra nice and share it with the raccoons. Because that’s the spirited thing to do,” announced Dipper as he watched the bowl be dumped of its undesirable contents. “There,” he said in a more regular voice. “That should keep the Trickster satisfied.”

“Whoa, dudes. Most kids I tell this story to just laugh it off. You dudes are pretty serious.”

“Soos, after the stuff we’ve seen in just the last month, I’m starting to disbelieve in the concept of fiction.”

“Huh?”

“It means he thinks all fantasy stories are actually real.”

“At least in Gravity Falls,” Dipper amended.

The twins went back to work putting the finishing touches on the Shack while the TV played in the background. It was some fluff piece about the latest celebrity gossip. Specifically, well-endowed actress Britney Javelin was walking around with her minizora boyfriend, Timothy Corvette, wedged between her boobs. The little guy was smiling and waving to the paparazzi, looking very snug and comfortable. His transport was absolutely eating up all the attention, posing for the cameras, and even messing with Timothy by playing with her boobs. It was like she was sending a message to all the women of the world, saying: ‘Look at me. I’ve got perfect tits that can please a minizora. What do you have?’ Mabel tried to keep busy with her work, but her eyes kept returning to the screen as her thoughts ran wild.

The doorbell rang and Stan instructed whoever to give them the terrible candy.

“Think I can do this on my own?”

Mabel frowned. “Well, okay, but I’m taking a sniper position on the roof.”

“Whatever makes you happy, sis.” Dipper patted her cheek and was let down. The bowl was placed on the skateboard for easy transport and a minizora button by the door opened it for Dipper’s convenience. “Happy Summerw-whoa!”

“‘Sup, squirt,” Robbie grumbled, having traded his usual broken heart hoodie for a skeleton one.

“Hey, Dipper,” Wendy greeted more warmly. Her hair was braided and she wore a tie-dye shirt and skirt, looking right out of Woodstock. “Like my costume. Mom picked it out for me.”

Dipper’s insides clenched. “Oh, heh-heh, yeah. She’s, uh, g-got good taste.”

“Wanna guess what I am?” invited Wendy. “A lazy, good-for-nothing leech on society with terrible taste in music.”

“Oh. I was going to say hippy, but I guess your way is more accurate.”

Wendy laughed. “Yeah. We just came by cuz I forgot my jacket, again,” she added in annoyance.

“What’s with the candy?” asked a resentful Robbie. “You going trick or treating or something?”

Dipper frowned. “Uh, it’s in a bowl, like the kind you give out to trick or treaters.”

“Yeah, Robbie. Of course, he’s not going out trick or treating,” Wendy added after retrieving her jacket.

Dipper felt his insides clench and his pits grow sweaty. “Um, yeah. T-trick or treating is for babies,” he agreed with a nervous laugh.

“You should come to this party with us. Tambry’s parents are out of town and it’s gonna be off the chain!” Wendy deepened her voice for that last part.

“Not surprised you didn’t hear about it,” Robbie said, dropping the flyer haphazardly over Dipper.

By the time the minizora pulled himself free, the couple had left. He quickly read through all the details, pausing briefly on the provocatively posed witch stickers, and found that the party began at nine. He carried the flyer and raced out to catch up with the pair. “Hey, uh, maybe I’ll see you there.”

“Yeah, if your sister’ll let you,” Robbie grumbled, earning an elbow to the shoulder.

“It’s at nine,” Wendy called as they drove off. “Don’t forget.”

As Dipper turned back to the flyer, studying its suggestive implications and contemplating his choice, a shadow eclipsed him.

“What’s at nine?” Mabel asked innocently.

“M-Mabel!” Dipper jumped. “What are you doing here?”

Casually she scooped her brother up in her open palm, carrying the flyer along for the ride. “I couldn’t get a good shot at Robbie with Wendy in the way, but it sounded like something was going on at nine.” When Dipper seemed reluctant to answer, Mabel finally took notice of the flyer and read. “This looks like a party.” She leveled a flat stare at him. “Did you agree to go to a party?”

“Maybe!” Dipper stressed. “I said maybe. You know, maybe, after we do our trick or treating, we could swing by the party.”

Still holding her brother in her open palm, Mabel folded her arms and tapped her foot impatiently. “Dipper.”

“Sorry! I’m sorry. It’s just Wendy was there, and Robbie, and she said, of course, I wasn’t trick or treating, and then-mmh!”

Mabel pressed her thumb to Dipper’s mouth. He could pull away whenever he wanted, but he took the cue to shut up. The big sister sighed her disappointment and then fixed her brother with a firm look. “Trick or treating first. Party second.”

Dipper’s expression lit up. “Y-yes! Yes, of course!” He hugged Mabel’s thumb. “Thank-you-thank-you-thank-you. You’re the best sister ever!”

Mabel giggled. “Yeah, I know. Now let’s get changed. It’s gonna be a looong night.”

I’m afraid he’s got some,” she snickered, “important meetings to attend.” On cue, the pig walked in with a little business suit hanging around his neck. Mabel squealed. “You guys are gonna love Dipper’s costume. It’s literally the sweetest thing ever.”

“Wanna bet.” When the others looked around, unable to spot him, Dipper whistled to call their attention to Mabel’s head. There he climbed out from his hiding spot and stood tall, dressed as a big old cherry and striking a proud pose. “Feast your eyes, ladies.”

Candy and Grenda were not prepared for such adorableness and each suffered an explosion of estrogen. Candy grabbed at her chest, seized up, and fell backward. Grenda, meanwhile, started moaning like a zombie and reached out for Dipper. “Must. Have. Cherry.”

“Hey, back off sister.” Mabel pushed Grenda back. “No touchy my Dippy.”

Grenda shook her head and started looking around like she’d just woken up. “Where’d I go just now?”

“Mabel, I think we might’ve gone overboard this year,” Dipper said in worry. “Twins as an ice cream sundae with a cherry on top? This is not a power that man was meant to wield.” He silently congratulated himself for saying all that with a straight face.

“Help,” wheezed Candy.

“Pssh. Screw that. I’m no man, and I say we use this power to conquer Summerween and take all the candy for ourselves! Mwahahaha!”

Then there came a knock at the door.

“I got it.” Dipper got down and prepared the candy bowl while Mabel ran defense against the girls and Waddles. Upon opening the door, Dipper beheld a freakishly tall man in rags, a pointed hat, a creepy smiling mask, skin so dark it was almost purple, and a disgustingly sweet smell.

“Trick… or treat,” intoned the wheezing man ominously.

“Oh shit!” Dipper couldn’t press the door button fast enough, causing it to slam shut. For what it was worth, he even put his hands on the door to keep it closed. “Grenda, help me!”

“On it, cutie,” agreed the big girl as she helped block the door, not questioning why.

“Dipper, what’s gotten into you?”

“The Trickster, Mabel! That was the Summerween Trickster. We can’t let him in!”

The local girls all looked worried at the mention of the legend and even Candy finally got up. “The Trickster is real?”

“Everything’s real in Gravity Falls!” Dipper stressed. “How do you people not-” He was cut off by a more urgent knocking at the door. “Ahh! He’s found us! Maybe he operates on vampire rules and can’t come in unless he’s invited.”

“Dipper, calm down,” assured Mabel. “Soos said he only eats kids who lack the Summerween spirit, and look at us. We’re all in costume, minutes away from a fun night on the town, and you’re so scared you look like you might pee your cherry. How much more Summerweeny could we get?”

The others exchanged looks, slowly surrendering to Mabel’s reasoning.

“Look, just step aside and I’ll deal with it.” Mabel shooed the others aside and threw the door open wide with her biggest and happiest grin. “Hello, friend. Me and my homies were just about to have a night of fun with-”

“SILENCE!” boomed the Trickster. “You have insulted me. And for this, you must pay… with your lives.”

Mabel blinked and tried shifting to a happier face. “Oh, I get it. You’re joking. Obviously, we’re already at peak Summerween spirit. You’re a funny guy, Mr. Trickster.”

“Funny, am I?” the Trickster wheezed, stepping inside and voiding Dipper’s vampire theory. Then, just to prove that he was a mean spirited dick with no concern for even his own rules, the Trickster gobbled up some random kid in a pirate costume who’d just walked up. “There’s only one way for you to avoid his fate,” intoned the Trickster as he reached out with his creepy long fingers and made the children back up. “I neeed a treat. If you can collect 500 pieces of candy, and bring them to me before the last jackomellon goes out,” he produced one from his shirt, lit a flame within with his thumb, and blew it out, “I will let you live.”

“Why are you doing this?” Dipper demanded, stepping forward. “We’re in costume. We were going to trick or treat just fine on our own. What’s your deal?”

“Aside from your rudeness, which is reason enough, one of you lacks the Summerween spirit.” Through his mask he looked upon the guilty child, making their stomach sink in dread. “Though at this point, it hardly matters. You have a choice, children. You must trick or treat… or die.” He jumped high in the air, crawling like a squirrel over the roof before disappearing into the night.

“What-do-we-do!?” Grenda screamed.

“Hey, guys, what’s goin’ on out here?” asked Soos. “I heard a ruckus. Haha. That’s a funny word.”

“Soos, I don’t know what we did wrong, but we pissed off the Trickster, and now he’s making us trick or treat or he’s gonna eat us,” summarized Dipper.

“I got a picture.” Candy showed Soos with her flip phone.

“Oh man, dude. You guys are in crazy bonkers trouble.”

“Wait, let’s think this through rationally,” Dipper began. “He just wants the candy, right? There’s still a bunch in the bowl. If we also get some from your parents,” he gestured between Candy and Grenda, “then that’ll give us enough of a head start to-”

*Quessh*

“Ahh!” Dipper jumped back from the impact sight.

“Dipper!” Mabel picked him up, holding him tight as they all examined what had almost squished him. “Is that… a jackomellon?”

“Looks like the Trickster’s picky about where he gets his candy from,” deduced Soos as they all looked around for where the projectile might have come from. “Sorry dudes, but you’re playing on hard mode.”

Mabel clapped to draw all eyes back on her. “Listen up, people. Now some might say that being cursed by a bloodthirsty holiday monster is a bad thing.”

“I wet myself,” affirmed Grenda.

“But that monster messed with the wrong crew. With Candy’s spirit, Grenda’s strength, Dipper’s smarts, and… Soos, we’ll get 500 pieces of candy and have fun doing it too, even if it takes us all night!” Everyone cheered as Mabel led the charge to Soos’ truck.

Dipper, however, was less enthusiastic. “All night? Are you sure?”

“Of course, I’m sure. Why wouldn’t I be?” Then Mabel’s smile flipped. “You’re not seriously thinking about the party, are you?”

“What? Me? No, of course not. I mean, obviously trick or treat or die takes priority. Can’t go to the party if I’m dead,” Dipper laughed nervously and rubbed his elbow. “But, you know, if there’s time…”

Mabel waved dismissively. “Yeah, yeah, whatever. Maybe. Now let’s go!” She threw her fist up to signal the charge. “For candy!”

With the youngsters gone, Stan was left to entertain himself by scaring the piss out of any who dared approach the Shack.

Who do we follow?
1213121111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Tricksters

1213121111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Out in town, kids and a handful of parents were having a night of demanding sweets from strangers. Manly Dan looked to be having a lot of fun dressed as a Viking and leading his sons into ‘battle’. Even the cops had dressed up as each other. But there was one group who was especially motivated to get them some candy.

The first house was Lazy Susan. She was dressed as a ball of yarn and covered in cats, but oblivious to the self-deprecating joke. She went down the line to make sure everyone was in costume. “Chimney sweep, elephant man, squeegee, a pile of snot,” Mabel’s eye twitched, “and… what are you supposed to be?”

Dipper frowned. “I’m a cherry. You know, like the kind that goes on an ice cream sundae.”

“And I’m the sundae. Just so we’re clear.”

“Looks more like snot with a zit to me, but whatever.” Lazy Susan then gave each of them a single piece of what they all agreed to be loser candy.

“Great. Our first house of the night is the sucky kind,” groused Mabel. She turned to the girls. “You guys live here, so you lead the way. Take us to the best houses with the best candy. I’m talking chocolate bars the size of semis.”

“Uh, Mabel, I think quantity might matter more than quality tonight,” Dipper gently reminded.

“No way, bro-say. Mabel is the co-king of Halloween, which means she settles for nothing less than the biggest and the best.”

“Oh really?” asked the Trickster. He was sitting upon a flickering street light before planting his long, spindly feet down on Soos’ shoulders. Down at their level, the creature reached into the shaking man’s bag and pulled out his single candy to scrutinize. “Hmm. I’ve seen better.” He then absconded with the candy, along with Susan’s jackomellon, hopped onto a nearby house, and blew out the candle. “Tick tock.” And once more he vanished into the night.

“Mmmaybe quantity isn’t so bad,” Mabel conceded.

So they changed up their strategy. As it turned out, folks were willing to give out more candy to single kids rather than groups. Mabel and Dipper stuck together, laying it on thick with cute dances and poses. One man even cried a single tear of joy. With Soos pushing the wheel barrel, the gang was making excellent progress. Though they did almost suffer a collective heart attack at the sight of Toby. Something about the night made his face exponentially more frightening.

Only one other house stood out as particularly interesting. It was almost completely encased in spooky decorations, meaning that they most likely had the candy to match. Mabel rang the doorbell and got into the prime dancing position. But when the door opened, she tripped on her own feet. “M-Mrs. Corduroy?”

“Well hi, sugar pie,” she beamed her elation. Sheela was dressed as a sexy vampire with heavy eyeshadow, hair dyed violet, and a dress that was so form-fitting it was like someone had stuck in a vacuum and sucked out all the air until it hugged every contour of her body. The front of her dress was open, showing off a heart-stopping amount of cleavage and stretching dangerously south of her navel. She squeaked in glee. “Oh, goodness! Don’t ya’ll jus’ look like the sweetest treats Ah ever did see.”

Mabel had to punch her chest to make sure she was still breathing. “Erhem. Yes. Um, thanks again for earlier.” Her eyes kept being drawn down to the lovely woman’s chest, filling the little girl with an internal turmoil she didn’t fully understand.

“Weren’t nothin’, sugar. Ah’m jus’ sorry ya had ta go through with that in the first place. Must be tough bein’ so desirable.” She shot a playful wink at Dipper and tittered when his heart restarted. Then her nose crinkled and she turned a suspicious eye on the twins. “Ya’ll didn’t happen ta cross paths with a tall smelly fella, did ya?”

“If you mean the Summerween Trickster, then yes,” Dipper blurted, unable to keep anything from this woman.

Sheela rolled her eyes and clenched her fist. “That old fogey’s still kickin’? Bleh. This is why Ah wanna start an HOA. One second, kids. Ah’ll be right back.” She turned around, swaying her bootylicious rump as she went back inside.

“You’re staring,” growled Mabel.

“Hmm? Wha?”

“Don’t you ‘wha’, me. You were totally just staring at her boobs.”

“And you weren’t?”

“… That’s not the point. Grr! What is with guys and boobs? It’s just stupid chest fat and suddenly you go totally gaga.”

“Yeah? Well, at least I’m not so gaga that I missed what she said about the Trickster. Mabel, she talked like she knew him.”

“Stop trying to change the subject! Right now we’re talking about you and your stupid obsession with boobs.”

“My obsession? Mabel, I think you might be projecting a little, here.”

“No, I’m not!” she stomped her foot to the ground, plucked her brother off her head, and brought him up to her face in closed fingers. She held him close, squeezing to the point that it was hard to breathe, but didn’t actually hurt. In the dim, flickering lights of the jackomellons, it almost looked like her eyes were shimmering.

“Mabel…?”

Sheela cleared her throat, bringing all eyes back to her and her nonplussed expression. “Ya’ll are obviously under a lot ‘f stress right now. Ah won’t pry, but Ah can make things a bit easier.” She dropped a large sack in front of the twins. “The deal is fer 500 pieces ‘f candy, right? Well, that’s 312, every piece in the house. Ah want ya’ll ta give that creeper what he wants ‘n’ try ta have a nice Summerween. Ya’ll kids deserve it. Also, when ya give ‘im the candy, tell that sugar golem Sheela Corduroy wants him out of Gravity Falls by sunup.” Her expression softened and she bent down low, somehow showing off even more cleavage. “Think ya’ll can do that fer me?” The twins nodded. “Good. Well, have a happy Summerween,” she waved goodbye before closing the door.

Dipper pointed. “See! She knows something. Quick, ring the doorbell again so we can-”

“No.”

“I’m sorry, what?”

“I said no!” Mabel grabbed the bag, huffing and stomping her way back to the street. “Why are we even bothering? This night is ruined.”

“Hey, Mabel.” Dipper patted her fingers. “Mabel, talk to me. What’s wrong?”

“You. You’re what’s wrong. First, you try to ditch me to a stupid party cuz of Wendy’s boobs, Lazy Susan called me snot, then Sheela shook her big tits at you, and all night I’ve seen everyone else laughing and having fun while I’m not!”

“MABEL!” Dipper shouted with show-stopping force. He quickly lowered his volume to something softer. “Mabel, you were so gung-ho about trick or treating, even with ‘die’ at the end.”

“Well, I wasn’t, okay,” she sniffled, wiping her face on her sleeve. “I was just acting like people expect cuz I didn’t want to ruin everyone’s special night.”

“But… why didn’t you tell me?”

Mabel looked like she was about to answer, but then the others showed up, so she got cleaned up and put her happy face back on. In total, they’d collected over 700 pieces of candy, enough to satisfy the Trickster and hopefully have plenty leftover. Dipper, however, convinced the others to give him and Mabel some space so they could keep talking. Grenda and Candy went to do a little more trick or treating, Soos went to fetch his truck, and the twins stayed back to guard the candy.

Dipper now stood in Mabel’s open palm. “Talk to me, sis. What’s the matter?”

“D-do you think Wendy’s prettier than me?”

Dipper pursed his lips. “That’s like comparing gummy candy to chocolate.”

“And which do you like more?”

“Mabel, you’re my sister. I’ve been with you since before I can even remember, and I probably loved you longer. No one is going to change that.”

“Then why were you going to ditch me for the party?”

“I wasn’t. I told you, like, the minute Wendy left.”

“Only cuz I forced you. You were totally planning on ditching me,” she accused with rising ire.

“What? No. Okay, maybe I was tempted at first, but-”

“Ah-ha! You admit it.”

“But I didn’t. I chose the both of you. Isn’t that what all of this is supposed to be about?”

Then, when tensions were at their highest, Robbie drove up with Wendy in shotgun.

“Hey Dipper. Mabel. Those are… some…” The redhead went bug-eyed. “That is the most adorable thing I’ve ever seen in my life.”

Robbie was unimpressed. “You two losers aren’t going to the party like that ar-yahahow!” he cried as Wendy administered a purple nurple.

“You guys are comin’ though, right?”

Dipper looked between the two women of his life. One was biting her lip while seemingly hypnotized by something, and the other looked ready to blow her top any moment. “Uy, I’m gonna have to take a raincheck on that.” Swallowing his nerve, he added, “Mabel and I still have some heavy trick or treating to do.”

“You sure?” Wendy sounded hurt.

“Yeah, definitely.”

“Well, okay.” Wendy stopped hurting Robbie and slumped in her seat as the pair drove off.

“See, Mabel. In the end, you needed me more. Besides, there’ll be other parties. Plenty of chances to hang out with Wendy and-and I shouldn’t have said that.”
1213121111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Treating

1213121111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
In a fury, Mabel screamed up at the night’s sky. Then, taking the bag that Sheela had given her, she blindly swung it around and hit the wheel barrel, sending them both into the bushes.

“Mabel, what are you doing?”

“I don’t know, okay!” She dropped down, brought her knees in, and started crying. “I don’t know what’s wrong with me.”

Having hopped onto her knee, Dipper put aside all other concerns and sat down as well. The candy could wait. Summerween could wait. Wendy could wait. Right now, there was only Mabel. He touched her face and smiled softly when she looked up.

“I’m angry, Dipper,” she sniffled. “I’m angry even when I’m happy and I don’t know why. At first, I thought I was okay with you going after Wendy, but now thinking about it makes me all confused.”

“Do you want me to stop?”

Mabel pulled back. “What?”

“I asked if you want me to stop. Look, Mabel, if me liking Wendy is hurting you then… then I’ll stop.”

Mabel scowled. “Dipper, you can’t just turn love off like that.”

“Well, maybe it isn’t love. Maybe it’s just a passing crush.”

“Yeah, a two-way crush. Did you seriously just miss the way she was looking at you?” Mabel demanded. “I swear, if it was just you two alone, she’d rip you right out of that cherry and start making out here and now.”

It was Dipper’s turn to flinch at this unexpected revelation. There was a lot to unpack there. “Wait, so, you’d be fine with that?”

“I… I don’t think it really matters what I think.”

“Well, it matters to me.”

“But I can’t get in the way of your love life, Dipper. You and Wendy would make such a cute couple.” She sounded almost urging.

Dipper just looked thoughtful as he tried to process all this. “Then… what can I do to make you less angry? You know you’re prettier when you smile.”

Mabel buried her face back in her sleeves to hide her grin. “Shut up.”

“Make me.”

“How’d you like to spend the rest of the night shoved down my panties?”

“Eh. Seven fifty, even split.”

“That doesn’t even make any sense,” Mabel laughed.

“Yeah. I’ve been trying to learn to speak Mabel, but I can never get the accent right.”

Laughing uncontrollably, Mabel seized her brother and held him tight to her cheek. “You’re such a goofus,” she tittered. “You make me so mad, I just wanna kiss you all over.”

“Hold on. Is this regular happy, or angry happy?”

Open palm, she held Dipper out in front of her. “I’ve got the best brother in the world trying to cheer me up. I’m happy enough.”

“Good, cuz as your brother, I’m going to keep bugging you about this until we figure it out.”

Mabel giggled. “That’s all I need,” she sighed, finally feeling at peace.

“Uh, guys?” asked Grenda, startling the twins. “Not to break up this cute moment, but where’s the candy?”

“Oh, it must still be in the bushes. Come over here. I’ll show ya.” Wiping her face clean, Mabel pushed the shrubbery aside. Her gut and expression immediately dropped like stones as she watched the bag and what remained of the barrel’s candy floating down the stream. “Uh oh.”

“Mabel, what happened?”

“I, it was, um…”

“Look, the jackomelons!” Dipper deflected.

But seriously, all the lights were going out. All save one. The kids all rushed McGucket to steal his hollowed gourd, but their collective sighs of relief blew out the candle.

With only a single blinking streetlight left on, the Trickster stepped out from the dark and knocked on the air. “Knock, knock,” he wheezed, resuming his approach. “So, children. Where’s my candyyy?”

“I swear we had all 500 pieces!” Dipper pleaded. “Hell, we had 700. This nice lady-” He remembered. “Sheela Corduroy!”

The Trickster stopped. “What did you say?”

“Sh-Sheela Corduroy. She said she wanted you out of Gravity Falls by sunup.”

“Sunup, aye?” Then the Trickster started to laugh. “Mwahahaha! HA-HA-HA! Plenty of time.” The monster grew tall. It’s back swelled out of his shirt until an extra pair of arms burst out. Now more than twice its original size, the Trickster snatched up all four children and wheezed its terrible, sickly laugh.

Then Soos drove up in his truck, hitting the Trickster and smashing it to bits. When everyone was satisfied that they weren’t hurt, the kids all ran up to the very anxious hero of the hour. “That wasn’t, like, a regular pedestrian, was it?”

“No, Soos. That was the Trickster. And you saved us.”

“By killing it,” Mabel added. “You killed it to death!”

Everyone loaded up on the truck and they departed for somewhere to rest for the evening, not noticing how the chunks of monster moved across the ground and fused back together. In no time the Trickster had regained his full mass, now with a body like an eggplant with stick arms and a narrow head. The only bit of clothing he had left was his mask and he hissed as his instincts told him exactly where his prey was. But before he could resume his chase, he felt a presence. He turned to see a woman, lavishly dressed, and carrying a glass of what looked like wine in one hand.

“Ah wouldn’t do that if Ah was you, honey bun.”

“Sh-Sheela?” the Trickster said in alarm.

“Howdy there, Tricky,” she greeted with a friendly wave. “Fancy seein’ ya’ll here, in mah town.”

“Hey, this is Summerween. For this one night, all of Gravity Falls is my turf.”

“Mighty tall claim.” She took a sip of her drink. “Think ya can back it up?”

For a while, nothing happened. A standoff was in play between the voluptuous Sheela Corduroy, and the grotesque Summerween Trickster. Then the silence was broken.

“Filthy sugar golem,” Sheela spat, swirling her drink. “All the little feelings of disgust as kids threw away their unwanted candy, all added up to one hideous waste of space. Your whole existence is a bad joke.”

“Perhaps,” allowed the Trickster. “But tonight, it’s a joke on everyone’s lips. That belief gives me power; power enough to trounce the likes of you, witch.” He shook his fist at her.

“This is mah final warning, Tricky. Leave Gravity Falls ‘n’ never come back. Cuz if Ah catch you after the sun rises, well, you know what’ll happen.”

“Oh, very well. I’ll leave. This town was getting too small for me, anyway. Think I’ll go restart my legend elsewhere. However, I still have one last curse to cast.”

“You leave those kids alone!” Sheela stomped her foot down, leaving a small dent in the gravel. “Or Ah swear Ah’ll hunt you down for the remainder of yer short existence!”

The Trickster just laughed. “Try me.”
1213121111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Truth

1213121111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
“So, that was some pretty heavy stuff back there,” Grenda said from the backseat, staring straight at the twins. “Is, uh, everything alright?”

“Yes. I hope everyone is feeling okay now that the danger has passed.” As Candy finished speaking, everyone but her face-palmed. “What?”

“You jinxed it,” Grenda answered. “Bad Candy. Bad.”

“Uh, dudes,” Soos said, checking the rearview mirror.

The monster was back in pursuit. It hobbled a little, almost like it had a limp, but it was still faster than any motor vehicle. The Trickster leaped into the air and jumped down on the truck, denting the roof as it maneuvered to block the front. Soos managed to swerve and knock it into a lamppost, breaking it. However, he lost control and drove straight into the store from earlier. Everyone hid as the monster followed after them and began its search.

“Okay, I was trying to be delicate before, but this is serious,” Grenda whisper hissed. “Mabel, did something happen to you?”

Candy narrowed her eyes on the minizora, though her words were directed at Mabel. “I hope no one was stupid enough to hurt you.”

“Guys, this is seriously not a good time,” Dipper stressed.

“No, this needs to be said,” Mabel relented. “Guys, I’m sorry for how I acted tonight. I’ve been kind of moody for a while. I know it’s no excuse, but I want you to understand that… that when the Trickster said one of us didn’t have the Summerween spirit, I’m pretty sure he meant me. I understand if you guys don’t want to hang out with me anymore after this.”

Candy adjusted her glasses. “No offense, Mabel, but you are quite stupid.”

“Say what now?”

“Yeah. The whole point of being friends is to stick together through the hard times. We’ve been trick or treating together all night, and you think we’d abandon you now? Honestly, I’m insulted.”

Mabel sniffled, fighting a losing battle against her tears. “You guys!”

“Hey, I just thought of something.” Dipper tapped his foot to Mabel’s neck. “If this thing can sense spirit, how come he hasn’t found us yet?”

“I don’t know, dude. Looks to me like he ain’t walkin’ straight.” As Soos spoke, the Trickster tripped on its own feet and knocked over a display. “Maybe he hit his head and now there’s a screw loose.”

“Probably the truck,” reasoned Dipper.

Unable to find its prey, the Trickster roared.

“We have to escape.”

“What if it sees us?”

“If only there was something we could use to cover our bodies and faces with. You know, like a disguise,” suggested Soos. However, while everyone was in awe and waited for the mic to drop, Soos disappointingly proved to be just as oblivious as he sounded.

The children and man-child did manage to find alternate costumes to resemble inanimate decorations. Following video game logic, they moved only when the Trickster had its back turned and froze when it looked their way. It was working and they almost made it out. Unfortunately, just when it looked like they were home free, Soos soosed up by tapping a singing skeleton head. The Trickster appeared behind him, opened its enormously grotesque mouth, and swallowed the big guy in one gulp.

Mabel let out an unearthly shriek and charged in a blind rage towards the monster. After the night she’d had so far, she was in no mood to lose anyone. While she scurried around its arms, breaking them with her bare hands while they kept reforming, the others armed. Whatever those fake Medieval weapons were made of, they were definitely not child-friendly as the kids hacked away. Dipper, remembering the Multibear, had Candy throw him approximately where the monster’s groin was in the hopes of hitting the weak point. However, as he trudged through the gooey stickiness, something became apparent.

Mabel spat after biting through the Trickster’s elbow. “Bleh! Saltwater taffy?”

Dipper tripped and face planted on the monster’s flesh. “Candy corn?”

“You really haven’t figured it out yet?” Having recovered from the surprise attack, the Trickster once more grabbed up all the kids. Candy, Grenda, and Dipper had to share one hand since two were needed to restrain both Mabel’s body and mouth. The last hand removed the Trickster’s mask. “Don’t you recognize me? Look at my face. Look… closely.”

Everyone gasped. “Loser candy.”

The Trickster was made up entirely of unpopular candy. Like any good villain, with the heroes unable to escape, he exposited his backstory. He was made up of all the candy the kids of Gravity Falls ever threw away, so now he seeks revenge for their pickiness. “No one would eat me, so now I’m going to eat you.” Then he started to scream and writhe in agony. Something was moving deep in his gut.

Soos burst forth, squealing like a mad pig as he held a large pulsing clump of candy. He pushed it out further, severing the strands that connected it to the main body. As a result, the Trickster fell over, spewing sugary gore as he dropped the children. Soos, meanwhile, sat atop his fallen enemy and casually ate his internal organs. “Dudes, you want some of this?” he asked with a level of casualness that frightened the other kids.

“Wait,” wheezed the Trickster. “You think I taste… good?”

“Yeah. Sure.”

“All I ever wanted was for someone to say that I was… good.” Crying candy tears of joy, the Trickster stopped fighting and finally passed away.

Also, the other kid emerged from the corpse, having somehow remained inside and unharmed even after the truck impact. Soos’ truck was still in reasonable order, so they all took it and left, calling it a night. Back at the Shack, everyone found Stan looking very pleased with himself for scaring some trick or treaters, along with a certain someone carving a jackomellon in the corner.

“Hey, guys.”

“Wendy,” Dipper greeted excitedly, only to pause and check with Mabel. She smiled appreciatively of his consideration and carried him over. “How was the party?”

“Ugh. Lame. The highlight was Robbie eating a lollipop stick first and needing to go to the hospital. Honestly, I think I would’ve had more fun trick or treating with you guys.” She sighed wistfully. “I miss those days.”

“Yeah, we could have used your help,” Mabel said.

“We fought the Summerween Trickster!” Grenda cheered.

Candy straightened her glasses. “It was a harrowing and stressful ordeal, but we have emerged stronger for it.”

Wendy blinked and looked at Dipper. “Seriously?”

“We’re never going to throw away unwanted candy ever again,” he avowed. “From now on, we’re throwing it into the fire so it can’t come back and get us later. Also, Soos ate him from the inside out.”

Wendy turned to Soos who was smacking his lips from an apparently delicious aftertaste. “Why do you guys get all the fun?”
1213121111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Trickster Trounced

1213121111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Manly Dan was a mighty proud father. His children had claimed a mighty haul of treasure this year. So much so that they were having a hard time carrying it all, which was probably the best kind of problem one could have. They didn’t complain, though. They’d seen that one group with the wheel barrel, but not one mentioned regret at not bringing one themselves. This made Dan proud. Hard work, he’d taught them, was its own reward. The candy was just a bonus. They’d learned this lesson well and it almost moved him to manly tears.

“Hey, dad,” said Gus, the youngest of his sons. “What’s that?”

“Looks like some kind of speedbump, but really weirdly shaped,” added Kevin, the middle son.

“I don’t think they’d do construction tonight. Maybe it fell off a truck,” reasoned the eldest son Marcus.

Manly Dan, after his eyes adjusted to the dim light, recognized the voluptuous shape and his face went pale. “Uh, kids, let’s hurry home.” He started pushing them away from the scene. “You’ll need to sort out your candy so it’ll last a few weeks. Remember to share,” he added, finally getting them to their front door. Luckily it was unlocked.

“Aren’t you gonna help us, dad?” asked Gus.

“Not right now, my sons. Dad, uh, needs to…”

Kevin pushed the door open and noticed the absence of a constrictive hug threatening to suffocate him in soft, womanly flesh. “And where’s mom?”

“Dad has to go find mom,” Dan answered honestly enough. “She probably saw Wendy’s new boyfriend and has him pinned up a tree somewhere.”

The boys laughed, accepting the plausibility of this explanation without question, and headed inside. Once the door was shut, Dan sprinted over to the scene of the incident. The gravel road was a mess with chunks of debris torn up and scattered all over the place. At the epicenter, in a modest crater, was the back of a woman. Her front half was submerged in the ground. Her formfitting dress had been torn to shreds, barely containing her curvaceous figure. In fact, it was that rounded booty that Dan recognized as his wife’s.

“Honey, can you hear me?” Dan boomed.

Recognizing his voice, Sheela started twitching and making sounds. Unfortunately, the road muffled her voice and she was wedged in too deep to get any leverage to pull herself out.

“Don’t worry, honey. I got ya!” Dan stabbed his fingers to either side of his wife’s waist, wrapped them around her childbearing hips, and carefully extricated her from the ground. Chunks of rock fell all around her as she coughed and sputtered. The front of her dress was even worse than the back and something the kids were not ready to see. Though to be fair, no kid was ever ready to see their mom in such a state. Cradling his wife bridal style, he tapped on her cheek. “Speak to me, honey.”

Sheela groaned. “Ah’m in tremendous pain.”

“I see that.” Dan looked her up and down, already imagining all the terrible things he would do to whoever did this to his beloved. “What happened?”

Sheela coughed and spat out some gravel mixed with blood. “It was… Tricky.”

“The Trickster?” Dan said in alarm. “I thought you took care of that monster already.”

“Ah did, too,” Sheela groaned. She curled up against her husband’s chest, finding comfort in his warm muscles. “Ah might be gone for a few months. You understand.”

“I do,” Dan grimly agreed, knowing full well what had happened and what his wife was honor-bound to do. It was a tragic thing, but justice needed to be served. “Who was it?”

Sheela pressed herself tighter into her husband. “Wendy’s friends. The Pines twins.”

“Pines? The tiny boy and his demon attack dog?”

Sheela looked up, confused by her husband’s tone. “Yes. Why?”

“I just saw them not a few minutes ago. They were driving with that chipmunk guy from the Mystery Shack. Pretty sure I heard them laughing.”

“A few minutes?” Sheela’s eyes darted around as she processed this. “Ah was down there for a good half hour, at least.” Her expression of embittered sorrow quickly morphed to one of joy. “So then… they survived! Ye-haw!” With new energy she jumped up and wrapped her arms around Dan’s neck, peppering his face with kisses. She then regretted her emotional outburst. “Yikes! Ow, ow, ow,” she winced while slipping back to her more relaxed position. “This can only mean… they beat ‘im,” she giggled.

“Those kids and the fat guy beat the Trickster?” Dan asked, barely able to believe it. Then he looked down at the woman in his arms and smiled. “Let me guess. You softened him up for ‘em.”

“Even if I did, that’s still a hell of a thing,” Sheela intoned. “Ah knew there was somethin’ Ah liked about those kids. Looks like they’ve got a lot more goin’ for ‘em than jus’ bein’ cute,” she giggled, looking around. “The boys?”

“At home sorting candy. I told ‘em you were giving Wendy’s new boyfriend a rough time.”
